CHAPTER I: A little page brought the glass of spirits and some salt fish on a tray.Uvar Ivanovitch slowly took the glass from the tray and gazed a long while with intense attention at it, as though he could not quite understand what it was he had in his hand.Then he looked at the page and asked him, ‘Wasn’t his name Vaska?’Then he assumed an air of resignation, drank off the spirit, munched the herring and was slowly proceeding to get his handkerchief out of his pocket.But the page had long ago carried off and put away the tray and the decanter, eaten up the remains of the herring and had time to go off to sleep, curled up in a great-coat of his master’s, while Uvar Ivanovitch still continued to hold the handkerchief before him in his opened fingers, and with the same intense attention gazed now at the window, now at the floor and walls.

第一章: 第九章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER IX

第一章: 舒宾回到了自己的小屋，刚打开一本书来读，这时尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇的男仆小心地走进他房里，交给他一个折了三折的小纸条，纸条顶部被一个厚重的纹章封住了。“我期望，”他看到纸条上写着，“你是一个高尚的人，你不会透露一丁点儿有关早上我们说过的那张期票的消息。你很清楚我的地位和我做事的原则，你也知道那笔钱和另外那件事对我来说无足轻重。最后，为了大家好，还有一些家庭秘密必须被尊重，保持家庭里的平静是神圣的，只有那些没心没肺的人（当然，我并没任何原因将你也算在这些人中）才会去破坏它！（阅后请退回。）——尼·斯”
CHAPTER I: Shubin went back to his room in the lodge and was just opening a book, when Nikolai Artemyevitch’s valet came cautiously into his room and handed him a small triangular note, sealed with a thick heraldic crest.‘I hope,’ he found in the note, ‘that you as a man of honour will not allow yourself to hint by so much as a single word at a certain promissory note which was talked of this morning.You are acquainted with my position and my rules, the insignificance of the sum in itself and the other circumstances; there are, in fine, family secrets which must be respected, and family tranquillity is something so sacred that only etres sans cour (among whom I have no reason to reckon you) would repudiate it!Give this note back to me.—N.S.’

第一章: 舒宾用铅笔在纸条下面潦草写道：“你别激动，我还不是个喜欢告密的人。”然后把纸条还给那个佣人，接着又读起书来。然而，那本书突然从他手里滑了下去。他看了看红彤彤的天空，又看了看树林中孤立在那里的两棵高大挺拔的新栽不久的松树，想着：“白天里，那些松树都是浅蓝色的，但一到了晚上，它们竟会变成如此美丽的青翠色。”然后，他出门走进花园，心里暗暗希望能在那里见到埃琳娜。他的猜测并没有错。在他前面那条灌木丛中的小径上，他瞥见了她的衣服。他追了上去，等到和她并肩走着的时候，他说：
CHAPTER I: Shubin scribbled below in pencil: ‘Don’t excite yourself, I’m not quite a sneak yet,’ and gave the note back to the man, and again began upon the book.But it soon slipped out of his hands.He looked at the reddening-sky, at the two mighty young pines standing apart from the other trees, thought ‘by day pines are bluish, but how magnificently green they are in the evening,’ and went out into the garden, in the secret hope of meeting Elena there.He was not mistaken.Before him on a path between the bushes he caught a glimpse of her dress.He went after her, and when he was abreast with her, remarked:

第一章: “不要朝我这里看，我可不值得你看啊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Don’t look in my direction, I’m not worth it.’

第一章: 她匆匆扫了他一眼，然后大笑了起来，接着向花园深处走去。舒宾跟在她后面。
CHAPTER I: She gave him a cursory glance, smiled cursorily, and walked on further into the depths of the garden.Shubin went after her.

第一章: “我求你不要看我，”他说，“但是我想跟你谈谈，我知道这样很前后矛盾。不过这又有什么关系呢？我已经不是第一次这样自相矛盾了。我刚想起来，我还没对昨天我那愚蠢的行为向你道歉呢。你不生我的气吧，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜？或者你还在生我的气？”
CHAPTER I: ‘I beg you not to look at me,’ he began, ‘and then I address you; flagrant contradiction.But what of that? it’s not the first time I’ve contradicted myself.I have just recollected that I have never begged your pardon as I ought for my stupid behaviour yesterday.You are not angry with me, Elena Nikolaevna, are you?’

第一章: 她静静站着，没有立即回答他——不是因为她还在生气，而是因为她的心思已经跑远了。
CHAPTER I: She stood still and did not answer him at once—not because she was angry, but because her thoughts were far away.

第一章: “没有，”最后她说道，“我一点儿也没生气。”舒宾咬了咬嘴唇。
CHAPTER I: ‘No,’ she said at last, ‘I am not in the least angry.’Shubin bit his lip.

第一章: “多么吸引人……却又冷淡的面孔啊！”他嘟囔着，“埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”他提高音量说，“我来给你说个小笑话吧。我有个朋友，而我这个朋友又有个朋友，那个人起初是个正儿八经的绅士，但后来却变成了个酒鬼。一天早上，我朋友在街上遇到了他（注意，那个时候，他们已经不再来往了），看到他醉醺醺的。我朋友竟然转过身背对着他。然而他那个朋友却跑过去对他说，‘我不会生气的，’他说，‘如果你拒绝认出我的话，但你为何要转过身去不看我呢？或许是我今天运气太差了。愿我死后能安息吧！’”
CHAPTER I: ‘What an absorbed… and what an indifferent face!’ he muttered.‘Elena Nikolaevna,’ he continued, raising his voice, ‘allow me to tell you a little anecdote.I had a friend, and this friend also had a friend, who at first conducted himself as befits a gentleman but afterwards took to drink.So one day early in the morning, my friend meets him in the street (and by that time, note, the acquaintance has been completely dropped) meets him and sees he is drunk.My friend went and turned his back on him.But he ran up and said, “I would not be angry,” says he, “if you refused to recognise me, but why should you turn your back on me?Perhaps I have been brought to this through grief.Peace to my ashes!”’

第一章: 舒宾停了下来。
CHAPTER I: Shubin paused.

第一章: “就这些吗？”埃琳娜问。
CHAPTER I: ‘And is that all?’ inquired Elena.

第一章: “是的，就这些。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes that’s all.’

第一章: “我实在不明白。你到底在暗示什么？是你刚才对我说，让我不要看你的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t understand you.What are you hinting at?You told me just now not to look your way.’

第一章: “是的，但是我现在告诉你：你转身背对我让我感觉很难过。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, and now I have told you that it’s too bad to turn your back on me.’

第一章: “但是，我有那样过吗？”埃琳娜开口说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘But did I?’ began Elena.

第一章: “难道你没有那样吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Did you not?’

第一章: 埃琳娜的脸微微泛红了，她把手伸向舒宾。他亲切地握着她的手。
CHAPTER I: Elena flushed slightly and held out her hand to Shubin.He pressed it warmly.

第一章: “你好像真的认为我很讨厌你，”埃琳娜说，“但是你的猜测并不正确。我甚至都没有想过要躲着你。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Here you seem to have convicted me of a bad feeling,’ said Elena, ‘but your suspicion is unjust.I was not even thinking of Avoiding you.’

第一章: “哪能啊，哪能啊。但是你必须承认，就算那时你脑海里有上千个想法，你也不会告诉我其中任何一个吧。嗯？我说的是事实吧？我没说错吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Granted, granted.But you must acknowledge that at that minute you had a thousand ideas in your head of which you would not confide one to me.Eh? I’ve spoken the truth, I’m quite sure?’

第一章: “或许是这样吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Perhaps so.’

第一章: “但是，这是为什么呢？为什么？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And why is it?why?’

第一章: “我也不清楚自己的想法。”埃琳娜说。
CHAPTER I: ‘My ideas are not clear to myself,’ said Elena.

第一章: “那么现在正是和别人说说这些想法的时候。”舒宾接着说，“但是，我会告诉你其实是怎么回事。你对我印象不好。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Then it’s just the time for confiding them to some one else,’ put in Shubin.‘But I will tell you what it really is.You have a bad opinion of me.’

第一章: “是的，你。你总觉得我这个人的一切都不真实，只因为我是个艺术家。你认为我不但什么也做不了——因为你很可能是对的——而且也总是虚情假意，你甚至都觉得我连哭都是故意装出来的，认为我是个爱传闲话和诽谤别人的人——所有的这些都只是因为我是个艺术家。我们这些艺术家真是不幸的、被上帝抛弃的可怜虫，总是被人那样想！就拿你举例来说，我喜欢你，但你根本就不相信我能悔改。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes you; you imagine that everything in me is half-humbug because I am an artist, that I am incapable not only of doing anything—in that you are very likely right—but even of any genuine deep feeling; you think that I am not capable even of weeping sincerely, that I’m a gossip and a slanderer—and all because I’m an artist.What luckless, God-forsaken wretches we artists are after that!You, for instance, I am ready to adore, and you don’t believe in my repentance.’

第一章: “不是的，帕维尔·雅克夫利奇，我一直都相信你能悔改，我也相信你的眼泪。不过我总觉得你的悔改和眼泪都是用来令你自己安心用的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, Pavel Yakovlitch, I believe in your repentance and I believe in your tears.But it seems to me that even your repentance amuses you—yes and your tears too.’

第一章: 舒宾哆嗦了一下。
CHAPTER I: Shubin shuddered.

第一章: “好了，我明白了，这就是医生常说的那种无药可医的疾病。没办法，我只能低头屈服了。可同时，天啊，当一个如此崇高的灵魂生活在我身边时，难道我还能如此自私吗？难道我能真的这样做吗?我也明白，其他人永远都不可能看穿这个灵魂，永远都不会理解它为何会苦恼，为何会快乐，它究竟在想些什么，追求些什么——准备到哪里去……告诉我，”他沉默了一会儿说道，“在任何情况下你都不会喜欢上一个艺术家吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, I see this is, as the doctors say, a hopeless case, casus incurabilis.There is nothing left but to bow the head and submit.And meanwhile, good Heavens, can it be true, can I possibly be absorbed in my own egoism when there is a soul like this living at my side?And to know that one will never penetrate into that soul, never will know why it grieves and why it rejoices, what is working within it, what it desires—whither it is going…Tell me,’ he said after a short silence, ‘could you never under any circumstances love an artist?’

第一章: 埃琳娜直视着他的眼睛。
CHAPTER I: Elena looked straight into his eyes.

第一章: “我想不会的，帕维尔·雅克夫利奇，不会的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t think so, Pavel Yakovlitch; no.’

第一章: “我只想证实一下。”舒宾滑稽又沮丧地说道，“我想以后你一个人散步的时候，我最好还是不要打扰你吧。如果是一个教授，他会问你为什么回答说‘不会’。虽然我不是个教授，而且依据你的观点，我还是个长不大的小孩，但是你要记住，即使是在小孩面前，人们也不会转身背向他的。再见！愿我死后安息！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Which was to be proved,’ said Shubin with comical dejection.‘After which I suppose it would be more seemly for me not to intrude on your solitary walk.A professor would ask you on what data you founded your answer no.I’m not a professor though, but a baby according to your ideas; but one does not turn one’s back on a baby, remember.Good-bye!Peace to my ashes!’

第一章: 埃琳娜刚想挽留他，但想了一下，她也说道：
CHAPTER I: Elena was on the point of stopping him, but after a moment’s thought she too said:

第一章: “再见。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Good-bye.’

第一章: 舒宾从院子里走了出来。在离斯塔霍夫房子不远的地方，他看到了别尔谢涅夫。他正急匆匆地走着，低着头，帽子向后掀到了脖子上。
CHAPTER I: Shubin went out of the courtyard.At a short distance from the Stahov’s house he was met by Bersenyev.He was walking with hurried steps, his head bent and his hat pushed back on his neck.

第一章: “安德烈·彼得罗维奇！”舒宾喊道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Andrei Petrovitch!’ cried Shubin.

第一章: 他停下了脚步。
CHAPTER I: He stopped.

第一章: “快走吧，快走吧，”舒宾继续说着，“我只想喊一下你，我可不想耽误你的时间——你最好直接去花园——埃琳娜也在那里，我想她是在等你吧……不管怎样，她是在等人的……你理解这些话的意思吧，她在等你呢！我亲爱的朋友，你知道这是多么令人意外的情况吗？你想想看，到现在为止，我跟她在同一个房子里共同生活了两年，我爱上了她，可是就在刚才，在那几分钟里，我才真正见到她是什么样的，虽然我还不能理解她。我见到真实的她以后太惊讶了，才会放开她的手。请你不要带着那种虚假讽刺的笑容看着我，这可一点儿都不符合你沉稳冷静的风格。好了，现在，我猜你想要提醒我关于安努什卡的事。那又怎么样呢？我不会否认的。安努什卡跟我一样可怜。所有的安努什卡，所有的卓娅，甚至所有的奥古斯丁娜·克里斯蒂安诺夫娜万岁！你现在去见埃琳娜吧，我则会去——你认为我会去见安努什卡吧？不，亲爱的朋友，比见她还糟糕些，我要去找齐库拉索夫公爵。他被认为是喀山鞑靼人中的米西纳斯，跟沃尔金差不多。你看看这邀请函，看看这些字母：R.S.V.P.？即使来到乡下，我也片刻不得安宁。再见！”别尔谢涅夫静静地听着舒宾的长篇大论，看上去似乎有些为他感到难为情。然后他就走进斯塔霍夫家的庭院里。而舒宾则真去找齐库拉索夫公爵了。那位公爵面带一副极热忱的神情，却说了许多十分无礼的话。那个喀山鞑靼人的米西纳斯微笑着，米西纳斯的宾客们也都附和着哈哈大笑，然而没有一个人真正觉得高兴，宴会结束后，每个人的心情都很不好。因此，当两个不太熟悉的先生在涅瓦大街偶遇之后，可能会见到对方瞬间龇牙咧嘴地笑起来，眼睛、鼻子和脸蛋都皱在一起，然后，他们快速地离开对方，恢复到之前那种冷漠的或是常常交织着虚弱病态的表情。
CHAPTER I: ‘Go on, go on,’ continued Shubin, ‘I only shouted, I won’t detain you—and you’d better slip straight into the garden—you’ll find Elena there, I fancy she’s waiting for you… she’s waiting for some one anyway….Do you understand the force of those words: she is waiting!And do you know, my dear boy, an astonishing circumstance?Imagine, it’s two years now that I have been living in the same house with her, I’m in love with her, and it’s only just now, this minute, that I’ve, not understood, but really seen her.I have seen her and I lifted up my hands in amazement.Don’t look at me, please, with that sham sarcastic smile, which does not suit your sober features.Well, now, I suppose you want to remind me of Annushka.What of it?I don’t deny it.Annushkas are on my poor level.And long life to all Annushkas and Zoyas and even Augustina Christianovnas!You go to Elena now, and I will make my way to—Annushka, you fancy?No, my dear fellow, worse than that; to Prince Tchikurasov.He is a Maecenas of a Kazan-Tartar stock, after the style of Volgin.Do you see this note of invitation, these letters, R.S.V.P.?Even in the country there’s no peace for me.Addio!’Bersenyev listened to Shubin’s tirade in silence, looking as though he were just a little ashamed of him.Then he went into the courtyard of the Stahovs’ house.And Shubin did really go to Prince Tchikurasov, to whom with the most cordial air he began saying the most insulting things.The Maecenas of the Tartars of Kazan chuckled; the Maecenas’s guests laughed, but no one felt merry, and every one was in a bad temper when the party broke up.So two gentlemen slightly acquainted may be seen when they meet on the Nevsky Prospect suddenly grinning at one another and pursing up their eyes and noses and cheeks, and then, directly they have passed one another, they resume their former indifferent, often cross, and generally sickly, expression.

第一章: 第十章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER X

第一章: 埃琳娜见到别尔谢涅夫后很热情，不过他们不是在花园里遇到的，而是在会客厅里。他们一见面，埃琳娜就立刻而且几乎是按捺不住地与他聊起前一天未结束的谈话。刚才会客厅里只有她一个人，尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇已经悄悄地离开了。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜则顶着一条湿毛巾在楼上躺着。卓娅坐在她身边，仔细地理了理自己的裙子，两只小手紧紧地抱着膝盖。而尤瓦·伊万诺维奇此时正躺在顶楼一个被称为“赛尔号”或是“酣睡者”的又大又舒适的长沙发上睡着了。别尔谢涅夫又提起了自己的父亲，他很珍惜这段记忆。那么，让我们也稍微了解一下他的父亲吧。
CHAPTER I: Elena met Bersenyev cordially, though not in the garden, but the drawing-room, and at once, almost impatiently, renewed the conversation of the previous day.She was alone; Nikolai Artemyevitch had quietly slipped away.Anna Vassilyevna was lying down upstairs with a wet bandage on her head.Zoya was sitting by her, the folds of her skirt arranged precisely about her, and her little hands clasped on her knees.Uvar Ivanovitch was reposing in the attic on a wide and comfortable divan, known as a ‘samo-son’ or ‘dozer.’Bersenyev again mentioned his father; he held his memory sacred.Let us, too, say a few words about him.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫的父亲共有八十二个农奴，但在他去世之前他把他们放了；他毕业于老哥廷根大学，是“光照会”的一员，还是《论世界中精神的转化或象征》这本著作的作者——在这本书里，谢林的哲学观、瑞典堡主义和共产主义被别出心裁地融合在了一起。别尔谢涅夫的母亲去世之后，父亲就立刻把还是小孩子的他带到了莫斯科，并立即亲自负责起对他的教育。他认真地准备每一节课，虽然倾尽全力，但还是完全失败了：因为他是一个梦想家，一个书虫，一个神秘主义者；他嗓音低沉，说话犹豫，经常用一些晦涩难懂、拐弯抹角的语言来表达自己，他也喜欢说一些隐喻性的话语，而且，即使在自己疼爱的儿子面前也会害羞。所以，儿子对父亲所讲的课困惑不解，而且学习上停滞不前也就不足令人为奇了。老人（他当时已差不多五十岁了，他结婚很晚）最终料想事情进行得并不顺利，就把安德烈送进了一所学校。安德烈开始在学校学习了，但他还是没有摆脱父亲的监督。父亲经常会到学校看望他，就连校长也对他的教导和谈话烦到了极点；老师们也很讨厌他的突然来访；他还总是带给他们一些书，就像他们所说的那样，都是些勉强算得上关于教育的书。看到这位老先生那黝黑的、布满麻点的脸孔，细长的手指，还有他那总是裹在身上的窄小的灰色外套，甚至连学生们都会感到尴尬。那时孩子们都没有料到，这个威严、长鼻子、像鹤一样迈着大步的老先生心里会像对待自己儿子那样关心和记挂着所有的学生。有一次，他想到要跟学生们讲讲华盛顿的故事。“充满朝气的同学们，”他开始讲道，但一听到他那奇怪的声音，充满朝气的同学们就全都跑掉了。这位优秀的老哥廷根学生并没有生活在安乐窝里；历史年轮的滚动让他感到颓丧，各种各样的问题和看法让他感到心情沉重。当年少的别尔谢涅夫进入大学后，父亲总是让他去听一些讲座，但他父亲自己的身体却是越来越不好了。1848年发生的事件彻底震撼了别尔谢涅夫的父亲（令他必须完全重写他的书），然而他却在1853年的冬天去世了，当时他的儿子还没有大学毕业，但他已经提前祝贺他获得学位，并鼓励他投身到科学事业当中。“我把火炬传给你，”在去世前两小时，他对儿子说道，“当我有能力时我一直在拿着它，你也一样，千万不能在你生命结束之前让火炬之火变得暗淡。”
CHAPTER I: The owner of eighty-two serfs, whom he set free before his death, an old Gottingen student, and disciple of the ‘Illuminati,’ the author of a manuscript work on ‘transformations or typifications of the spirit in the world’—a work in which Schelling’s philosophy, Swedenborgianism and republicanism were mingled in the most original fashion—Bersenyev’s father brought him, while still a boy, to Moscow immediately after his mother’s death, and at once himself undertook his education.He prepared himself for each lesson, exerted himself with extraordinary conscientiousness and absolute lack of success: he was a dreamer, a bookworm, and a mystic; he spoke in a dull, hesitating voice, used obscure and roundabout expressions, metaphorical by preference, and was shy even of his son, whom he loved passionately.It was not surprising that his son was simply bewildered at his lessons, and did not advance in the least.The old man (he was almost fifty, he had married late in life) surmised at last that things were not going quite right, and he placed his Andrei in a school.Andrei began to learn, but he was not removed from his father’s supervision; his father visited him unceasingly, wearying the schoolmaster to death with his instructions and conversation; the teachers, too, were bored by his uninvited visits; he was for ever bringing them some, as they said, far-fetched books on education.Even the schoolboys were embarrassed at the sight of the old man’s swarthy, pockmarked face, his lank figure, invariably clothed in a sort of scanty grey dresscoat.The boys did not suspect then that this grim, unsmiling old gentleman, with his crane-like gait and his long nose, was at heart troubling and yearning over each one of them almost as over his own son.He once conceived the idea of talking to them about Washington: ‘My young nurslings,’ he began, but at the first sounds of his strange voice the young nurslings ran away.The good old Gottingen student did not lie on a bed of roses; he was for ever weighed down by the march of history, by questions and ideas of every kind.When young Bersenyev entered the university, his father used to drive with him to the lectures, but his health was already beginning to break up.The events of the year 1848 shook him to the foundation (it necessitated the re-writing of his whole book), and he died in the winter of 1853, before his son’s time at the university was over, but he was able beforehand to congratulate him on his degree, and to consecrate him to the service of science.‘I pass on the torch to you,’ he said to him two hours before his death.‘I held it while I could; you, too, must not let the light grow dim before the end.’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫跟埃琳娜谈了很久关于他父亲的事情。他在她面前那种尴尬的感觉现在也消失不见了，说话的时候也流利了很多。之后，交谈的话题转移到了大学上。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev talked a long while to Elena of his father.The embarrassment he had felt in her presence disappeared, and his lisp was less marked.The conversation passed on to the university.

第一章: “告诉我，”埃琳娜问他，“在你的同学里面，有没有那种十分优秀的人？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Tell me,’ Elena asked him, ‘were there any remarkable men among your comrades?’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫再次想起了舒宾所说的话。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev was again reminded of Shubin’s words.

第一章: “没有，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，实话跟你说吧，我们之中一个优秀的人都没有。而且确实是这样的，到哪里去找这样的人啊！听说，莫斯科大学曾经也是很辉煌的！但它现在却不再辉煌。现在，它只是一所学校，而不是一所大学。和我的同学在一起，我一点儿也不快乐。”他接着又低声说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘No, Elena Nikolaevna, to tell you the truth, there was not a single remarkable man among us.And, indeed, where are such to be found!There was, they say, a good time once in the Moscow university!But not now.Now it’s a school, not a university.I was not happy with my comrades,’ he added, dropping his voice.

第一章: “不快乐，”埃琳娜咕哝着说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Not happy,’ murmured Elena.

第一章: “不过，”别尔谢涅夫继续说着，“却有一个例外。我认识一个同学——他跟我不是一个院系的——但他倒是一个十分优秀的人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘But I ought,’ continued Bersenyev, ‘to make an exception.I know one student—it’s true he is not in the same faculty—he is certainly a remarkable man.’

第一章: “他叫什么？”埃琳娜充满兴趣地问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What is his name?’Elena inquired with interest.

第一章: “他叫德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇·因萨罗夫。是个保加利亚人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Insarov Dmitri Nikanorovitch.He is a Bulgarian.’

第一章: “不是俄国人吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Not a Russian?’

第一章: “嗯，他不是俄国人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, he is not a Russian,’

第一章: “那他为何会住在莫斯科呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why is he living in Moscow, then?’

第一章: “他来这边是为了学习。你知道他学习的目的是什么吗？他只有一个梦想，那就是解放他的祖国。他的经历也十分地与众不同。他的父亲是一个十分成功的商人，来自图尔诺沃。图尔诺沃现在是一个很小的城市，但在过去，当保加利亚还是个独立的国家时，它曾是保加利亚的首都。他父亲的生意都在索非亚，和俄国也有些关系。他的妹妹，即因萨罗夫的姑妈，仍然住在基辅，嫁给了当地一所高级中学里的历史老师。1835年，也就是说在十八年前，发生了一件十分可怕的事情：因萨罗夫的母亲突然失踪了，没有留下一点儿踪迹，一个星期之后，她的尸体被发现，是被人谋杀的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘He came here to study.And do you know with what aim he is studying?He has a single idea: the liberation of his country.And his story is an exceptional one.His father was a fairly well-to-do merchant; he came from Tirnova.Tirnova is now a small town, but it was the capital of Bulgaria in the old days when Bulgaria was still an independent state.He traded with Sophia, and had relations with Russia; his sister, Insarov’s aunt, is still living in Kiev, married to a senior history teacher in the gymnasium there.In 1835, that is to say eighteen years ago, a terrible crime was committed; Insarov’s mother suddenly disappeared without leaving a trace behind; a week later she was found murdered.’

第一章: 埃琳娜哆嗦了一下。别尔谢涅夫停了下来。
CHAPTER I: Elena shuddered.Bersenyev stopped.

第一章: “继续说，继续说。”她说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Go on, go on,’ she said.

第一章: “谣言说，她是被一个土耳其官员侮辱后杀死的，她的丈夫，也就是因萨罗夫的父亲，查到真相之后，试图为妻子报仇，但仅仅用匕首扎伤了那个官员……然后他的父亲就被枪决了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘There were rumours that she had been outraged and murdered by a Turkish aga; her husband, Insarov’s father, found out the truth, tried to avenge her, but only succeeded in wounding the aga with his poniard….He was shot.’

第一章: “枪决了？都没有审讯？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Shot, and without a trial?’

第一章: “是的。那个时候因萨罗夫才刚刚八岁。他靠邻居的接济活了下来。她的姑妈听到哥哥家中的变故之后，就准备把侄子接过去跟她一起生活。他们把他带到了奥德萨市，然后从那里去了基辅。他在基辅整整生活了十二年。所以他的俄语说得很好。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.Insarov was just eight years old at the time.He remained in the hands of neighbours.The sister heard of the fate of her brother’s family, and wanted to take the nephew to live with her.They got him to Odessa, and from there to Kiev.At Kiev he lived twelve whole years.That’s how it is he speaks Russian so well.’

第一章: “他会说俄语？”
CHAPTER I: ‘He speaks Russian?’

第一章: “和我们差不多。当他二十岁时（也就是1848年春），他开始想回到自己的祖国。他去了索非亚和图尔诺沃，走遍了保加利亚的各个角落，在那里住了两年，重新学会了家乡的语言。土耳其政府一直都在迫害他，可想而知，他在那两年里碰到了多少危险，我曾在他的脖子上看到了一块很大的伤疤，毫无疑问，曾经是个伤口，但他却不愿意谈这件事情。他也一直以自己的方式有所保留。我曾试着问他以往的事，但却一无所获。他总是笼统地回答我。他非常顽固。他1850年又回到了俄国，回到了莫斯科，打算在这里完成自己的学业，并开始和俄国人交朋友，当他大学毕业之后——”
CHAPTER I: ‘Just as we do.When he was twenty (that was at the beginning of the year 1848) he began to want to return to his country.He stayed in Sophia and Tirnova, and travelled through the length and breadth of Bulgaria, spending two years there, and learning his mother tongue over again.The Turkish Government persecuted him, and he was certainly exposed to great dangers during those two years; I once caught sight of a broad scar on his neck, from a wound, no doubt; but he does not like to talk about it.He is reserved, too, in his own way.I have tried to question him about everything, but I could get nothing out of him.He answers by generalities.He’s awfully obstinate.He returned to Russia again in 1850, to Moscow, with the intention of educating himself thoroughly, getting intimate with Russians, and then when he leaves the university—’

第一章: “之后会怎样？”埃琳娜打断他的话说。
CHAPTER I: ‘What then?’ broke in Elena.

第一章: “那就要看上帝如何安排了。将来的事情是很难预见的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘What God wills.It’s hard to forecast the future.’

第一章: 埃琳娜好一会儿都目不转睛地盯着别尔谢涅夫。
CHAPTER I: For a while Elena did not take her eyes off Bersenyev.

第一章: “你所说的话令我很感兴趣，”她说，“他长得怎样呢，你的这位朋友，你怎么称呼他，是叫他因萨罗夫吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You have greatly interested me by what you have told me,’ she said.‘What is he like, this friend of yours; what did you call him, Insarov?’

第一章: “怎么跟你说好呢？在我眼里，他长得十分英俊。但你很快就能见到他了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘What shall I say?To my mind, he’s good-looking.But you will see him for yourself.’

第一章: “为什么这么说呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘How so?’

第一章: “我会把他带过来见你的。他后天就会来到这个地方，然后就跟我住在同一所房子里。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I will bring him here to see you.He is coming to our little village the day after tomorrow, and is going to live with me in the same lodging.’

第一章: “真的吗？他真的愿意来看我们吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Really?But will he care to come to see us?’

第一章: “我想他会愿意的。他一定会很高兴的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I should think so.He will be delighted.’

第一章: “这么说他不是个骄傲的人了？”
CHAPTER I: ‘He isn’t proud, then?’

第一章: “一点儿也不。我想说的是，看你怎样想了，如果你认为他自负，他确实有点儿骄傲，但并不是你想象中的那种骄傲。比方说，他从不向任何人借钱。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Not the least.That’s to say, he is proud if you like, only not in the sense you mean.He will never, for instance, borrow money from any one.’

第一章: “他很穷吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Is he poor?’

第一章: “是的，他并不富有。他去保加利亚的时候，继承了父亲留下来的一点儿遗产，他的姑妈也会资助他，但这些钱都很少的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, he isn’t rich.When he went to Bulgaria he collected some relics left of his father’s property, and his aunt helps him; but it all comes to very little.’

第一章: “他肯定是个十分坚强的人。”埃琳娜说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘He must have a great deal of character,’ observed Elena.

第一章: “是的，他有着钢铁一般的意志。同时，你也会看到，当他注意力集中的时候，甚至是在拘谨的时候，有一种纯真、直率的特质会从他的身上散发出来。没错，他的坦诚不是我们通常所说的那种做作的坦诚——而是那种人们完全无法掩饰的坦诚……不过，我会带他来见你的，你就耐心地等着吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.He is a man of iron.And at the same time you will see there is something childlike and frank, with all his concentration and even his reserve.It’s true, his frankness is not our poor sort of frankness—the frankness of people who have absolutely nothing to conceal….But there, I will bring him to see you; wait a little.’

第一章: “他不会害羞吗？”埃琳娜又问。
CHAPTER I: ‘And isn’t he shy?’ asked Elena again.

第一章: “不，他不会害羞的。只有那些虚荣的人才会害羞。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, he’s not shy.It’s only vain people who are shy.’

第一章: “为什么这么说，那你虚荣吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why, are you vain?’

第一章: 他变得不知所措起来，无奈地摊了摊手。
CHAPTER I: He was confused and made a vague gesture with his hands.

第一章: “你让我变得好奇起来，”埃琳娜继续说道，“不过告诉我，他没找那个土耳其官员报仇吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You excite my curiosity,’ pursued Elena.‘But tell me, has he not taken vengeance on that Turkish aga?’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫笑了。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev smiled.

第一章: “报仇只是在小说中才会出现的情节，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，况且，现在已经过了十二年了，那个官员恐怕早就死了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Revenge is only to be found in novels, Elena Nikolaevna; and, besides, in twelve years that aga may well be dead.’

第一章: “尽管如此，因萨罗夫先生什么都没跟你讲吗，关于这件事情的？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Mr. Insarov has never said anything, though, to you about it?’

第一章: “是的，从来都没讲过。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, never.’

第一章: “那他为什么还要去索非亚？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why did he go to Sophia?’

第一章: “他的父亲以前在那里住过。”
CHAPTER I: ‘His father used to live there.’

第一章: 埃琳娜陷入沉思。
CHAPTER I: Elena grew thoughtful.

第一章: “寻求国家的解放！”她说，“这些话是如此地伟大，甚至将它们说出来都令人感到害怕。”
CHAPTER I: ‘To liberate one’s country!’ she said.‘It is terrible even to utter those words, they are so grand.’

第一章: 正在此时，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜走了进来，打断了他们的谈话。
CHAPTER I: At that instant Anna Vassilyevna came into the room, and the conversation stopped.

第一章: 那天晚上，当别尔谢涅夫回到房间的时候，一股莫名的情绪让他感到烦躁不堪。他并不后悔把因萨罗夫介绍给埃琳娜，他觉得他对这个保加利亚年轻人的讲述会给埃琳娜留下很深的印象是一件很正常的事情……如果他自己没有试图去加深这个印象的话！然而，一股模糊、无法言明的感觉隐秘地潜藏在他的心中，他感到一阵悲伤，而且这悲伤之中并无任何高尚的成分。然而，这阵悲伤却没有让他停止阅读《霍亨斯陶芬王朝史》这本书，他拿起书，接着昨晚看到的地方读了下去。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev was stirred by strange emotions when he returned home that evening.He did not regret his plan of making Elena acquainted with Insarov, he felt the deep impression made on her by his account of the young Bulgarian very natural… had he not himself tried to deepen that impression!But a vague, unfathomable emotion lurked secretly in his heart; he was sad with a sadness that had nothing noble in it.This sadness did not prevent him, however, from setting to work on the History of the Hohenstaufen, and beginning to read it at the very page at which he had left off the evening before.

第一章: 第十一章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XI

第一章: 两天后，因萨罗夫按照约定时间拿着行李来到了别尔谢涅夫的住处。他没有仆人，但不用任何人帮忙，他自己就把房间收拾好了，家具摆好了，灰尘擦掉了，地板也拖干净了。但他在放写字台的时候遇到了一点点麻烦，那桌子怎么都挤不进墙角的空地，但是，因萨罗夫凭借着那倔强的性格和坚持不懈的努力，最后总算把它成功挤进去了。一切弄妥之后，他首先付给了别尔谢涅夫十卢布，然后拿着一根粗棍子防身，出发查看自己新搬到的这个村子周围的环境。三个小时后，他回到了住所。别尔谢涅夫邀请他一起用餐，他说他不会拒绝今天跟他一起用餐，但他已经告诉女房东，请她以后将给自己的饭送到房间里去。
CHAPTER I: Two days later, Insarov in accordance with his promise arrived at Bersenyev’s with his luggage.He had no servant; but without any assistance he put his room to rights, arranged the furniture, dusted and swept the floor.He had special trouble with the writing table, which would not fit into the recess in the wall assigned for it; but Insarov, with the silent persistence peculiar to him succeeded in getting his own way with it.When he had settled in, he asked Bersenyev to let him pay him ten roubles in advance, and arming himself with a thick stick, set off to inspect the country surrounding his new abode.He returned three hours later; and in response to Bersenyev’s invitation to share his repast, he said that he would not refuse to dine with him that day, but that he had already spoken to the woman of the house, and would get her to send him up his meals for the future.

第一章: “我敢保证！”别尔谢涅夫说，“你不会吃得很好的，那个老女人根本就不会做饭。你为什么不和我一起吃饭呢，我们可以平摊伙食费的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Upon my word!’ said Bersenyev, ‘you will fare very badly; that old body can’t cook a bit.Why don’t you dine with me, we would go halves over the cost.’

第一章: “我那点儿钱根本就不够让我跟你吃的一样。”因萨罗夫静静地笑着回答。
CHAPTER I: ‘My means don’t allow me to dine as you do,’ Insarov replied with a tranquil smile.

第一章: 那笑容中夹杂着一种让对方无法坚持的力量，别尔谢涅夫没有再说什么。吃完饭，别尔谢涅夫打算带因萨罗夫去拜访斯塔霍夫一家，但因萨罗夫说他当天晚上准备给那些保加利亚的朋友们写信，因此，他请别尔谢涅夫把去斯塔霍夫家的拜访推迟到第二天。别尔谢涅夫早已十分清楚因萨罗夫的个性，但只有在现在，当他们住在一起的时候，他才完全意识到，无论怎样因萨罗夫都不会改变自己的决定，就像别尔谢涅夫自己无论如何都要履行自己所许下的诺言一样，对别尔谢涅夫——一个地地道道的俄国人来说——这种比德国人还要严谨的个性似乎很古怪，甚至有点儿荒唐可笑，但他很快就适应了这一点儿，后来他还发现——如果这种个性不能获得尊敬的话——至少能使大家的交流方便一些。
CHAPTER I: There was something in that smile which forbade further insistence; Bersenyev did not add a word.After dinner he proposed to Insarov that he should take him to the Stahovs; but he replied that he had intended to devote the evening to correspondence with his Bulgarians, and so he would ask him to put off the visit to the Stahovs till next day.Bersenyev was already familiar with Insarov’s unbending will; but it was only now when he was under the same roof with him, that he fully realised at last that Insarov would never alter any decision, just in the same way as he would never fail to carry out a promise he had given; to Bersenyev—a Russian to his fingertips—this more than German exactitude seemed at first odd, and even rather ludicrous; but he soon got used to it, and ended by finding it—if not deserving of respect—at least very convenient.

第一章: 搬来的第二天的早晨，因萨罗夫四点钟就起床了，逛遍了整个孔佐沃，在河里游了泳，喝下一杯凉牛奶之后，他就开始工作了。他有很多事情要做，他现在正在研究俄国历史、法律和政治经济学，翻译保加利亚民谣和史册，收集一些关于东方问题方面的资料，编纂一本供保加利亚人使用的俄语语法书籍和一本供俄国人使用的保加利亚语语法书籍。别尔谢涅夫来到了他的房间，跟他讨论了一阵子费尔巴哈。因萨罗夫认认真真地听着，有时还会发表一些见解，但句句切中要害，从他的见解里我们可以看出，他正在试图得出一个结论，就是他究竟是需要研究费尔巴哈的理论，还是不研究他也可以。然后，别尔谢涅夫转移了话题，他谈到因萨罗夫的工作，并问因萨罗夫是否可以在他面前展示一下。因萨罗夫给他读了自己翻译的两三首保加利亚民谣，然后就焦急地等待着他的评论。别尔谢涅夫认为译文很忠于原文，但没有足够的激情。因萨罗夫很仔细地听取了她的批评。从那些歌谣里，别尔谢涅夫又将话题转移到了保加利亚现在的局势，就在这时，他第一次发现，当一提到因萨罗夫的祖国时，因萨罗夫自身就产生了一种很大的变化，不是脸红或是音量加大——不是的！一股坚强有力的力量和勇往直前的动力在他周身散发开来，他嘴角的线条变得更加坚定，更加柔韧，双眼中闪耀着一丝模糊的、顽强不息的光芒。因萨罗夫不喜欢回忆他在祖国的一些经历，但如果是关于保加利亚的一些事情，他总是会跟每一个人滔滔不绝地讲着。他能够详细地介绍那些土耳其人，谈他们的压迫，谈保加利亚人民的灾难和不幸，同时也谈他们的希望，在他说的每句话中，都能够令人感到到一种聚精会神的思考和一种独特的、强烈的激情。
CHAPTER I: The second day after his arrival, Insarov got up at four o’clock in the morning, made a round of almost all Kuntsovo, bathed in the river, drank a glass of cold milk, and then set to work.And he had plenty of work to do; he was studying Russian history and law, and political economy, translating the Bulgarian ballads and chronicles, collecting materials on the Eastern Question, and compiling a Russian grammar for the use of Bulgarians, and a Bulgarian grammar for the use of Russians.Bersenyev went up to him and began to discuss Feuerbach.Insarov listened attentively, made few remarks, but to the point; it was clear from his observations that he was trying to arrive at a conclusion as to whether he need study Feuerbach, or whether he could get on without him.Bersenyev turned the conversation on to his pursuits, and asked him if he could not show him anything.Insarov read him his translation of two or three Bulgarian ballads, and was anxious to hear his opinion of them.Bersenyev thought the translation a faithful one, but not sufficiently spirited.Insarov paid close attention to his criticism.From the ballads Bersenyev passed on to the present position of Bulgaria, and then for the first time he noticed what a change came over Insarov at the mere mention of his country: not that his face flushed nor his voice grew louder—no! but at once a sense of force and intense onward striving was expressed in his whole personality, the lines of his mouth grew harder and less flexible, and a dull persistent fire glowed in the depths of his eyes.Insarov did not care to enlarge on his own travels in his country; but of Bulgaria in general he talked readily with any one.He talked at length of the Turks, of their oppression, of the sorrows and disasters of his countrymen, and of their hopes: concentrated meditation on a single ruling passion could be heard in every word he uttered.

第一章: “啊，没错，”别尔谢涅夫在心里仔细考虑着，“试想一下，那个杀害他父母的土耳其官员可能已经得到了惩罚。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah, well, there’s no mistake about it,’ Bersenyev was reflecting meanwhile, ‘that Turkish aga, I venture to think, has been punished for his father’s and mother’s death.’

第一章: 因萨罗夫还没有讲完要说的话，门突然被打开了，舒宾走了进来。
CHAPTER I: Insarov had not had time to say all he wanted to say, when the door opened and Shubin made his appearance.

第一章: 他带着一种过分悠闲、和善的神态走进了房间里，了解他个性的别尔谢涅夫立刻就看出来，他又被一些事情刺激到了。
CHAPTER I: He came into the room with an almost exaggerated air of ease and good-humour; Bersenyev, who knew him well, could see at once that something had been jarring on him.

第一章: “我随便地介绍下自己，”他带着一种既兴奋又真诚的表情说道，“我叫舒宾，是这个年轻人的朋友（他指着别尔谢涅夫）。”“你应该就是因萨罗夫先生了吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘I will introduce myself without ceremony,’ he began with a bright and open expression on his face.‘My name is Shubin; I’m a friend of this young man here’ (he indicated Bersenyev).‘You are Mr. Insarov, of course, aren’t you?’

第一章: “没错，我是因萨罗夫。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I am Insarov.’

第一章: “那让我们握个手认识一下吧。我不知道别尔谢涅夫是否在你面前提起过我，但他却经常跟我谈起你的事情。你要住在这里吗？太好了！请你不要介意我这样盯着你看。我是个雕刻家，我想不久的将来我一定会请你允许我给你塑头像的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Then give me your hand and let us be friends.I don’t know if Bersenyev has talked to you about me, but he has told me a great deal about you.You are staying here?Capital!Don’t be offended at my staring at you so.I’m a sculptor by trade, and I foresee I shall in a little time be begging your permission to model your head.’

第一章: “我很乐意。”因萨罗夫说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘My head’s at your service,’ said Insarov.

第一章: “那我们今天做什么呢，嗯？”舒宾说着，突然坐进了一张矮小的椅子里，双腿分开，手臂支在上面，“安德烈·彼得罗维奇，能请问你今天有什么计划吗？今天天气很好，到处都弥漫着干草和干草莓的芬芳，就好像人们为了治感冒而喝的草莓果茶。我们应该出去玩一玩。让我们领着孔佐沃的新住户去欣赏欣赏那数不尽的美景吧。”（肯定有什么事让他心烦意乱了，别尔谢涅夫一直想着。）“哎，你怎么不说话啊，霍雷肖？你就发表点儿意见吧。我们是应该到外面走走呢，还是不出去好？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What shall we do to-day, eh?’ began Shubin, sitting down suddenly on a low chair, with his knees apart and his elbows propped on them.‘Andrei Petrovitch, has your honour any kind of plan for to-day?It’s glorious weather; there’s a scent of hay and dried strawberries as if one were drinking strawberry-tea for a cold.We ought to get up some kind of a spree.Let us show the new inhabitant of Kuntsov all its numerous beauties.’ (Something has certainly upset him, Bersenyev kept thinking to himself.)‘Well, why are thou silent, friend Horatio?Open your prophetic lips.Shall we go off on a spree, or not?’

第一章: “我不知道因萨罗夫觉得怎么样，”别尔谢涅夫说道，“我想他会呆在这里工作吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t know how Insarov feels,’ observed Bersenyev.‘He is just getting to work, I fancy.’

第一章: 舒宾从椅子上转过身来。
CHAPTER I: Shubin turned round on his chair.

第一章: “你准备工作吗？”他用一种谦逊的语气问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘You want to work?’ he inquired, in a somewhat condescending voice.

第一章: “没有，”因萨罗夫回答说，“今天我可以出去走走。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No,’ answered Insarov; ‘to-day I could give up to walking.’

第一章: “啊！”舒宾说道，“这简直太好了。快走，我的朋友，安德烈·彼得罗维奇，把帽子扣到你那聪明的脑袋上，看到哪里就走到哪里吧。我们的眼睛里充满朝气——它会引领着我们走向远方。我知道有一家令人讨厌的小餐馆，我们就去那里随便吃一顿糟糕的便饭吧，不过我们会过得很高兴的。走吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah!’ commented Shubin.‘Well, that’s delightful.Run along, my friend, Andrei Petrovitch, put a hat on your learned head, and let us go where our eyes lead us.Our eyes are young—they may lead us far.I know a very repulsive little restaurant, where they will give us a very beastly little dinner; but we shall be very jolly.Come along.’

第一章: 半小时之后，他们三个来到了莫斯科河岸边散步。因萨罗夫扣着一顶十分奇怪的带有帽沿的帽子，舒宾瞧了瞧那顶帽子，不自然地笑了笑。而因萨罗夫则泰然自若地迈着步子观赏着周围美丽的景色，平静地呼吸着，说笑着，他今天是专门出来放松的，而且玩得相当开心。“懂事的小伙子，只有在星期天才会出来走走的。”舒宾低声在别尔谢涅夫的耳边说道。舒宾自己玩得非常开心，他一直跑在前面，摆出各种著名雕像的造型，并在草地上来回翻着跟头，因萨罗夫的安静并没有让他感到别扭，而是促使他不断地做出一些滑稽可笑的动作。“真是个坐立不安的法国佬！”别尔谢涅夫两次都对他说，“没错，我就是法国人，半个法国人，”舒宾答道，“正像一个佣人曾经跟我说的那样，我是介于享乐和严肃之间的一个人。”三个小伙子在河边改变了路线，他们沿着一条又深又窄的小路走了下去，小路两旁满是高高的、金黄色的黑麦，一个浅蓝色的阴影从黑麦的一侧照在他们身上，那闪烁的阳光仿佛从耳朵的上沿滑过，云雀在歌唱，鹌鹑在欢叫，到处都显现出一片青草的新绿，微风轻轻地吹动着草叶，摇曳着花朵。一阵漫长的散步、休息和交谈之后（舒宾甚至都想跟他们碰到的那个已经掉光牙齿的老农民玩蛙跳游戏，那个老人什么都不说，只是在一旁傻笑着，舒宾让他做什么他就做什么），三个年轻人来到了那个“令人讨厌”的小餐馆，侍者们忙乱地几乎要撞到他们，并且的确给他们上了一顿十分糟糕的便饭，拿给他们的是一种巴尔干酒，然而这些并没有破坏他们的兴致，正如舒宾刚才所说的那样，但是，虽然舒宾的欢笑声最大，但内心的快乐却是最少的。他为不太令人理解、但却伟大的韦涅林的健康干杯，为保加利亚国王库玛和差不多跟亚当同一个时代的赫玛或赫罗玛的健康干杯。
CHAPTER I: Half an hour later they were all three walking along the bank of the Moskva.Insarov had a rather queer cap with flaps, over which Shubin fell into not very spontaneous raptures.Insarov walked without haste, and looked about, breathing, talking, and smiling with the same tranquillity; he was giving this day up to pleasure, and enjoying it to the utmost.‘Just as well-behaved boys walk out on Sundays,’ Shubin whispered in Bersenyev’s ear.Shubin himself played the fool a great deal, ran in front, threw himself into the attitudes of famous statues, and turned somersaults on the grass; Insarov’s tranquillity did not exactly irritate him, but it spurred him on to playing antics.‘What a fidget you are, Frenchman!’Bersenyev said twice to him.‘Yes, I am French, half French,’ Shubin answered, ‘and you hold the happy medium between jest and earnest, as a waiter once said to me.’The young men turned away from the river and went along a deep and narrow ravine between two walls of tall golden rye; a bluish shadow was cast on them from the rye on one side; the flashing sunlight seemed to glide over the tops of the ears; the larks were singing, the quails were calling: on all sides was the brilliant green of the grass; a warm breeze stirred and lifted the leaves and shook the heads of the flowers.After prolonged wanderings, with rest and chat between (Shubin had even tried to play leap-frog with a toothless peasant they met, who did nothing but laugh, whatever the gentlemen might do to him), the young men reached the ‘repulsive little’ restaurant: the waiter almost knocked each of them over, and did really provide them with a very bad dinner with a sort of Balkan wine, which did not, however, prevent them from being very jolly, as Shubin had foretold; he himself was the loudest and the least jolly.He drank to the health of the incomprehensible but great Venelin, the health of the Bulgarian king Kuma, Huma, or Hroma, who lived somewhere about the time of Adam.

第一章: “那是在九世纪。”因萨罗夫纠正他说。
CHAPTER I: ‘In the ninth century,’ Insarov corrected him.

第一章: “在九世纪吗？”舒宾叫道，“啊，多么地令人愉快啊！”
CHAPTER I: ‘In the ninth century?’ cried Shubin.‘Oh, how delightful!’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫注意到，在舒宾那些玩笑和胡闹中，他好像在不停地考验着因萨罗夫，他想试探试探他，内心里十分兴奋，但因萨罗夫还是跟往常一样，平静而又直率。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev noticed that among all his pranks, and jests and gaiety, Shubin was constantly, as it were, examining Insarov; he was sounding him and was in inward excitement, but Insarov remained as before, calm and straightforward.

第一章: 最后他们回到了家里，换了衣服，就按照上午的原计划，准备去拜访斯塔霍夫一家。舒宾跑在前面去报信。
CHAPTER I: At last they returned home, changed their dress, and resolved to finish the day as they had begun it, by going that evening to the Stahovs.Shubin ran on before them to announce their arrival.

第一章: 第十二章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XII

第一章: “伟大的因萨罗夫马上就要过来了！”他得意洋洋地喊着，跑进了斯塔霍夫家的客厅里，恰巧那时只有埃琳娜和卓娅呆在那里。
CHAPTER I: ‘The conquering hero Insarov will be here directly!’ he shouted triumphantly, going into the Stahovs’ drawing-room, where there happened at the instant to be only Elena and Zoya.

第一章: “他是谁？”卓娅用德语问道。当碰到突发状况时，她经常会说自己的母语。埃琳娜挺直了身体。舒宾带着一丝戏谑的笑意看了看她。她感到有些生气，但却没说什么。
CHAPTER I: ‘Wer?’ inquired Zoya in German.When she was taken unawares she always used her native language.Elena drew herself up.Shubin looked at her with a playful smile on his lips.She felt annoyed, but said nothing.

第一章: “你听到了吗？”舒宾重复道，“因萨罗夫先生马上就要过来了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You heard,’ he repeated, ‘Mr. Insarov is coming here.’

第一章: “我知道了，”她回答说，“我也听到了你是怎样称呼他的。我真是觉得奇怪。因萨罗夫先生还没踏进这里，你就已经十分随便地在这里嘲弄他了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I heard,’ she replied; ‘and I heard how you spoke of him.I am surprised at you, indeed.Mr. Insarov has not yet set foot in the house, and you already think fit to turn him into ridicule.’

第一章: 舒宾立刻变得十分沮丧。
CHAPTER I: Shubin was crestfallen at once.

第一章: “你说得对，你永远都对，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”他咕哝着说，“但我可以保证，我并没有别的意思。我们今天跟他逛了一整天，我敢说，他是个十分杰出的年轻人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You are right, you are always right, Elena Nikolaevna,’ he muttered; ‘but I meant nothing, on my honour.We have been walking together with him the whole day, and he’s a capital fellow, I assure you.’

第一章: “我并没有问你对他的看法。”埃琳娜站起来说。
CHAPTER I: ‘I didn’t ask your opinion about that,’ commented Elena, getting up.

第一章: “因萨罗夫年轻吗？”卓娅问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Is Mr. Insarov a young man?’ asked Zoya.

第一章: “他已经一百四十四岁了。”舒宾恼火地说。
CHAPTER I: ‘He is a hundred and forty-four,’ replied Shubin with an air of vexation.

第一章: 这时，一个男佣人跑过来说那两位先生已经到了。他们走了进来。别尔谢涅夫介绍了下因萨罗夫。埃琳娜安排他们坐下，随后自己也入座了，而卓娅则跑到了楼上，她要去告诉安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜他们来了。跟所有人第一次见面一样，他们谈了些无关紧要的话题。舒宾安静地呆着角落里打量着，但却没什么好看的。在埃琳娜身上，他发现她对他——舒宾——有一种压抑着的厌烦和失望的迹象，仅此而已。然后他又看了看别尔谢涅夫和因萨罗夫，从一个雕塑家的角度来比较着他们的脸孔。“他们都称不上很帅，”他思索着，“那个保加利亚人的脸孔很有特色，线条分明——现在正散发着动人的光彩，而这个俄国人的脸孔倒适合画油彩画，脸上没有线条，只有表情。但是我敢说，一个人可能会爱上他们其中一个的。她现在还没有恋爱，但她一定会爱上别尔谢涅夫的。”他肯定地对自己说。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜走进客厅后，谈话的风格就变为典型的别墅式的——不是乡村房屋式的，而是彻头彻尾的夏季别墅式的谈话。交谈的主题涉及了方方面面，但每隔两三分钟，谈话就会被一股令人窒息的、无聊的沉默所取代。在其中的一次沉默中，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜瞧了瞧卓娅。舒宾明白了她的暗示，朝她做了个大大的鬼脸，而此时卓娅则坐到钢琴前，边弹边唱地展现着她会唱的所有歌曲。尤瓦·伊万诺维奇在门口站了片刻，但他只是拉了拉手指，然后就跑掉了。随后，下午茶准备好了，大家都到了花园里……外面，天色渐渐地暗了，客人们离开了。
CHAPTER I: The page announced the arrival of the two friends.They came in.Bersenyev introduced Insarov.Elena asked them to sit down, and sat down herself, while Zoya went off upstairs; she had to inform Anna Vassilyevna of their arrival.A conversation was begun of a rather insignificant kind, like all first conversations.Shubin was silently watching from a corner, but there was nothing to watch.In Elena he detected signs of repressed annoyance against him—Shubin—and that was all.He looked at Bersenyev and at Insarov, and compared their faces from a sculptor’s point of view.‘They are neither of them good-looking,’ he thought, ‘the Bulgarian has a characteristic face—there now it’s in a good light; the Great-Russian is better adapted for painting; there are no lines, there’s expression.But, I dare say, one might fall in love with either of them.She is not in love yet, but she will fall in love with Bersenyev,’ he decided to himself.Anna Vassilyevna made her appearance in the drawing-room, and the conversation took the tone peculiar to summer villas—not the country-house tone but the peculiar summer visitor tone.It was a conversation diversified by plenty of subjects; but broken by short rather wearisome pauses every three minutes.In one of these pauses Anna Vassilyevna turned to Zoya.Shubin understood her silent hint, and drew a long face, while Zoya sat down to the piano, and played and sang all her pieces through.Uvar Ivanovitch showed himself for an instant in the doorway, but he beat a retreat, convulsively twitching his fingers.Then tea was served; and then the whole party went out into the garden….It began to grow dark outside, and the guests took leave.

第一章: 因萨罗夫留给埃琳娜的印象并没有她想象中那样深，或者可以这样说，他留给她的印象并不是她期待中的那样。她喜欢他的直率、他的沉着冷静和他的外观，但因萨罗夫的整体性格——他那平静的倔强和家常的纯真——并不符合她脑海中那通过别尔谢涅夫的叙述而形成的他的形象。埃琳娜想着他肯定会遇见更加重大的事情，对此她一点儿都不怀疑。“然而，”她不断思索着，“今天他的话很少，这也怪我，我都没怎么问他，下次再说吧……不过他的眼神还挺真诚的。”她觉得自己并没有迷恋他的倾向，仅仅只是想跟他做个朋友，她现在很迷茫，她不知道自己的意中人到底是不是跟因萨罗夫一样，“伟大的人”。最后几个字让她想起了舒宾，她躺在床上面，脸色绯红，生起气来。
CHAPTER I: Insarov had really made less impression on Elena than she had expected, or, speaking more exactly, he had not made the impression she had expected.She liked his directness and unconstraint, and she liked his face; but the whole character of Insarov—with his calm firmness and everyday simplicity—did not somehow accord with the image formed in her brain by Bersenyev’s account of him.Elena, though she did not herself suspect it, had anticipated something more fateful.‘But,’ she reflected, ‘he spoke very little to-day, and I am myself to blame for it; I did not question him, we must have patience till next time… and his eyes are expressive, honest eyes.’She felt that she had no disposition to humble herself before him, but rather to hold out her hand to him in friendly equality, and she was puzzled; this was not how she had fancied men, like Insarov, ‘heroes.’This last word reminded her of Shubin, and she grew hot and angry, as she lay in her bed.

第一章: “你觉得今天认识的朋友怎么样？”别尔谢涅夫在回家的路上问因萨罗夫。
CHAPTER I: ‘How did you like your new acquaintances?’Bersenyev inquired of Insarov on their way home.

第一章: “我很喜欢他们，”因萨罗夫回答说，“尤其是他们的女儿。她绝对是个好姑娘。她的情绪变化无常，但这种情绪化在她身上则表现得恰到好处。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I liked them very much,’ answered Insarov, ‘especially the daughter.She must be a nice girl.She is excitable, but in her it’s a fine kind of excitability.’

第一章: “你以后应该多接近接近他们。”别尔谢涅夫说。
CHAPTER I: ‘You must go and see them a little oftener,’ observed Bersenyev.

第一章: “是的。”因萨罗夫说道，此后便一言不发了。回到家后，他立刻就把自己关在屋子里，屋里的灯光一直持续到午夜。
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, I must,’ said Insarov; and he said nothing more all the way home.He at once shut himself up in his room, but his candle was burning long after midnight.

第一章: 刚读完一页劳默尔的著作，别尔谢涅夫就发现有一把小石子打在了他的玻璃窗上。他禁不住站了起来，打开玻璃窗子，看到面色惨白的舒宾正站在外面。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev had had time to read a page of Raumer, when a handful of fine gravel came rattling on his window-pane.He could not help starting; opening the window he saw Shubin as white as a sheet.

第一章: “你真是个不可理喻的家伙，你简直就是个夜蛾子——”别尔谢涅夫开口说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What an irrepressible fellow you are, you night moth—’ Bersenyev was beginning.

第一章: “嘘——”舒宾打断他的话，“我就是想偷偷来看看你，就像马克思见阿加莎似的，我有些话必须要和你单独谈。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Sh—’ Shubin cut him short; ‘I have come to you in secret, as Max went to Agatha I absolutely must say a few words to you alone.’

第一章: “那你进来吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Come into the room then.’

第一章: “不了，没那个必要，”舒宾回答说，并将胳膊斜靠在窗台上，“这样会更有趣些，好像我们是在西班牙似的。首先，我要祝贺你，你现在形象极佳。而你高度赞扬的那个杰出的人却失利了。这点我敢肯定。公平起见，你可要听好了——下面就是我对因萨罗夫先生的总结和认识。没有天资，一点儿也没有，没有才情，工作努力，记忆力很强，悟性不高也没有特色，但深刻机敏，单调乏味，固执倔强，当关于保加利亚的话题——在我们之间被提起时——他的口才还是很不错的。怎样！你觉得我的评价客观吗？此外，你永远都不可能称呼他的教名，而且也从来没有人这样称呼过他。当然，我一个搞雕塑的，他很不屑一顾，但我却很自豪。乏味，乏味，不过他却可以把我们大家挤成粉末。他忠于自己的国家——不像我们这些碌碌无为的人们，只会奉承民众说，请把生命之水洒向我们吧！但是显而易见，他的任务更加明确，也就很容易让人理解，他的唯一任务就是解放祖国，驱逐土耳其人。然而这些东西对于女人来说，感谢上帝，她们是不屑一顾的。这样的人没有魅力，没有吸引力，跟我们一点儿都不一样。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, that’s not necessary,’ replied Shubin, and he leaned his elbows on the window-sill, ‘it’s better fun like this, more as if we were in Spain.To begin with, I congratulate you, you’re at a premium now.Your belauded, exceptional man has quite missed fire.That I’ll guarantee.And to prove my impartiality, listen—here’s the sum and substance of Mr. Insarov.No talents, none, no poetry, any amount of capacity for work, an immense memory, an intellect not deep nor varied, but sound and quick, dry as dust, and force, and even the gift of the gab when the talk’s about his—between ourselves let it be said—tedious Bulgaria.What! do you say I am unjust?One remark more: you’ll never come to Christian names with him, and none ever has been on such terms with him.I, of course, as an artist, am hateful to him; and I am proud of it.Dry as dust, dry as dust, but he can crush all of us to powder.He’s devoted to his country—not like our empty patriots who fawn on the people; pour into us, they say, thou living water!But, of course, his problem is easier, more intelligible: he has only to drive the Turks out, a mighty task.But all these qualities, thank God, don’t please women.There’s no fascination, no charm about them, as there is about you and me.’

第一章: “干嘛要把我给扯进来？”别尔谢涅夫抱怨地说，“而且其他方面你也搞错了，他一点儿也不讨厌你，而且，他跟他的同胞都一直以教名相称——这些我都是知道的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why do you bring me in?’ muttered Bersenyev.‘And you are wrong in all the rest; you are not in the least hateful to him, and with his own countrymen he is on Christian name terms—that I know.’

第一章: “这可不是一回事！在他们眼里，他就是个不折不扣的英雄，但是，坦白地说，我对英雄有着不同的见解，一个真正的英雄用不着能言善辩，他要能像公牛似的咆哮，不过，若当它用角顶的时候，墙壁都会为之震动。他也不必明白为什么自己要去顶撞这个东西，而只是仅仅去顶撞它而已。然而，当今我们可能需要不同类型的英雄。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That’s a different matter!For them he’s a hero; but, to make a confession, I have a very different idea of a hero; a hero ought not to be able to talk; a hero should roar like a bull, but when he butts with his horns, the walls shake.He ought not to know himself why he butts at things, but just to butt at them.But, perhaps, in our days heroes of a different stamp are needed.’

第一章: “你为何会对因萨罗夫如此感兴趣？”别尔谢涅夫问道，“你来这里仅仅就只是为了告诉我你对他的看法吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why are you so taken up with Insarov?’ asked Bersenyev.‘Can you have run here only to describe his character to me?’

第一章: “我来你这里，”舒宾开口说道，“是因为呆在家里我心里会很难受。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I came here,’ began Shubin, ‘because I was very miserable at home.’

第一章: “哦，是这样啊！你不是想再哭一场吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Oh, that’s it!Don’t you want to have a cry again?’

第一章: “你就嘲笑我吧！我来这里是因为我已经毫无办法了，我被失望、苦闷和妒忌给包围了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You may laugh!I came here because I’m at my wits’ end, because I am devoured by despair, anger, jealousy.’

第一章: “妒忌？妒忌谁啊？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Jealousy?of whom?’

第一章: “妒忌你，妒忌他，妒忌每一个人。如果我能早一点儿了解她，如果我知道该怎么处理好这件事情，那么我现在也就不用受这些折磨了——但现在说这些还有什么用呢！最终，我只能一直保持着微笑，做着各种滑稽的动作去逗乐别人，正如她说的那样，一直都在装模作样，我真想把自己勒死算了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Of you and him and every one.I’m tortured by the thought that if I had understood her sooner, if I had set to work cleverly—But what’s the use of talking!It must end by my always laughing, playing the fool, turning things into ridicule as she says, and then setting to and strangling myself.’

第一章: “得了吧，你才不会勒死自己呢。”别尔谢涅夫说道。
CHAPTER I: ’Stuff, you won’t strangle yourself,’ observed Bersenyev.

第一章: “在这样一个美丽的夜晚，那是肯定不会的了，不过先让我活到秋天再说吧。在这样的夜晚肯定也会有人去世的，但只会是因为幸福而逝。啊，幸福！每一个从树上投到小路上的阴影都好像在窃窃私语地说：“我知道幸福在哪里……你想知道吗？”我想邀请你出去散散步，然而你现在却沉浸在这优美的散文里。赶快去睡吧，希望你会梦到一些有用的数字！我的心都要碎了。你们，这些尊敬的绅士，看见一个人在哈哈大笑，就会认为他心情很愉悦，你们可以向他证明他若不高兴其实是自寻烦恼，也就是说，他并不苦闷……上帝保佑你！”
CHAPTER I: ‘On such a night, of course not; but only let me live on till the autumn.On such a night people do die too, but only of happiness.Ah, happiness!Every shadow that stretches across the road from every tree seems whispering now: “I know where there is happiness… shall I tell you?”I would ask you to come for a walk, only now you’re under the influence of prose.Go to sleep, and may your dreams be visited by mathematical figures!My heart is breaking.You, worthy gentlemen, see a man laughing, and that means to your notions he’s all right; you can prove to him that he’s humbugging himself, that’s to say, he is not suffering….God bless you!’

第一章: 舒宾突然离开了窗口。“安纽——什卡！”别尔谢涅夫很想在他后面这样叫，但他忍住没有那样做。舒宾现在情绪真的有点儿激动。两分钟后，别尔谢涅夫甚至听到了一阵哭泣声，他忍不住站起身来打开了窗户，外面一片寂静，仅仅听到一个人在远处某个地方——大概是一个经过的农夫吧——在低声哼唱着《莫兹多克大草原》这首歌。
CHAPTER I: Shubin abruptly left the window.‘Annu-shka!’Bersenyev felt an impulse to shout after him, but he restrained himself; Shubin had really been white with emotion.Two minutes later, Bersenyev even caught the sound of sobbing; he got up and opened the window; everything was still, only somewhere in the distance some one—a passing peasant, probably—was humming ‘The Plain of Mozdok.’

第一章: 第十三章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XIII

第一章: 在因萨罗夫搬来孔佐沃的前两个礼拜里，他仅仅拜访了斯塔霍夫家四五次，而别尔谢涅夫则天天过去。埃琳娜见到他总是很高兴，他们之间总是会有一些生动有趣的谈话。但是一回到家里，他就会变得愁眉苦脸。舒宾把自己关了起来，他发疯似的沉浸在他的艺术当中，有时还把自己反锁在屋里，身穿宽松工作服，浑身上下都沾着泥土；或者是在莫斯科的工作室里呆上几天，一些模特和意大利的雕刻家们，还有他的朋友和老师们过去总是去那里看望他。埃琳娜一直都没能像她想象中那样跟因萨罗夫好好聊聊，他不在时，她总是准备好想要问他的问题，但当他真的过来时，她却怎样也不好意思开口。因萨罗夫的安静始终让她觉得紧张，她觉得自己没有权利强迫他回答问题，所以她打算以后再问。尽管如此，她还是觉得随着他的一次次拜访，她越来越关心他了，不管他们之间到底谈了些什么，然而她却一直都没找到机会跟他单独谈谈——若是一个人很想去亲近另一个人，至少也要单独和对方聊一次天吧。她和别尔谢涅夫谈了很多关于因萨罗夫的事情。别尔谢涅夫意识到埃琳娜的思绪已经深深地被因萨罗夫吸引住了，而且感到高兴的是他的朋友并没有像舒宾说的那样“失利”了。他如实跟埃琳娜讲着他所了解的因萨罗夫的各个方面，事无巨细（当我们想极力讨好某人时，我们会经常把自己的朋友带入到谈话当中，而且几乎从不怀疑，这样可以顺便夸耀一下自己）。只要埃琳娜那白净的脸上染上一丝绯红，两眼圆睁，透露着兴奋的光芒时，别尔谢涅夫的心里就会感到一阵刺痛，就像他以前感到过的那样。
CHAPTER I: During the first fortnight of Insarov’s stay in the Kuntsovo neighbourhood, he did not visit the Stahovs more than four or five times; Bersenyev went to see them every day.Elena was always pleased to see him, lively and interesting talk always sprang up between them, and yet he often went home with a gloomy face.Shubin scarcely showed himself; he was working with feverish energy at his art; he either stayed locked up in his room, from which he would emerge in a blouse, smeared all over with clay, or else he spent days in Moscow where he had a studio, to which models and Italian sculptors, his friends and teachers, used to come to see him.Elena did not once succeed in talking with Insarov, as she would have liked to do; in his absence she prepared questions to ask him about many things, but when he came she felt ashamed of her plans.Insarov’s very tranquillity embarrassed her; it seemed to her that she had not the right to force him to speak out; and she resolved to wait; for all that, she felt that at every visit however trivial might be the words that passed between them, he attracted her more and more; but she never happened to be left alone with him—and to grow intimate with any one, one must have at least one conversation alone with him.She talked a great deal about him to Bersenyev.Bersenyev realised that Elena’s imagination had been struck by Insarov, and was glad that his friend had not ‘missed fire’ as Shubin had asserted.He told her cordially all he knew of him down to the minutest details (we often, when we want to please some one, bring our friends into our conversation, hardly ever suspecting that we are praising ourselves in that way), and only at times, when Elena’s pale cheeks flushed a little and her eyes grew bright and wide, he felt a pang in his heart of that evil pain which he had felt before.

第一章: 一天，别尔谢涅夫上午十一点钟就来到了斯塔霍夫家，与往常的拜访时间不同。埃琳娜下楼来在客厅里招待他。
CHAPTER I: One day Bersenyev came to the Stahovs, not at the customary time, but at eleven o’clock in the morning.Elena came down to him in the parlour.

第一章: “你想象一下，”他带着一丝不自然的笑容说道，“我们的因萨罗夫不见了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Fancy,’ he began with a constrained smile, ‘our Insarov has disappeared.’

第一章: “不见了？”埃琳娜说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Disappeared?’ said Elena.

第一章: “是的，他不见了。前天他就出去了，到现在还没有回来。”
CHAPTER I: ‘He has disappeared.The day before yesterday he went off somewhere and nothing has been seen of him since.’

第一章: “他没告诉你他要去哪里吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘He did not tell you where he was going?’

第一章: “没有。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No.’

第一章: 埃琳娜将身子陷进椅子里。
CHAPTER I: Elena sank into a chair.

第一章: “他很有可能去莫斯科了。”她喃喃地说道，而且尽量使自己表现得平静一点儿，但同时她又为自己尽量表现平静的举动感到十分地诧异。
CHAPTER I: ‘He has most likely gone to Moscow,’ she commented, trying to seem indifferent and at the same time wondering that she should try to seem indifferent.

第一章: “我可不认为是这样，”别尔谢涅夫反驳说，“他不是一个人离开的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t think so,’ rejoined Bersenyev.‘He did not go alone.’

第一章: “那他是和谁一起离开的呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘With whom then?’

第一章: “有两个不认识的人——很有可能是他的同乡——在前天吃饭前过来找他。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Two people of some sort—his countrymen they must have been—came to him the day before yesterday, before dinner.’

第一章: “保加利亚人！你怎么会想到他们？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Bulgarians!what makes you think so?’

第一章: “这是因为我听到他们在用一种我不懂的语言交谈，但是我知道那种语言是属于斯拉夫语系的……埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，你一直都说因萨罗夫没有什么神秘感可言，还有什么比这个拜访更让人觉得神秘呢？你好好想想，他们来找他——然后就开始激烈地喊叫、争吵，而且是如此粗鲁愤怒的争吵……他也大叫了起来。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why as far as I could hear, they talked to him in some language I did not know, but Slavonic…You are always saying, Elena Nikolaevna, that there’s so little mystery about Insarov; what could be more mysterious than this visit?Imagine, they came to him—and then there was shouting and quarrelling, and such savage, angry disputing….And he shouted too.’

第一章: “他也叫了吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘He shouted too?’

第一章: “没错。他朝他们喊了起来。他们貌似在相互责备。你要是能见一眼那两个来客就知道了。他们肤色黝黑，脸色凝重，颧骨高突，鼻子很弯，两个人大概都四十岁左右，穿得破破烂烂地，满身灰尘，大汗淋漓，看起来像是工人一样——不是工人，也不是绅士——谁知道他们到底是干什么的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.He shouted at them.They seemed to be accusing each other.And if you could have had a peep at these visitors.They had swarthy, heavy faces with high cheek bones and hook noses, both about forty years old, shabbily dressed, hot and dusty, looking like workmen—not workmen, and not gentlemen—goodness knows what sort of people they were.’

第一章: “他跟他们一起走的吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And he went away with them?’

第一章: “没错。他给他们拿了些吃的东西，然后就一起走掉了。那个女房东告诉我说他们两个人竟然吃了整整一大罐麦片粥。而且还说，他们简直就像饿狼似的，争先恐后地吃着东西。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.He gave them something to eat and went off with them.The woman of the house told me they ate a whole huge pot of porridge between the two of them.They outdid one another, she said, and gobbled it up like wolves.’

第一章: 埃琳娜淡淡地笑了笑。
CHAPTER I: Elena gave a faint smile.

第一章: “你以后就会发现，”她说道，“这些事情都很平常。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You will see,’ she said, ‘all this will be explained into something very prosaic.’

第一章: “但愿是这样吧。不过你不需要用那个字眼。关于因萨罗夫，他可没有一件事情是平常的，虽然舒宾一直坚持说——”
CHAPTER I: ‘I hope it may!But you need not use that word.There is nothing prosaic about Insarov, though Shubin does maintain—’

第一章: “舒宾！”埃琳娜打断他的话说，耸了耸肩膀，“但是你得承认他们两个也在喝麦片粥生活——”
CHAPTER I: ‘Shubin!’Elena broke in, shrugging her shoulders.‘But you must confess these two good men gobbling up porridge—’

第一章: “就连费密斯托克耳在萨拉米斯战争的前夜也吃了晚餐呢。”别尔谢涅夫面带笑意地说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Even Themistocles had his supper on the eve of Salamis,’ observed Bersenyev with a smile.

第一章: “是的，不过第二天就开始打仗了。不管怎么样，如果他回来了，还是请你告诉我一声吧。”埃琳娜继续说道，她准备改变话题，但他们的谈话却被打断了。卓娅来到了客厅，踮着脚尖在屋里来回地走着，这也就在说明安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜还在睡觉。
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes; but then there was a battle next day.Any way you will let me know when he comes back,’ said Elena, and she tried to change the subject, but the conversation made little progress.Zoya made her appearance and began walking about the room on tip-toe, giving them thereby to understand that Anna Vassilyevna was not yet awake.

第一章: 然后别尔谢涅夫就离开了。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev went away.

第一章: 那天晚上，他给埃琳娜送来一个纸条。“他已经回来了，”他给她写道，“脸被晒黑了，浑身脏兮兮地，但他到底去了哪里，做了些什么，我却不清楚，你想不想知道？”
CHAPTER I: In the evening of the same day a note from him was brought to Elena.‘He has come back,’ he wrote to her, ’sunburnt and dusty to his very eyebrows; but where and why he went I don’t know; won’t you find out?’

第一章: “你想不想知道！”埃琳娜低声说着，“貌似他想跟我谈谈！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Won’t you find out!’Elena whispered, ‘as though he talked to me!’

第一章: 第十四章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XIV

第一章: 第二天下午两点时，埃琳娜正站在花园里一个小狗屋前，她在这里养了两只可爱的小狗。（一位园丁在树篱下面发现了这两只被遗弃的小动物，因为他曾听那些洗衣女工们讲过，埃琳娜小姐喜欢各种各样的小动物，所以就将那两只小狗送给了她。他这样做一点儿都没错。埃琳娜给了他二十五卢布。）她朝那个狗屋里看了看，确认这两只小狗都活蹦乱跳的，而且窝里也已垫上了新鲜的稻草，这才转过身来，接着她几乎叫出声来，因萨罗夫正一个人沿着小路朝她走来。
CHAPTER I: The next day, at two o’clock, Elena was standing in the garden before a small kennel, where she was rearing two puppies.(A gardener had found them deserted under a hedge, and brought them to the young mistress, being told by the laundry-maids that she took pity on beasts of all sorts.He was not wrong in his reckoning.Elena had given him a quarter-rouble.)She looked into the kennel, assured herself that the puppies were alive and well, and that they had been provided with fresh straw, turned round, and almost uttered a cry; down an alley straight towards her was walking Insarov, alone.

第一章: “早上好。”他说着，走到她的身边，拿掉帽子。她发现，他在刚过去的这三天里的确被晒黑了很多。“我本来准备和安德烈·彼得罗维奇一起过来的，但他起床洗漱实在太慢，所以我就自己跑来了。你家房子里一个人都没有，他们都在睡觉或者根本就没回家，所以我就来这里了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Good-morning,’ he said, coming up to her and taking off his cap.She noticed that he certainly had got much sunburnt during the last three days.‘I meant to have come here with Andrei Petrovitch, but he was rather slow in starting; so here I am without him.There is no one in your house; they are all asleep or out of doors, so I came on here.’

第一章: “你好像在道歉似的，”埃琳娜回答说，“这就大可不必了。我们大家都很喜欢经常见到你。我们就坐在树阴下的长凳上吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You seem to be apologising,’ replied Elena.‘There’s no need to do that.We are always very glad to see you.Let us sit here on the bench in the shade.’

第一章: 她自己坐了下来。因萨罗夫就在她旁边坐着。
CHAPTER I: She seated herself.Insarov sat down near her.

第一章: “我想你前些日子没在家吧？”她开口说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘You have not been at home these last days, I think?’ she began.

第一章: “是的，”他回答说，“我出去了几天。是安德烈·彼得罗维奇告诉你的吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘No,’ he answered.‘I went away.Did Andrei Petrovitch tell you?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫看着她笑了笑，然后就开始摆弄手里的帽子。当他笑起来时，眼睛里就会闪闪发光，嘴角也向上翘起，这让他看起来很亲切。
CHAPTER I: Insarov looked at her, smiled, and began playing with his cap.When he smiled, his eyes blinked, and his lips puckered up, which gave him a very good-humoured appearance.

第一章: “安德烈·彼得罗维奇可能也告诉过你我是和一些不起眼的人一起离开的吧。”他仍旧笑着说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Andrei Petrovitch most likely told you too that I went away with some—unattractive people,’ he said, still smiling.

第一章: 埃琳娜感到有点儿尴尬，但她很快就觉得她应该跟因萨罗夫说实话。
CHAPTER I: Elena was a little confused, but she felt at once that Insarov must always be told the truth.

第一章: “是的。”她直接说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes,’ she said decisively.

第一章: “那你觉得我这个人怎么样呢？”他突然问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What did you think of me?’ he asked her suddenly.

第一章: 埃琳娜抬眼看着他。
CHAPTER I: Elena raised her eyes to him.

第一章: “我觉得，”她说，“我觉得你一直都很清楚自己在做什么，而且你从来都不会做坏事。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I thought,’ she said, ‘I thought that you always know what you’re doing, and you are incapable of doing anything wrong.’

第一章: “哦——谢谢你这么夸我。你知道吗，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”他说道，亲密地向她靠了靠，“我有一些同胞在这边，当中有些人并没有读过多少书，但我们却都衷心坚持着同一个梦想。令人遗憾的是，大家相处总会产生矛盾，而他们都认识我，信任我，所以就让我过去解决纠纷。我就去了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well—thanks for that.You see, Elena Nikolaevna,’ he began, coming closer to her in a confidential way, ‘there is a little family of our people here; among us there are men of little culture; but all are warmly devoted to the common cause.Unluckily, one can never get on without dissensions, and they all know me, and trust me; so they sent for me to settle a dispute.I went.’

第一章: “那地方离这里很远吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Was it far from here?’

第一章: “我走了大概有五十多英里路才到达特罗伊茨克区。我们有一些同胞住在那里的修道院附近。不管怎样，我没有白跑这一趟，我顺利地解决了纠纷。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I went about fifty miles, to the Troitsky district.There, near the monastery, there are some of our people.At any rate, my trouble was not thrown away; I settled the matter.’

第一章: “你遇到困难了吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And had you much difficulty?’

第一章: “没错。有一个人实在太固执了。他不愿意退钱。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.One was obstinate through everything.He did not want to give back the money.’

第一章: “什么？你们是因为钱吵起来的吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What?Was the dispute over money?’

第一章: “是的，只是为一小笔钱而已。那你以为是什么呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes; and a small sum of money too.What did you suppose?’

第一章: “你就因为这点儿小事跑了五十多英里路啊？还浪费了三天时间？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And you travelled over fifty miles for such trifling matters?Wasted three days?’

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，当关系到我的同胞们时，那些事情对我来说就不是小事情了。在这种状况下，如果我拒绝就太不厚道了。我看到连遗弃的小狗你都会去帮助它们，你真的是很善良。至于我花掉的时间，那没什么的，我以后会把它们补回来。我们的时间并不是属于我们自己的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘They are not trifling matters, Elena Nikolaevna, when my countrymen are involved.It would be wicked to refuse in such cases.I see here that you don’t refuse help even to puppies, and I think well of you for it.And as for the time I have lost, that’s no great harm; I will make it up later.Our time does not belong to us.’

第一章: “那是属于谁的？”
CHAPTER I: ‘To whom does it belong then?’

第一章: “啊，当然是属于那些需要我们帮助的人们。我一时冲动把事情都告诉了你，因为我很在乎你的看法。我能想象到安德烈·彼得罗维奇说的话让你对此有多好奇！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why, to all who need us.I have told you all this on the spur of the moment, because I value your good opinion.I can fancy how Andrei Petrovitch must have made you wonder!’

第一章: “在乎我的看法，”埃琳娜低声说，“为什么呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You value my good opinion,’ said Elena, in an undertone, ‘why?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫又笑了笑。
CHAPTER I: Insarov smiled again.

第一章: “因为你是一位好女孩，没有一点儿贵族架子……就是这些。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Because you are a good young lady, not an aristocrat… that’s all.’

第一章: 接着两人陷入了短暂的沉默。
CHAPTER I: A short silence followed.

第一章: “德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇，”埃琳娜说，“你知道这是你第一次对我如此坦诚吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Dmitri Nikanorovitch,’ said Elena, ’do you know that this is the first time you have been so unreserved with me?’

第一章: “此话怎讲？我觉得在你面前，我一直都是怎么想就怎么说。”
CHAPTER I: ‘How’s that?I think I have always said everything I thought to you.’

第一章: “不，这可是第一次，我很高兴，我准备以后也要坦诚地面对你。我可以吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, this is the first time, and I am very glad, and I too want to be open with you. May I?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫笑着说：”当然可以。“
CHAPTER I: Insarov began to laugh and said: ‘You may.’

第一章: “我警告你哦，我的好奇心可是很强的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I warn you I am very inquisitive.’

第一章: “没事，你就问吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Never mind, tell me.’

第一章: “安德烈·彼得罗维奇给我讲了好多关于你的事情，还包括你小时候的事情。我知道有一件事，一件很可怕的事情……我知道后来你又回到了自己的祖国……如果你觉得我的问题冒犯了你，看在上帝的份上，你就不要回答我了，不过有一个问题一直困扰着我……告诉我，你有没有见到那个人？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Andrei Petrovitch has told me a great deal of your life, of your youth.I know of one event, one awful event….I know you travelled afterwards in your own country….Don’t answer me for goodness sake, if you think my question indiscreet, but I am fretted by one idea….Tell me, did you meet that man?’

第一章: 埃琳娜差点儿喘不上气来。她为自己的鲁莽感到羞愧和惊慌。因萨罗夫目不转睛地看着她，微微皱了皱眉，并用手指摩挲着下巴。
CHAPTER I: Elena caught her breath.She felt both shame and dismay at her own audacity.Insarov looked at her intently, slightly knitting his brows, and stroking his chin with his fingers.

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”他最后开口说道，声音比往日低沉了许多，这让埃琳娜感到十分恐怖，“我知道你说的那人是指谁。没有，我没有见到他，感谢上帝没有让我碰到他！我也没有试图去找他。我没去找他，不是因为我觉得自己没有权利杀掉他——我可以毫不犹豫地杀掉他——而是因为现在还不到时机，现在不是讲个人恩怨的时候，我们要顾全大局，从整个民族的利益出发——或者这样讲也不是很准确——我们现在要考虑的是民族的解放。一个是会妨碍另一个的。时机到了的时候，那个也会实现的……那个也会实现的。”他重复着，并且晃着脑袋。
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena Nikolaevna,’ he began at last, and his voice was much lower than usual, which almost frightened Elena, ‘I understand what man you are referring to.No, I did not meet him, and thank God I did not!I did not try to find him.I did not try to find him: not because I did not think I had a right to kill him—I would kill him with a very easy conscience—but because now is not the time for private revenge, when we are concerned with the general national vengeance—or no, that is not the right word—when we are concerned with the liberation of a people.The one would be a hindrance to the other.In its own time that, too, will come… that too will come,’ he repeated, and he shook his head.

第一章: 埃琳娜从侧面看了看他。
CHAPTER I: Elena looked at him from the side.

第一章: “你很爱自己的祖国吗？”她谨慎地问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘You love your country very dearly?’ she articulated timidly.

第一章: “这还需要时间来证明，”他回答说，“当我们中间有人为祖国而牺牲时，那么这人才真正算得上热爱自己的祖国。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That remains to be shown,’ he answered.‘When one of us dies for her, then one can say he loved his country.’

第一章: “所以说，如果你以后回不了保加利亚了，”埃琳娜继续说道，“那你在俄国应该会很不开心吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘So that, if you were cut off all chance of returning to Bulgaria,’ continued Elena, ‘would you be very unhappy in Russia?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫低下了头。
CHAPTER I: Insarov looked down.

第一章: “我想我会崩溃的。”他说。
CHAPTER I: ‘I think I could not bear that,’ he said.

第一章: “告诉我，”埃琳娜又开口说道，“保加利亚语很难学吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Tell me,’ Elena began again, ‘is it difficult to learn Bulgarian?’

第一章: “一点儿都不。如果一个俄国人不会讲保加利亚语，那么这就是一件令他丢脸的事。一个俄国人应该了解所有斯拉夫语系的方言。我给你拿点儿保加利亚的书籍吧？你就会发现保加利亚语其实是很简单的。我们有许多好听的民谣！差不多和塞尔维亚歌谣一样。稍等片刻，我翻译一首给你听听。这首是关于……但是，你至少了解过一些我们的历史吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Not at all.It’s a disgrace to a Russian not to know Bulgarian.A Russian ought to know all the Slavonic dialects.Would you like me to bring you some Bulgarian books?You will see how easy it is.What ballads we have! equal to the Servian.But stop a minute, I will translate to you one of them.It is about…But you know a little of our history at least, don’t you?’

第一章: “不，我什么都不知道。”埃琳娜回答说。
CHAPTER I: ‘No, I know nothing of it,’ answered Elena.

第一章: “你等我一下，我给你拿本书过来。你至少可以从那本书里了解一些比较重大的历史事件。现在请听这首民谣……不过我最好还是给你一篇译文吧。我敢肯定你一定会喜欢上我们的，因为你同情所有那些被压迫的人们。如果你知道我们的土地是何等富饶那该多好啊！但是，它现在已经饱受摧残，饱经掠夺，”他一边说着，一边不由自主地挥动手臂，脸色沉了下来，“他们掠夺了我们所有的东西，所有的：我们的教堂，我们的法律，我们的土地，禽兽不如的土耳其人像驱逐牲口似的对待我们，残害我们——”
CHAPTER I: ‘Wait a little and I will bring you a book.You will learn the principal facts at least from it.Listen to the ballad then….But I had better bring you a written translation, though.I am sure you will love us, you love all the oppressed.If you knew what a land of plenty ours is!And, meanwhile, it has been downtrodden, it has been ravaged,’ he went on, with an involuntary movement of his arm, and his face darkened; ‘we have been robbed of everything; everything, our churches, our laws, our lands; the unclean Turks drive us like cattle, butcher us—’

第一章: “德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇！”埃琳娜叫了起来。
CHAPTER I: ‘Dmitri Nikanorovitch!’ cried Elena.

第一章: 他停了下来。
CHAPTER I: He stopped.

第一章: “对不起。一谈起这些，我就冷静不下来。但是你刚才问我是否热爱自己的祖国。除此之外，一个人还有什么可热爱的呢？还有什么能让我们坚定目标，还有什么能让我们排除万难，还有什么能让我们——除了上帝——坚持自己的信念？而且还是在祖国需要我们的时候。……你想想，在保加利亚，即使是最贫穷的农民，最可怜的乞丐，都和我一样拥有一个共同的希望。我们都有一个共同的目标。你以后会明白这将给我们带来多大的力量，多大的信心！”
CHAPTER I: ‘I beg your pardon.I can’t speak of this coolly.But you asked me just now whether I love my country.What else can one love on earth?What is the one thing unchanging, what is above all doubts, what is it—next to God—one must believe in?And when that country needs.… Think; the poorest peasant, the poorest beggar in Bulgaria, and I have the same desire.All of us have one aim.You can understand what strength, what confidence that gives!’

第一章: 因萨罗夫沉默了一小会儿，又开始谈起了保加利亚。埃琳娜专心致志、心情沉重地听着他的诉说。当他停下来之后，她再次问了他：
CHAPTER I: Insarov was silent for an instant; then he began again to talk of Bulgaria.Elena listened to him with absorbed, profound, and mournful attention.When he had finished, she asked him once more:

第一章: “无论如何你都不会留在俄国吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Then you would not stay in Russia for anything?’

第一章: 当他离开的时候，她盯着他的背影看了很长时间。就在那天，他在她眼里彻底地脱胎换骨了。当她跟着他穿过花园回去的时候，他已经不是她两个小时之前见到的那个因萨罗夫了。
CHAPTER I: And when he went away, for a long time she gazed after him.On that day he had become a different man for her.When she walked back with him through the garden, he was no longer the man she had met two hours before.

第一章: 那天过后，他过来的次数就越来越多了，而别尔谢涅夫则只是偶尔过来一次。一种莫名的感情开始在他们之间滋长，他们两个都意识到了这种感情，但他们却没有声张，他们害怕去面对这种感情。就这样，一个月过去了。
CHAPTER I: From that day he began to come more and more often, and Bersenyev less and less often.A strange feeling began to grow up between the two friends, of which they were both conscious, but to which they could not give a name, and which they feared to analyse.In this way a month passed.

第一章: 第十五章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XV

第一章: 就像读者您早已经知道的那样，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜喜欢呆在家里，不过有时她会冒出一些让人很稀奇古怪的想法：一些不同寻常的快乐之事，越是惹麻烦，需要做的准备和安排越多，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜也就越激动，她获得的快乐也越多。如果她在冬天产生这种想法，她就会提前预定好两三个排在一起的包厢，然后邀请所有熟人去看戏或者是去参加假面舞会，假如是在夏天，她就会驾车到城外去游玩，走得越远越好。到了第二天，她就会抱怨说自己头疼，呻吟着，一直躺在床上，但两个月过后，她脑海里就会又蹦出一些“稀奇古怪”的想法来。现在的情况就是这样。她无意中听人说察里津诺的景色很迷人，然后就立马决定后天要去察里津诺游玩。全家人都陷入了忙碌中；一个信使飞奔去莫斯科接尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇；和他同去的还有去买酒、馅饼和其他粮食的管家；舒宾被派去租一辆敞篷马车——单单一辆四轮马车是不够用的，而且还要预备几匹备用的马；一封信被两次送到了别尔谢涅夫和因萨罗夫的别墅，那是卓娅写的请帖，第一次是用俄语写的，第二次是用法语写的；安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜自己则忙着准备她和女儿旅行用的服饰。在此期间，这件快乐之事差点儿成了一场悲剧。尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇从莫斯科回来之后就一直精神不振，脾气乖戾，行为异常。他还在和奥古斯丁娜·克里斯蒂安诺夫娜生气，当他得知出游的计划时，他断然拒绝前往，还说从孔佐沃到莫斯科，然后再从莫斯科到察里津诺，最后再原路返回简直就是一出闹剧。“事实上，”他继续说道，“只要有人能让我信服，在地球上，有一个地方就是比另一个地方让人快乐，那样的话我就去。”当然，谁也没法跟他保证这点，没有了丈夫的陪同，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜就准备要放弃这次出游的计划，但她突然想到了尤瓦·伊万诺维奇，所以就悲伤地让人把他请过来，口中说着：“即使快被淹死，也要抓住最后一根稻草。”他们把他喊了起来，他来到楼下安静地听完安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜的建议，动了动手指，竟然同意了。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜亲了亲他的脸颊，直呼他为亲爱的，尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇则轻蔑地笑着说：“真是愚蠢！”（他喜欢偶尔说几句时髦的法语。）第二天一大早，坐满乘客的大马车和那个敞篷的四轮马车就从斯塔霍夫家的院子里浩浩荡荡地出发了。小姐们、别尔谢涅夫，还有一个女仆坐在那个大马车上，因萨罗夫坐在前面赶车的位置上，而尤瓦·伊万诺维奇和舒宾则坐在了敞篷马车上。尤瓦·伊万诺维奇示意让舒宾坐到自己身边，他知道舒宾一路上会取笑他，然而，这个“老古董”和这个年轻艺术家之间存在一种奇怪的吸引，一种无所顾忌的直率。但是，这次，舒宾却没有取笑过他那胖胖的朋友，他看上去不知在想什么，沉默不语，表现得很绅士。
CHAPTER I: Anna Vassilyevna, as the reader knows already, liked staying at home; but at times she manifested, quite unexpectedly, an irresistible longing for something out of the common, some extraordinary partie du plaisir, and the more troublesome the partie du plaisir was, the more preparations and arrangements it required, and the greater Anna Vassilyevna’s own agitation over it, the more pleasure it gave her.If this mood came upon her in winter, she would order two or three boxes to be taken side by side, and, inviting all her acquaintances, would set off to the theatre or even to a masquerade; in summer she would drive for a trip out of town to some spot as far off as possible.The next day she would complain of a headache, groan and keep her bed; but within two months the same craving for something ‘out of the common’ would break out in her again.That was just what happened now.Some one chanced to refer to the beautiful scenery of Tsaritsino before her, and Anna Vassilyevna suddenly announced an intention of driving to Tsaritsino the day after tomorrow.The household was thrown into a state of bustle; a messenger galloped off to Moscow for Nikolai Artemyevitch; with him galloped the butler to buy wines, pies, and all sorts of provisions; Shubin was commissioned to hire an open carriage—the coach alone was not enough—and to order relays of horses to be ready; a page was twice despatched to Bersenyev and Insarov with two different notes of invitation, written by Zoya, the first in Russian, the second in French; Anna Vassilyevna herself was busy over the dresses of the young ladies for the expedition.Meanwhile the partie du plaisir was very near coming to grief.Nikolai Artemyevitch arrived from Moscow in a sour, ill-natured, frondeurish frame of mind.He was still sulky with Augustina Christianovna; and when he heard what the plan was, he flatly declared that he would not go; that to go trotting from Kuntsovo to Moscow and from Moscow to Tsaritsino, and then from Tsaritsino again to Moscow, from Moscow again to Kuntsovo, was a piece of folly; and, ‘in fact,’ he added, ‘let them first prove to my satisfaction, that one can be merrier on one spot of the globe than another spot, and I will go.’This, of course, no one could prove to his satisfaction, and Anna Vassilyevna was ready to throw up the partie du plaisir for lack of a solid escort; but she recollected Uvar Ivanovitch, and in her distress she sent to his room for him, saying: ‘a drowning man catches at straws.’They waked him up; he came down, listened in silence to Anna Vassilyevna’s proposition, and, to the general astonishment, with a flourish of his fingers, he consented to go.Anna Vassilyevna kissed him on the cheek, and called him a darling; Nikolai Artemyevitch smiled contemptuously and said: quelle bourde!(he liked on occasions to make use of a ‘smart’ French word); and the following morning the coach and the open carriage, well-packed, rolled out of the Stahovs’ court-yard.In the coach were the ladies, a maid, and Bersenyev; Insarov was seated on the box; and in the open carriage were Uvar Ivanovitch and Shubin.Uvar Ivanovitch had himself beckoned Shubin to him; he knew that he would tease him the whole way, but there existed a queer sort of attachment, marked by abusive candour, between the ‘primeval force’ and the young artist.On this occasion, however, Shubin left his fat friend in peace; he was absent-minded, silent, and gentle.

第一章: 当马车赶到察里津诺古堡的废墟前时，太阳已经高高地挂在万里无云的蓝天中了，即使是在中午，那个古堡看起来还是一样地阴森可怕。所有人都下车走到草地上，接着就立刻朝公园方向走去。埃琳娜、卓娅和因萨罗夫走在了前面，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜则挽着尤瓦·伊万诺维奇的手臂，一脸幸福地跟在他们的后面。尤瓦·伊万诺维奇喘着粗气步履蹒跚地走着，脑袋被一顶新草帽磨痛，双脚在靴子里感到一阵阵的刺痛，但他却十分开心。舒宾和别尔谢涅夫走在了后面。“小伙子，我们就像退伍军人一样，很快就会成为预备军了，”舒宾低声对别尔谢涅夫说道，“那里现在是保加利亚的了！”他继续说着，并朝埃琳娜方向挑了挑眉。
CHAPTER I: The sun stood high in a cloudless blue sky when the carriage drove up to the ruins of Tsaritsino Castle, which looked gloomy and menacing, even at mid-day.The whole party stepped out on to the grass, and at once made a move towards the garden.In front went Elena and Zoya with Insarov; Anna Vassilyevna, with an expression of perfect happiness on her face, walked behind them, leaning on the arm of Uvar Ivanovitch.He waddled along panting, his new straw hat cut his forehead, and his feet twinged in his boots, but he was content; Shubin and Bersenyev brought up the rear.‘We will form the reserve, my dear boy, like veterans,’ whispered Shubin to Bersenyev.‘Bulgaria’s in it now!’ he added, indicating Elena with his eyebrows.

第一章: 天气真是太好了。周围鲜花怒放，蜂飞蝶舞，百鸟争鸣，远处的湖水波光粼粼，所有的人的心情都十分轻松欢快。“哦，实在是太美了，哦，太美了！”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜不停地惊呼着，尤瓦·伊万诺维奇也不住地点头赞同她的观点，甚至有一次还开口说道：“确实是这样！确实是这样！”埃琳娜时不时地跟因萨罗夫聊上几句，卓娅则用两根纤细的手指轻轻地扶着头上那顶大草帽的帽檐，从粉红色的巴雷格纱裙下的浅灰色圆头鞋子里偷偷伸出长着圆圆脚趾的小脚，她不断地张望着，一会儿朝旁边看看，一会儿朝后面看看。“唉！”舒宾突然低声喊道，“卓娅·尼基季什娜好像在四处寻人呢。我要去她那边。现在埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜看不起我，但对于你，安德烈·彼得罗维奇，她还是很敬重你的，不过说到底还是一样的。我要过去了，我不想再让自己这么烦。我建议你啊，我亲爱的朋友，应该多去研究研究植物，就你目前的状况而言，这是最好的选择，而且从科学的观点来说，这对你的学习也是很有帮助的。再会！”舒宾跑到卓娅那里，伸出手臂说：“小姐，请伸出手来。”然后，他就牵着她的手朝前方走去。埃琳娜停了下来，把别尔谢涅夫喊到了自己的身旁，挽起了他的手臂，但仍然在和因萨罗夫聊天。她问他铃兰花、苜蓿、橡树和椴树等等用保加利亚语怎么说……“彻底被保加利亚占领了！”可怜的安德烈·彼得罗维奇暗自想着。
CHAPTER I: The weather was glorious.Everything around was flowering, humming, singing; in the distance shone the waters of the lakes; a light-hearted holiday mood took possession of all.‘Oh, how beautiful; oh, how beautiful!’Anna Vassilyevna repeated incessantly; Uvar Ivanovitch kept nodding his head approvingly in response to her enthusiastic exclamations, and once even articulated: ‘To be sure!to be sure!’From time to time Elena exchanged a few words with Insarov; Zoya held the brim of her large hat with two fingers while her little feet, shod in light grey shoes with rounded toes, peeped coquettishly out from under her pink barege dress; she kept looking to each side and then behind her.‘Hey!’ cried Shubin suddenly in a low voice, ‘Zoya Nikitishna is on the lookout, it seems.I will go to her.Elena Nikolaevna despises me now, while you, Andrei Petrovitch, she esteems, which comes to the same thing.I am going; I’m tired of being glum.I should advise you, my dear fellow, to do some botanising; that’s the best thing you could hit on in your position; it might be useful, too, from a scientific point of view.Farewell!’Shubin ran up to Zoya, offered her his arm, and saying: ‘Ihre Hand, Madame’ caught hold of her hand, and pushed on ahead with her.Elena stopped, called to Bersenyev, and also took his arm, but continued talking to Insarov.She asked him the words for lily-of-the-valley, clover, oak, lime, and so on in his language…‘Bulgaria’s in it!’ thought poor Andrei Petrovitch.

第一章: 突然前面传来了一阵尖叫声，大家都朝那边看去。舒宾的香烟盒子被卓娅扔到灌木丛中了。“等一下，我一定会找你算账的！”他一边喊着，一边钻进了灌木丛里，找到香烟盒后，他正要回到了卓娅那里，但还没走到她的身边，那盒子又被扔到了路的对面。这个动作又被重复了四遍，他就这样一直笑嘻嘻地威胁她，但卓娅只是俏皮地笑了笑，然后就像小猫似的蜷缩在一起。后来他抓住了她的手指，用力地捏了一下，然后她就立刻尖叫了起来，过后还假装生气，不停地吹着那被捏的手指，而舒宾则在她耳边低声说着什么。
CHAPTER I: Suddenly a shriek was heard in front; every one looked up.Shubin’s cigar-case fell into a bush, flung by Zoya’s hand.‘Wait a minute, I’ll pay you out!’ he shouted, as he crept into the bushes; he found his cigar-case, and was returning to Zoya; but he had hardly reached her side when again his cigar-case was sent flying across the road.Five times this trick was repeated, he kept laughing and threatening her, but Zoya only smiled slyly and drew herself together, like a little cat.At last he snatched her fingers, and squeezed them so tightly that she shrieked, and for a long time afterwards breathed on her hand, pretending to be angry, while he murmured something in her ears.

第一章: “这些年轻人真是淘气。”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜心情愉悦地对尤瓦·伊万诺维奇说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Mischievous things, young people,’ Anna Vassilyevna observed gaily to Uvar Ivanovitch.

第一章: 他听后，只是动了动手指。
CHAPTER I: He flourished his fingers in reply.

第一章: “卓娅·尼基季什娜真是个小女孩！”别尔谢涅夫对埃琳娜说。
CHAPTER I: ‘What a girl Zoya Nikitishna is!’ said Bersenyev to Elena.

第一章: “那舒宾呢？他又如何呢？”她回答说。
CHAPTER I: ‘And Shubin?What of him?’ she answered.

第一章: 此时，大家都已经来到了凉亭里，这里是欣赏景物的最佳地点，所以大家都纷纷停下脚步观赏察里津诺湖那迷人的风光。这些湖泊连绵数十英里，周围被一大片浓密的树林包围。一大片青翠色的草地覆盖在最那片大湖泊前面的斜坡上，在水中显现出一种绿翡翠般的色彩。湖水一片沉寂，甚至连湖边也没有一丝浪花。远远看去，就好像是一块坚硬无比的大玻璃笨重地、闪闪发亮地横躺在一个硕大的洗礼盘中，天空也仿佛沉到了它的底部，郁郁葱葱的树林也在静静地注视着自己在水里的倒影。所有人都沉浸在这安静迷人的景色当中，就连舒宾也变得一言不发，卓娅也完全被吸引住了。后来，所有人都准备去水面上游玩。舒宾、因萨罗夫和别尔谢涅夫纷纷从草地上跑了下来。他们找到了一条刷过漆的大船，然后又雇了两个船夫，这才把那群小姐夫人喊了过来。女士们纷纷坐进了船里，尤瓦·伊万诺维奇则小心翼翼地跟在她们后面钻了进去。当他在船上坐好后，所有人都哈哈大笑起来。“小心点儿，我的大老爷，千万不要把船给弄翻了。”其中一个船夫说道，他穿着一件鲜艳的印花衬衫，鼻子短翘。“得了吧，你话真多！”尤瓦·伊万诺维奇回答说。船终于出发了。几个年轻人都拿起了木浆，但只有因萨罗夫才懂得如何划船。舒宾建议大家合唱一首俄罗斯民谣，并起头唱道：“奔腾的伏尔加河……”然后，别尔谢涅夫、卓娅甚至是安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜也一起唱了起来——因萨罗夫不知道该怎么唱——但是其他人也唱得不怎么整齐，到第三部分的时候，大家就完全唱错了。只有别尔谢涅夫还在用低音继续唱着，“波涛中什么东西也看不到。”然而他也很快就坚持不下去了。那两个船夫相互看了看对方，咧着嘴悄悄笑了起来。
CHAPTER I: Meanwhile the whole party went into the arbour, well known as Pleasant View arbour, and stopped to admire the view of the Tsaritsino lakes.They stretched one behind the other for several miles, overshadowed by thick woods.The bright green grass, which covered the hill sloping down to the largest lake, gave the water itself an extraordinarily vivid emerald colour.Even at the water’s edge not a ripple stirred the smooth surface.One might fancy it a solid mass of glass lying heavy and shining in a huge font; the sky seemed to drop into its depths, while the leafy trees gazed motionless into its transparent bosom.All were absorbed in long and silent admiration of the view; even Shubin was still; even Zoya was impressed.At last, all with one mind, began to wish to go upon the water.Shubin, Insarov, and Bersenyev raced each other over the grass.They succeeded in finding a large painted boat and two boatmen, and beckoned to the ladies.The ladies stepped into the boat; Uvar Ivanovitch cautiously lowered himself into it after them.Great was the mirth while he got in and took his seat.‘Look out, master, don’t drown us,’ observed one of the boatmen, a snubnosed young fellow in a gay print shirt.‘Get along, you swell!’ said Uvar Ivanovitch.The boat pushed off.The young men took up the oars, but Insarov was the only one of them who could row.Shubin suggested that they should sing some Russian song in chorus, and struck up: ‘Down the river Volga’… Bersenyev, Zoya, and even Anna Vassilyevna, joined in—Insarov could not sing—but they did not keep together; at the third verse the singers were all wrong.Only Bersenyev tried to go on in the bass, ‘Nothing on the waves is seen,’ but he, too, was soon in difficulties.The boatmen looked at one another and grinned in silence.

第一章: “嗯？”舒宾转向他们问道，“你们觉得我们不会唱歌吗？”那个穿着印花衬衣的年轻人只是摇了摇头。“等着看吧，翘鼻子，”舒宾反驳说，“我们给你来一曲。卓娅·尼基季什娜，请给我们唱首尼德迈耶尔的名曲《湖泊》吧。不要再划啦！”几只湿漉漉的木浆停了下来，像翅膀一样指向了天空，桨上的水滴有节奏地往下落着，船又向前划了一段，然后就停在了那里，像一只天鹅似的在水里轻轻摇摆着。刚开始，卓娅还假装推辞……“唱啊。”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜温柔地说……然后，卓娅就拿掉了草帽，放声唱了起来：“哦，湖泊，一年才刚刚过去！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Eh?’ said Shubin, turning to them, ‘the gentlefolks can’t sing, you say?’The boy in the print shirt only shook his head.‘Wait a little snubnose,’ retorted Shubin, ‘we will show you.Zoya Nikitishna, sing us Le lac of Niedermeyer.Stop rowing!’The wet oars stood still, lifted in the air like wings, and their splash died away with a tuneful drip; the boat drifted on a little, then stood still, rocking lightly on the water like a swan.Zoya affected to refuse at first….‘Allons’ said Anna Vassilyevna genially….Zoya took off her hat and began to sing: ‘O lac, l’annee a peine a fini sa carriere!’
