第一章: 她那轻微但纯洁的声音漂浮在湖面上，每一个词语都回荡在远处的树林中，仿佛在那里也有一个人在歌唱，声音听起来既神秘又超凡脱俗。当卓娅唱完的时候，一阵喝彩声从岸边的一个凉亭里传了出来，那里有几个来察里津诺游玩的红脸德国佬。他们中有好几个人都没有穿大衣，也没有系领带，甚至连背心也没有穿，他们一直在狂喊着“再来一曲”，无奈之下，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜只好让船夫尽快将船靠到湖的另一边。然而，在船还没有靠岸的时候，尤瓦·伊万诺维奇再次把大家给震住了，他注意到在树林的某一个地方，有一个回声特别地清晰，然后他就突然学着鹌鹑叫了起来。起先大家都吓了一跳，但是很快便开心地听了起来，尤其是在尤瓦·伊万诺维奇模仿的叫声栩栩如生的时候。受到鼓舞之后，他又试图模仿猫叫，但这次却没有成功，接着又模仿了一次鹌鹑的叫声后，他瞅了瞅大家，然后停了下来。舒宾挤过去要亲他一下，但却被他推开了。就在这个时候，船靠到了岸边，所有人都走下船来，朝岸上走去。
CHAPTER I: Her small, but pure voice, seemed to dart over the surface of the lake; every word echoed far off in the woods; it sounded as though some one were singing there, too, in a distinct, but mysterious and unearthly voice.When Zoya finished, a loud bravo was heard from an arbour near the bank, from which emerged several red-faced Germans who were picnicking at Tsaritsino.Several of them had their coats off, their ties, and even their waistcoats; and they shouted ‘bis!’ with such unmannerly insistence that Anna Vassilyevna told the boatmen to row as quickly as possible to the other end of the lake.But before the boat reached the bank, Uvar Ivanovitch once more succeeded in surprising his friends; having noticed that in one part of the wood the echo repeated every sound with peculiar distinctness, he suddenly began to call like a quail.At first every one was startled, but they listened directly with real pleasure, especially as Uvar Ivanovitch imitated the quail’s cry with great correctness.Spurred on by this, he tried mewing like a cat; but this did not go off so well; and after one more quail-call, he looked at them all and stopped.Shubin threw himself on him to kiss him; he pushed him off.At that instant the boat touched the bank, and all the party got out and went on shore.

第一章: 这时，车夫、一个男仆和一个女仆从马车里端出了篮子，在老菩提树下的草地上摆好了午餐。他们围着一块桌布坐了下来，津津有味地品尝着各种各样的馅饼和其他的食品。他们的胃口都很好，但安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜还是不住地劝宾客们多吃点儿，并对他们说没有什么东西能比在美景中野餐更有营养了。她甚至将这些话讲给了尤瓦·伊万诺维奇听。“不用担心我！”他张着那塞满食物的嘴巴含糊不清地说道，“如此美好的天气，简直就是上帝送给我们的礼物！”她不停地重复着。人们好像从没见过她似的，她看起来仿佛小了二十岁。别尔谢涅夫把这些告诉了她。“是的，是的，”她说道，“年轻的时候，我的相貌可是数一数二的。”舒宾紧挨着卓娅坐着，不停地给她添酒，虽然卓娅拒绝，但舒宾却执拗地让她把酒喝掉，结果，他每喝完一杯，就逼着卓娅也干一杯，他甚至说他很想把头靠在她的膝盖上，但是，不管怎样她都决不会让他“如此随便”的。埃琳娜恐怕是这一群中最严肃的一个，但是她的内心却十分地平静，这种感觉她很长时间都没有体会过了。她觉得自己充满了善意和仁慈，因此，她常常想着要把因萨罗夫和别尔谢涅夫都留在自己的身边……安德烈·彼得罗维奇朦胧地感觉到了这些，所以暗自叹了口气。
CHAPTER I: Meanwhile the coachman, with the groom and the maid, had brought the baskets out of the coach, and made dinner ready on the grass under the old lime-trees.They sat down round the outspread tablecloth, and fell upon the pies and other dainties.They all had excellent appetites, while Anna Vassilyevna, with unflagging hospitality, kept urging the guests to eat more, assuring them that nothing was more wholesome than eating in the open air.She even encouraged Uvar Ivanovitch with such assurances.‘Don’t trouble about me!’ he grunted with his mouth full.‘Such a lovely day is a God-send, indeed!’she repeated constantly.One would not have known her; she seemed fully twenty years younger.Bersenyev said as much to her.‘Yes, yes.’she said; ‘I could hold my own with any one in my day.’Shubin attached himself to Zoya, and kept pouring her out wine; she refused it, he pressed her, and finished by drinking the glass himself, and again pressing her to take another; he also declared that he longed to lay his head on her knee; she would on no account permit him ‘such a liberty.’Elena seemed the most serious of the party, but in her heart there was a wonderful sense of peace, such as she had not known for long.She felt filled with boundless goodwill and kindness, and wanted to keep not only Insarov, but Bersenyev too, always at her side….Andrei Petrovitch dimly understood what this meant, and secretly he sighed.

第一章: 几个小时很快就过去了，此时，夜幕已经降临。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜突然变得急躁起来。“啊，我亲爱的朋友们，怎么这么晚了！”她喊道，“再美好的事情也有结束的时候，现在我们该回家了。”她开始慌乱起来，此时大家也都急急忙忙地站起身来朝古堡那边的马车走去。当路过那片湖泊时，他们再次停下了脚步，最后一次欣赏着察里津诺那迷人的风景。周围的一切都笼罩在那傍晚鲜艳的色调中，整个天空一片火红，树上的叶子被渐起的风吹起时，反射出各种各样的颜色，远处的湖面上金光流动，那些坐落在公园里的红色塔楼和凉亭，在青绿色树林的环绕下，既鲜明又清晰。“再见了，察里津诺，我们不会忘记这一天的！”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜喃喃说道……但是，就在这个时候，好像要验证她所说的话似的，突然发生了一件奇怪的事情，这件事的确是不会让人忘记的。
CHAPTER I: The hours flew by; the evening was coming on.Anna Vassilyevna suddenly took alarm.‘Ah, my dear friends, how late it is!’ she cried.‘All good things must have an end; it’s time to go home.’She began bustling about, and they all hastened to get up and walk towards the castle, where the carriages were.As they walked past the lakes, they stopped to admire Tsaritsino for the last time.The landscape on all sides was glowing with the vivid hues of early evening; the sky was red, the leaves were flashing with changing colours as they stirred in the rising wind; the distant waters shone in liquid gold; the reddish turrets and arbours scattered about the garden stood out sharply against the dark green of the trees.‘Farewell, Tsaritsino, we shall not forget to-day’s excursion!’ observed Anna Vassilyevna….But at that instant, and as though in confirmation of her words, a strange incident occurred, which certainly was not likely to be forgotten.

第一章: 事情是这样的。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜还没有跟察里津诺告别完，一阵欢呼声和吵闹声就突然地从她身旁几步远的丁香丛中传了出来，接着，一伙穿戴不齐的年轻人，也就是刚才朝卓娅欢呼的那群德国人，突然跳到了路中间。这群喜欢音乐的年轻人看起来像是喝醉了。他们一看到女士就停下了脚步，但是，他们中间一个个头很高的小伙子从人群中走了出来，那人长着公牛一般的粗脖子和大眼睛，他笨拙地拿掉帽子，摇摇晃晃地来到已经吓呆了的安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜身边。
CHAPTER I: This was what happened.Anna Vassilyevna had hardly sent her farewell greeting to Tsaritsino, when suddenly, a few paces from her, behind a high bush of lilac, were heard confused exclamations, shouts, and laughter; and a whole mob of disorderly men, the same devotees of song who had so energetically applauded Zoya, burst out on the path.These musical gentlemen seemed excessively elevated.They stopped at the sight of the ladies; but one of them, a man of immense height, with a bull neck and a bull’s goggle eyes, separated from his companions, and, bowing clumsily and staggering unsteadily in his gait, approached Anna Vassilyevna, who was petrified with alarm.

第一章: “您好，夫人，”他用憨厚的声音说道，“你还好吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Bonzhoor, madame,’ he said thickly, ‘how are you?’

第一章: 安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜后退了几步。
CHAPTER I: Anna Vassilyevna started back.

第一章: “你怎么了，”那个高个子用不太娴熟的俄语问道，“我们当时高呼着请你们再唱一首，你为何要拒绝呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why wouldn’t you,’ continued the giant in vile Russian, ’sing again when our party shouted bis, and bravo?’

第一章: “没错，为什么啊？”他的同伴也一起叫嚷着。
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, why?’ came from the ranks of his comrades.

第一章: 因萨罗夫准备走上前去，但舒宾却拦住了他，他自己挡在了安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜的前面。
CHAPTER I: Insarov was about to step forward, but Shubin stopped him, and himself screened Anna Vassilyevna.

第一章: “让我来，”他说，“尊贵的朋友们，你们的行为让我们感到十分诧异。我可以看出，你们应该是高加索民族撒克逊人的后代，那么，我们就有理由相信，你们肯定会熟知一些交往的礼仪和规范，然而这位朋友，你还没有介绍自己，就这样贸然地跟这位夫人搭起讪来。你要知道，假如是在其他场合，我会很乐意来交你这个朋友，因为我看到你身体十分强壮，二头肌、三头肌和三角肌都很发达，作为一个雕塑家，我会很乐意邀请你去给我当模特的，但是现在，你就不要再打扰我们了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Allow me,’ he began, ‘honoured stranger, to express to you the heartfelt amazement, into which you have thrown all of us by your conduct.You belong, as far as I can judge, to the Saxon branch of the Caucasian race; consequently we are bound to assume your acquaintance with the customs of society, yet you address a lady to whom you have not been introduced.I assure you that I individually should be delighted another time to make your acquaintance, since I observe in you a phenomenal development of the muscles, biceps, triceps and deltoid, so that, as a sculptor, I should esteem it a genuine happiness to have you for a model; but on this occasion kindly leave us alone.’

第一章: 那位“尊贵的朋友”听了之后，满不在乎地将头偏在一边，两手叉腰站在那里。
CHAPTER I: The ‘honoured stranger’ listened to Shubin’s speech, his head held contemptuously on one side and his arms akimbo.

第一章: “我不明白你在说什么，”他最后开口说道，“你不会认为我是个补鞋匠或是个修表工吧？喂！我可是个官员，一个当官的。知道吗！”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t understand what you say,’ he commented at last.‘Do you suppose I’m a cobbler or a watchmaker?Hey!I’m an officer, an official, so there.’

第一章: “这点我不否认——”舒宾说着。
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t doubt that—’ Shubin was beginning.

第一章: “我所说的是这样，”那个官员继续说着，并用那结实的双手将他推到旁边，就好像在踢开路上的树枝一样——“当我们叫好的时候，你为什么不再唱一首呢？我会马上离开，只要这位小姐，不是那位夫人，不，不是她，而是这位小姐或者是那位（他指了指埃琳娜和卓娅），能够亲吻一下我的脸颊，没错，用德语讲就是亲我一下，怎么样？这可一点儿都不过分啊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘What I say is,’ continued the stranger, putting him aside with his powerful arm, like a twig out of the path—‘why didn’t you sing again when we shouted bis?And I’ll go away directly, this minute, only I tell you what I want, this fraulein, not that madam, no, not her, but this one or that one (he pointed to Elena and Zoya) must give me einen Kuss, as we say in German, a kiss, in fact; eh?That’s not much to ask.’

第一章: “亲一下没什么大不了的。”他的同伴再次叫嚷了起来，“嘿！这下有意思了！”一个略带醉意的德国人说着，笑得前仰后合。
CHAPTER I: ‘Einen Kuss, that’s not much,’ came again from the ranks of his companions, ‘Ih!der Stakramenter!’ cried one tipsy German, bursting with laughter.

第一章: 卓娅抓住了因萨罗夫的手臂，但他却挣脱开来，直冲到那个无礼的高个子身边。
CHAPTER I: Zoya clutched at Insarov’s arm, but he broke away from her, and stood directly facing the insolent giant.

第一章: “识相的话快滚开。”他低声说道，但听起来却很严厉。
CHAPTER I: ‘You will please to move off,’ he said in a voice not loud but sharp.

第一章: 那个德国人大笑了起来，“滚开？不过我就喜欢这样。难道我不会走路吗？滚开？为什么我要滚开？”
CHAPTER I: The German gave a heavy laugh, ‘Move off ?Well, I like that.Can’t I walk where I please?Move off?Why should I move off?’

第一章: “因为你冒犯了这位夫人，”因萨罗夫说着，脸色突然变得苍白起来，“因为你喝醉了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Because you have dared to annoy a lady,’ said Insarov, and suddenly he turned white, ‘because you’re drunk.’

第一章: “嗯？我喝醉了？听听他说的话。你懂了吗，医生？我可是个当官的，而他竟然……现在我要得到满足。她必须得亲我一下。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Eh?me drunk?Hear what he says.Horen Sie das, Herr Provisor?I’m an officer, and he dares…Now I demand satisfaction.Einen Kuss will ich.’

第一章: “如果你胆敢向前一步——”因萨罗夫说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘If you come another step nearer—’ began Insarov.

第一章: “哦？那又怎样？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well?What then’

第一章: “我就将你扔到水里去！”
CHAPTER I: ‘I’ll throw you in the water!’

第一章: “扔到水里？先生们！就这样吗？好吧，那就让大伙儿瞧瞧，那肯定很好玩。”
CHAPTER I: ‘In the water?Herr Je!Is that all?Well, let us see that, that would be very curious, too.’

第一章: 那个官员握起拳头，向前挪了一步，但猛然间，一件令人惊奇的事情发生了。他尖叫了一声，随后整个笨重的身体就被抬了起来，双腿在空中胡乱地踢着，接着，在女士们还没来得及尖叫出来、大家还不知道怎么回事的时候，随着一声巨响，那官员肥胖的身体就被扔了出去，并很快地消失在了漩涡中。
CHAPTER I: The officer lifted his fists and moved forward, but suddenly something extraordinary happened.He uttered an exclamation, his whole bulky person staggered, rose from the ground, his legs kicking in the air, and before the ladies had time to shriek, before any one had time to realise how it had happened, the officer’s massive figure went plop with a heavy splash, and at once disappeared under the eddying water.

第一章: “哦！”女士们异口同声地尖叫了起来。“老天啊！”另一边的人也在喊着。没过多久……一个圆圆的、满头是水的脑袋从水里钻了出来，口里在不停地吐着水泡，两手在嘴边胡乱地挣扎着。“他会被淹死的，快去救救他！救救他！”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜朝因萨罗夫喊道，他此时正站在岸边，双脚分开，喘着粗气。
CHAPTER I: ‘Oh!’ screamed the ladies with one voice.‘Mein Gott!’ was heard from the other side.An instant passed… and a round head, all plastered over with wet hair, showed above water, it was blowing bubbles, this head; and floundering with two hands just at its very lips.‘He will be drowned, save him!save him!’ cried Anna Vassilyevna to Insarov, who was standing with his legs apart on the bank, breathing heavily.

第一章: “他会游上来的，”因萨罗夫回答说，夹杂着不屑和冷淡的语气，“我们出发吧，”他挽起安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜的手臂说道，“走吧，尤瓦·伊万诺维奇，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜。”
CHAPTER I: ‘He will swim out,’ he answered with contemptuous and unsympathetic indifference.‘Let us go on,’ he added, taking Anna Vassilyevna by the arm.‘Come, Uvar Ivanovitch, Elena Nikolaevna.’

第一章: “啊——啊——哦——哦！”那个不幸的德国人此刻正痛苦地呻吟着，他刚抓住了岸边的灯芯草。
CHAPTER I: ‘A—a—o—o’ was heard at that instant, the plaint of the hapless German who had managed to get hold of the rushes on the bank.

第一章: 大家都尾随在因萨罗夫的后面，从那群人的身边经过。不过，没了领头人，这群横行霸道的德国人立马变得谦逊起来，大气都不敢吭一声，但其中一个比较胆大的德国人摇着头喃喃自语着：“好吧……这个简直太……你们就等着瞧吧。”而另一个人却恭敬地甚至摘掉了帽子。对他们而言，因萨罗夫是难以对付的，他的脸上刻着一种仇恨、危险的神态。那群德国人急冲冲地去拉自己的同伴，刚一上岸，那个家伙就泪流满面地朝这些“俄国无赖们”辱骂了起来，口口声声地说着要去起诉他们，还要去见冯基泽里茨伯爵等等。
CHAPTER I: They all followed Insarov, and had to pass close by the party.But, deprived of their leader, the rowdies were subdued and did not utter a word; but one, the boldest of them, muttered, shaking his head menacingly: ‘All right… we shall see though… after that’; but one of the others even took his hat off.Insarov struck them as formidable, and rightly so; something evil, something dangerous could be seen in his face.The Germans hastened to pull out their comrade, who, directly he had his feet on dry ground, broke into tearful abuse and shouted after the ‘Russian scoundrels,’ that he would make a complaint, that he would go to Count Von Kizerits himself, and so on.

第一章: 但这些“俄国无赖们”并没有把他的话放在心上，只是尽可能地加快脚步朝古堡走去。穿过公园的时候，大家谁都没有说话，只有安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜轻轻地叹了口气。然而，当他们走到马车旁停下来的时候，大家都抑制不住地开怀大笑起来。舒宾带头狂笑出声，简直就跟疯了一样，别尔谢涅夫也跟着他咯咯地笑了起来，而卓娅也发出了银铃般的笑声，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜也猛地笑出声来，就连埃琳娜也忍住不地微笑着，最后，因萨罗夫也终于撑不住笑了。然而，谁都没有尤瓦·伊万诺维奇笑得更大声、更持久、更猛烈，他一直笑到肚子发疼，呼吸急促，喷嚏连连。他安静了好一会儿后，在笑出的泪花里低声说着：“我——一直在想——怎么会有一声巨响——那里——原来是他——被扔到水里了。”好不容易将最后一句话说完，他又开始狂笑了起来，整个身体随着笑声不断地颤抖着。卓娅趁机推波助澜。“我看到了他的双腿，”她说，“在空中胡乱地踢着。”“是的，是的，”尤瓦·伊万诺维奇随声附和着，“他的双腿，他的双腿——然后就是砰的一声！他整个人都被扔到水里了！”
CHAPTER I: But the ‘Russian scoundrels’ paid no attention to his vociferations, and hurried on as fast as they could to the castle.They were all silent, as they walked through the garden, though Anna Vassilyevna sighed a little.But when they reached the carriages and stood still, they broke into an irrepressible, irresistible fit of Homeric laughter.First Shubin exploded, shrieking as if he were mad, Bersenyev followed with his gurgling guffaw, then Zoya fell into thin tinkling little trills, Anna Vassilyevna too suddenly broke down, Elena could not help smiling, and even Insarov at last could not resist it.But the loudest, longest, most persistent laugh was Uvar Ivanovitch’s; he laughed till his sides ached, till he choked and panted.He would calm down a little, then would murmur through his tears: ‘I—thought—what’s that splash—and there—he—went plop.’And with the last word, forced out with convulsive effort, his whole frame was shaking with another burst of laughter.Zoya made him worse.‘I saw his legs,’ she said, ‘kicking in the air.’‘Yes, yes,’ gasped Uvar Ivanovitch, ‘his legs, his legs—and then splash!—there he plopped in!’

第一章: “因萨罗夫到底是怎么办到的？那个德国人看起来不是比他壮实很多吗？”卓娅问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘And how did Mr. Insarov manage it?why the German was three times his size?’ said Zoya.

第一章: “让我来告诉你吧，”尤瓦·伊万诺维奇一边说着，一边不停地抹着眼泪，“我当时看到了，他的一只胳膊环绕在他的腰间，并用脚狠狠地绊了他一下，然后他就掉进水里了！我听到——扑通一声巨响——他就被扔了出去。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I’ll tell you,’ answered Uvar Ivanovitch, rubbing his eyes, ‘I saw; with one arm about his waist, he tripped him up, and he went plop!I heard—a splash—there he went.’

第一章: 两辆马车渐渐地远去，此时已经赶了很长时间的路了，察里津诺古堡也逐渐地消失在了眼帘里，而尤瓦·伊万诺维奇却依旧控制不住自己的情绪。后来，跟他坐在一起的舒宾忍不住地嘲笑起他来。
CHAPTER I: Long after the carriages had started, long after the castle of Tsaritsino was out of sight, Uvar Ivanovitch was still unable to regain his composure.Shubin, who was again with him in the carriage, began to cry shame on him at last.

第一章: 然而，因萨罗夫却觉得很不好意思。他正对着埃琳娜坐在马车里（别尔谢涅夫坐在赶车的位置上），一句话都不说，而她也是沉默不语。他猜想，她肯定是在心里责备自己刚才的鲁莽，但是她却没有责备他。她从一开始比较害怕，后来他脸上的神情让她感到十分惊奇，接着她就一直在思索着。她本人也不清楚自己到底在思索着什么。白天她所经历的情感现在都已消失殆尽，她也意识到了这点，此刻，这种情感已被另一种她也说不清楚的感觉代替了。这次游玩结束得太晚，转眼间夜幕已降临。两辆马车在路上疾驶着，有时路过成熟的庄稼田地，那里的空气里充满了小麦的芬芳，有时会路过宽阔的草地，一阵阵新鲜的空气就会迎面扑来。此时，整个天空就好像一层烟雾笼罩在地平线上。最后，月亮升了起来，暗淡而又鲜红。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜此刻已经闭上了眼睛，而卓娅则把脑袋探出窗外，呆呆地望着外面的大路。埃琳娜终于意识到，她已经有一个多小时没有跟因萨罗夫说过话了。于是她请教了他一个无关痛痒的问题，他立刻高兴地回答了她。空气中传来了一阵模糊不清的声音，就好像是远处的各种声响被夹杂在了一起，他们已经离莫斯科很近了。远处的灯光若隐若现，渐渐地，那些光线便强了起来，终于，他们来到了铺有鹅卵石的路面上了。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜醒了过来，大家在马车里也都开始说起话来，尽管都听不清楚对方在讲着什么，所有的声音都被车轮声和马蹄声给淹没了。从莫斯科到孔佐沃的路程仿佛变得既遥远又疲惫，大家要么已经睡着，要么就是沉默不语，都把脑袋靠在各自的角落里，埃琳娜睁着眼睛，她一直在凝视着因萨罗夫那朦胧的身影。一股悲伤的情绪萦绕在舒宾的心中，微风吹过他的眼睛，也会刺激到他，他拢了拢大衣领子，眼眶里充满了泪水。尤瓦·伊万诺维奇平静地打着鼾睡着了，身体在不停地晃悠着。马车终于停了下来。两个仆人把安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜搀了下来，此刻她已经精疲力尽了，和大家分别时，她声称自己快“累死了”，大家都纷纷向她表示感谢，但她却一直在重复着“累死了”。埃琳娜在分别时第一次握了下因萨罗夫的手掌，接着就在窗前坐了很长时间，舒宾趁机对别尔谢涅夫低声说道：
CHAPTER I: Insarov felt ashamed.He sat in the coach facing Elena (Bersenyev had taken his seat on the box), and he said nothing; she too was silent.He thought that she was condemning his action; but she did not condemn him.She had been scared at the first minute; then the expression of his face had impressed her; afterwards she pondered on it all.It was not quite clear to her what the nature of her reflections was.The emotion she had felt during the day had passed away; that she realised; but its place had been taken by another feeling which she did not yet fully understand.The partie de plaisir had been prolonged too late; insensibly evening passed into night.The carriage rolled swiftly along, now beside ripening cornfields, where the air was heavy and fragrant with the smell of wheat; now beside wide meadows, from which a sudden wave of freshness blew lightly in the face.The sky seemed to lie like smoke over the horizon.At last the moon rose, dark and red.Anna Vassilyevna was dozing; Zoya had poked her head out of window and was staring at the road.It occurred to Elena at last that she had not spoken to Insarov for more than an hour.She turned to him with a trifling question; he at once answered her, delighted.Dim sounds began stirring indistinctly in the air, as though thousands of voices were talking in the distance; Moscow was coming to meet them.Lights twinkled afar off; they grew more and more frequent; at last there was the grating of the cobbles under their wheels.Anna Vassilyevna awoke, every one in the carriage began talking, though no one could hear what was said; everything was drowned in the rattle of the cobbles under the two carriages, and the hoofs of the eight horses.Long and wearisome seemed the journey from Moscow to Kuntsovo; all the party were asleep or silent, leaning with their heads pressed into their respective corners; Elena did not close her eyes; she kept them fixed on Insarov’s dimly-outlined figure.A mood of sadness had come upon Shubin; the breeze was blowing into his eyes and irritating him; he retired into the collar of his cloak and was on the point of tears.Uvar Ivanovitch was snoring blissfully, rocking from side to side.The carriages came to a standstill at last.Two men-servants lifted Anna Vassilyevna out of the carriage; she was all to pieces, and at parting from her fellow travellers, announced that she was ‘nearly dead’; they began thanking her, but she only repeated, ‘nearly dead.’ Elena for the first time pressed Insarov’s hand at parting, and for a long while she sat at her window before undressing; Shubin seized an opportunity to whisper to Bersenyev:

第一章: “瞧，他可真是个大英雄，他竟然可以把喝醉了的德国人扔进水里去！”
CHAPTER I: ‘There, isn’t he a hero; he can pitch drunken Germans into the river!’

第一章: “然而你却办不到。”别尔谢涅夫反驳道，然后就和因萨罗夫一起回去了。
CHAPTER I: ‘While you didn’t even do that,’ retorted Bersenyev, and he started homewards with Insarov.

第一章: 当这两个年轻人回到别墅的时候，天空已经露出了白肚皮。此刻，太阳还没有出来，但是空气中已经传来了阵阵凉意，灰白色的露水出现在了草地上，早起的一群云雀在朦胧辽阔的天空中大声叫着，那里还有最后一颗星星挂在空中，像一只独眼似的俯瞰着整个大地。
CHAPTER I: The dawn was already showing in the sky when the two friends reached their lodging.The sun had not yet risen, but already the chill of daybreak was in the air, a grey dew covered the grass, and the first larks were trilling high, high up in the shadowy infinity of air, whence like a solitary eye looked out the great, last star.

第一章: 第十六章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XVI

第一章: 和因萨罗夫熟识之后，埃琳娜（第五次或者是第六次）开始写日记了。下面的内容节选自她的日记：
CHAPTER I: Soon after her acquaintance with Insarov, Elena (for the fifth or sixth time) began a diary.Here are some extracts from it:

第一章: “六月……安德烈·彼得罗维奇拿了几本书给我，但我却读不下去。我不好意思跟他讲实话，但我又不想在还书的时候骗他说我已看过了。我觉得那样会伤害到他。他一直都很关心我。看起来他可能有点儿喜欢我吧。他真是个好人，安德烈·彼得罗维奇……我在想些什么啊？为什么我心里会感到这样地沉重，这样地压抑？为什么我看到飞过的小鸟时会感到嫉妒？我感觉到，我很希望跟它们一起翱翔在空中，去哪里我不知道，但一定要远离这个地方。我这种想法难道不邪恶吗？我的父母，我的家庭全在这边。难道我不爱他们了吗？是的，我现在已经不像我所希望的那样爱他们了。要承认这一点真得很可怕，但这却是事实。或许我天生就是个充满罪恶感的人，或许这就是我内心伤感和不安的原因吧。好像有一只无形的手抓住了我，把我摁倒，我好像被关在了一个监狱里，四周的墙壁马上就要朝我这边倒来。为什么别人没有这种感觉呢？如果我对自己的双亲都冷漠不语，那我还会爱谁呢？很明显，父亲是对的，他老是责备我说除了小猫小狗，我就不会爱别人了。这点我要好好想想。我很少祈祷的，但我现在应该去祷告一下……啊，我觉得我是知道怎样去爱的！当和因萨罗夫先生在一起的时候，我还是感觉很害羞。我不知道这是为什么，我觉得我已经不是个小女孩了，他是如此地坦诚，如此地友好。有时，他也会摆出一副严肃的样子。他没有过多的时间来看望我们。我感觉到了这些，也就不好意思再去占用他的时间了。而安德烈·彼得罗维奇则恰恰相反。我可以跟他聊一整天。但他总是在说因萨罗夫。总是告诉我一些关于他的可怕的事情！昨晚我还看到他出现在我梦里，手里拿着一把匕首。好像在对我说：‘我要杀了你，然后再杀掉我自己！’这简直太荒谬了！
CHAPTER I: ‘June….Andrei Petrovitch brings me books, but I can’t read them.I’m ashamed to confess it to him; but I don’t like to give back the books, tell lies, say I have read them.I feel that would mortify him.He is always watching me.He seems devoted to me.A very good man, Andrei Petrovitch….What is it I want?Why is my heart so heavy, so oppressed?Why do I watch the birds with envy as they fly past?I feel that I could fly with them, fly, where I don’t know, but far from here.And isn’t that desire sinful?I have here mother, father, home.Don’t I love them?No, I don’t love them, as I should like to love.It’s dreadful to put that in words, but it’s the truth.Perhaps I am a great sinner; perhaps that is why I am so sad, why I have no peace.Some hand seems laid on me, weighing me down, as though I were in prison, and the walls would fall on me directly.Why is it others don’t feel this?Whom shall I love, if I am cold to my own people?It’s clear, papa is right; he reproaches me for loving nothing but cats and dogs.I must think about that.I pray very little; I must pray…. Ah, I think I should know how to love!…I am still shy with Mr. Insarov.I don’t know why; I believe I’m not schoolgirlish generally, and he is so simple and kind.Sometimes he has a very serious face.He can’t give much thought to us.I feel that, and am ashamed in a way to take up his time.With Andrei Petrovitch it’s quite a different thing.I am ready to chat with him the whole day long.But he too always talks of Insarov.And such terrible facts he tells me about him!I saw him in a dream last night with a dagger in his hand.And he seemed to say to me, “I will kill you and I will kill myself!”What silliness!

第一章: “啊，如果有人这样对我说：‘你必须这样做！’要有一颗善心——这还不够，要多做善事……是的，这才是人生中最重要的事情。但是，要怎样做善事呢？哦，如果我能学会控制自己该多好啊！我不知道我为什么老是想起因萨罗夫先生。当他过来拜访，坐下来认真地听着时，他自己一点儿都不紧张，泰然自若，我看着他心里就会觉得很高兴，就是这样而已，当他离开以后，我会一直琢磨着他刚才所说的话，不断地埋怨着自己，甚至会感到失落。我不知道这是为什么。（他法语说得不好，但却并没有觉得不好意思——我很喜欢他这点。）然而，我总是对新结交的朋友想得很多。每次跟他讲话时，我就会突然想起我们的男管家，瓦西里，他曾从一个着火的茅草屋里救出一个上了年纪的瘸子，而自己也差点儿丢了性命。父亲夸他是个勇敢的人，母亲奖励了他五卢布，而我对他则佩服得五体投地。他有一张极其平凡的面孔——甚至看起来有点儿愚蠢——后来他却嗜酒如命……
CHAPTER I: ‘Oh, if some one would say to me: “There, that’s what you must do!”Being good—isn’t much; doing good… yes, that’s the great thing in life.But how is one to do good?Oh, if I could learn to control myself!I don’t know why I am so often thinking of Mr. Insarov.When he comes and sits and listens intently, but makes no effort, no exertion himself, I look at him, and feel pleased, and that’s all, and when he goes, I always go over his words, and feel vexed with myself, and upset even.I can’t tell why.(He speaks French badly and isn’t ashamed of it—I like that.)I always think a lot about new people, though.As I talked to him, I suddenly was reminded of our butler, Vassily, who rescued an old cripple out of a hut that was on fire, and was almost killed himself.Papa called him a brave fellow, mamma gave him five roubles, and I felt as though I could fall at his feet.And he had a simple face—stupid-looking even—and he took to drink later on….

第一章: “今天我给了一个女乞丐一便士，她对我说：‘你怎么看起来这样伤心？’我从来没想到我看起来会伤感。我猜想这可能是因为孤独的原因吧，不管我是善良还是邪恶，都是一样地孤单！没有人朝我伸出手来。那些靠近我的人，都不是我想要的，而我想接近的人——却一个个都离我远去。
CHAPTER I: ‘I gave a penny to-day to a beggar woman, and she said to me, “Why are you so sorrowful?”I never suspected I looked sorrowful.I think it must come from being alone, always alone, for better, for worse!There is no one to stretch out a hand to me.Those who come to me, I don’t want; and those I would choose—pass me by.

第一章: “……我不知道今天是怎么回事，我脑中十分混乱，我想跪在地上请求宽恕。我不知道是谁又如何让我这样难过，但我清楚我现在已经饱受折磨，我在心里叛逆地呐喊着，我泪流满面，内心无法平静……哦，我的上帝，请制止住我内心的这些纷乱吧！只有你才能挽救我，其他的都没有用，我那微不足道的施舍也好，那满腹经纶的学问也罢，所有的这一切都无法帮助我。我很想去某个地方当个佣人，真的，这样我就不会再难受了。
CHAPTER I: ‘…I don’t know what’s the matter with me to-day; my head is confused, I want to fall on my knees and beg and pray for mercy.I don’t know by whom or how, but I feel as if I were being tortured, and inwardly I am shrieking in revolt; I weep and can’t be quiet….O my God, subdue these outbreaks in me!Thou alone canst aid me, all else is useless; my miserable alms-giving, my studies can do nothing, nothing, nothing to help me.I should like to go out as a servant somewhere, really; that would do me good.

第一章: “我的青春应该怎样度过，我为何而活，我的灵魂该寄放在哪里，这一切都是为了什么？
CHAPTER I: ‘What is my youth for, what am I living for, why have I a soul, what is it all for?

第一章: “……因萨罗夫，因萨罗夫先生——真的，我不知道该如何下笔——他一直都让我好奇，我很想知道，他内心里到底在想些什么？他看起来很坦诚、一副很容易交往的样子，但我却一点儿都不了解他。有时他会用那种探究的目光看着我——还是这只是我的猜想而已？保罗一直取笑我。我很不喜欢他。他到底想做什么？他爱上了我……但他的爱对我无益。他也爱上了卓娅。我不爱他，这对他不公平，昨天他还跟我说我从来都没喜欢过他……确实是这样。真是糟糕透顶了。
CHAPTER I: ‘… Insarov, Mr. Insarov—upon my word I don’t know how to write—still interests me, I should like to know what he has within, in his soul?He seems so open, so easy to talk to, but I can see nothing.Sometimes he looks at me with such searching eyes—or is that my fancy?Paul keeps teasing me.I am angry with Paul.What does he want?He’s in love with me… but his love’s no good to me.He’s in love with Zoya too.I’m unjust to him; he told me yesterday I didn’t know how to be unjust by halves… that’s true.It’s very horrid.

第一章: “啊，我觉得每个人都需要感受一下不幸、贫穷或是痛苦，否则我们很快就会自以为是的。
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah, I feel one needs unhappiness, or poverty or sickness, or else one gets conceited directly.

第一章: “……今天安德烈·彼得罗维奇为何会跟我讲那两个保加利亚人的事情呢！他好像是故意说给我听的。这跟我和因萨罗夫先生有什么关系呢？我对安德烈·彼得罗维奇的感觉有些复杂。
CHAPTER I: ‘… What made Andrei Petrovitch tell me to-day about those two Bulgarians!He told me it as it were with some intention.What have I to do with Mr. Insarov?I feel cross with Andrei Petrovitch.

第一章: “……我拿起笔却不知道该写些什么。今天实在是太意外了，他竟然在花园里主动跟我聊天！他这个人是多么地友好，多么地让人信赖啊！这件事发生得太突然了！就好像我们以前就已相识，只是刚刚才认出对方而已。我以前怎么没能了解他啊？此刻他跟我是如此地亲近！而这——实在是太美好了——现在我内心里感觉到一种从来没有过的平静。真是可笑，昨天我还生着安德烈·彼得罗维奇的气，对他感到很是不满，甚至我还叫他因萨罗夫先生，可是今天……至少他是一个坦诚的人，一个可以让人信赖的男人。他从来都不骗人，他是我碰到的第一个不会说谎的人，其他的人都在撒谎，说着各种各样的假话。安德烈·彼得罗维奇，他是一个很好的朋友，为什么我要伤害他呢？不！安德烈·彼得罗维奇要比他更加有学问，或许比他还聪明些。然而我不明白的是，他在因萨罗夫旁边竟然看起来那么渺小。当他谈到自己的祖国时，他的形象立马高大了起来，他的脸孔看起来神采奕奕，他的声音听起来如钢铁般坚强，同时……不……彷佛这世上没有人可以将他打倒。他不是只在口头上说说而已……他已付诸了行动，而且将会继续下去，我想问问他……他突然转过头来朝我笑了笑！只有和兄弟之间才有这样的微笑！啊，我实在是太兴奋了！当他第一次前来拜访时，我怎么没有想到我们的关系会发展得如此迅速。现在，我甚至还为我第一次见到他时表现出来的冷淡而感到高兴。冷淡？难道我现在对他不冷淡了吗？很长时间我的内心都没有如此平静了。我感到很平静，很平静。没有什么可写了吗？我经常看到他，仅此而已。还有什么可写的呢？
CHAPTER I: ‘… I take my pen and don’t know how to begin.How unexpectedly he began to talk to me in the garden to-day!How friendly and confiding he was!How quickly it happened!As if we were old, old friends and had only just recognised each other.How could I have not understood him before?How near he is to me now!And—what’s so wonderful—I feel ever so much calmer now.It’s ludicrous; yesterday I was angry with Andrei Petrovitch, and angry with him, I even called him Mr. Insarov, and to-day…Here at last is a true man; some one one may depend upon.He won’t tell lies; he’s the first man I have met who never tells lies; all the others tell lies, everything’s lying.Andrei Petrovitch, dear good friend, why do I wrong you?No! Andrei Petrovitch is more learned than he is, even, perhaps more intellectual.But I don’t know, he seems so small beside him.When he speaks of his country he seems taller, and his face grows handsome, and his voice is like steel, and… no… it seems as though there were no one in the world before whom he would flinch.And he doesn’t only talk…. he has acted and he will act I shall ask him…. How suddenly he turned to me and smiled!…It’s only brothers that smile like that!Ah, how glad I am!When he came the first time, I never dreamt that we should so soon get to know each other.And now I am even pleased that I remained indifferent to him at first.Indifferent? Am I not indifferent then now?…It’s long since I have felt such inward peace.I feel so quiet, so quiet.And there’s nothing to write?I see him often and that’s all.What more is there to write?

第一章: “……保罗把自己关了起来，安德烈·彼得罗维奇也不经常过来了……可怜的家伙们！我感觉他……然而这是不可能的事情。我喜欢跟安德烈·彼得罗维奇交谈，他总是避免谈自己，经常聊一些切合实际的、有用处的事情。这跟舒宾完全不同。舒宾总是像只蝴蝶似的穿得十分完美，并引以为傲，而蝴蝶们是不会这样做的。然而舒宾和安德烈·彼得罗维奇这两个人……我很清楚我的想法。
CHAPTER I: ‘… Paul shuts himself up, Andrei Petrovitch has taken to coming less often…. poor fellow!I fancy he…But that can never be, though.I like talking to Andrei Petrovitch; never a word of self, always of something sensible, useful.Very different from Shubin.Shubin’s as fine as a butterfly, and admires his own finery; which butterflies don’t do.But both Shubin and Andrei Petrovitch….I know what I mean.

第一章: “……他很喜欢过来拜访我们，我是知道的。但是为什么呢？他从我这里发现了什么？的确，我们志趣相投，我和他两个人都不怎么喜欢诗歌，我们也都不懂艺术。但是，他要比我强许多！他一直都很平静，但我却总是心神不宁，他已经选择了自己的道路，自己的目标——但我呢——我该何去何从？哪里才是我的归宿？他沉着冷静，但是他所有的想法都很遥远。有那么一天，他将会永远地离开我们，越过大海，回到自己的祖国。这该怎么办呢？愿上帝祝福他！然而不管怎样，我还是很高兴能够认识他，很高兴他还在这里。
CHAPTER I: ‘… He enjoys coming to us, I see that.But why?what does he find in me?It’s true our tastes are alike; he and I, both of us don’t care for poetry; neither of us knows anything of art. But how much better he is than I!He is calm, I am in perpetual excitement; he has chosen his path, his aim—while I—where am I going?where is my home?He is calm, but all his thoughts are far away.The time will come, and he will leave us for ever, will go home, there over the sea.Well?God grant he may!Any way I shall be glad that I knew him, while he was here.

第一章: “为什么他不是俄国人呢？不，他怎么可能是俄国人啊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why isn’t he a Russian?No, he could not be Russian.

第一章: “母亲也很喜欢他，说他是一位虚心的年轻人。亲爱的母亲！她并不了解他。保罗什么话也不说，他已经猜到了我不喜欢他的暗示，但是他很嫉妒他。令人反感的家伙！不过他为何会这样？难道我曾经……这些事情简直太荒谬了！我怎么会想到这些东西呢？
CHAPTER I: ‘Mamma too likes him; she says: an unassuming young man.Dear mamma!She does not understand him.Paul says nothing; he guessed I didn’t like his hints, but he’s jealous of him.Spiteful boy!And what right has he?Did I ever…All that’s nonsense!What makes all that come into my head?

第一章: “……然而这是不是有点儿奇怪啊，我现在已经二十岁了，但却从来没有喜欢上一个人！我觉得德（我称呼他为德——我很喜欢德米特里这个名字）内心十分淡定的原因就在于他把自己完完全全地奉献给了自己的事业，自己的理想。这样他还有什么可烦心的事呢？当一个人完完全全地……完完全全地……把自己奉献出去的时候，那么他就没有什么事情可担忧了。如此一来，就不是我想怎么做了，而且它需要我做些什么。顺便说一下，我和他两个人都很喜欢同一种花。今天早上我摘了一朵玫瑰，一片花瓣落在了地上，他就把它捡了起来……然后我就将整朵花送给了他。
CHAPTER I: ‘… Isn’t it strange though, that up till now, up to twenty, I have never loved any one!I believe that the reason why D.’s (I shall call him D.—I like that name Dmitri) soul is so clear, is that he is entirely given up to his work, his ideal.What has he to trouble about?When any one has utterly… utterly… given himself up, he has little sorrow, he is not responsible for anything.It’s not I want, but it wants.By the way, he and I both love the same flowers.I picked a rose this morning, one leaf fell, he picked it up….I gave him the whole rose.

第一章: “……德经常过来拜访我们。昨天整个晚上他都在这里。他想教我保加利亚语。跟他在一起我很快乐，就像在家里一样，比呆在家里还有趣。
CHAPTER I: ‘… D. often comes to us.Yesterday he spent the whole evening.He wants to teach me Bulgarian.I feel happy with him, quite at home, more than at home.

第一章: “……时间过得真快……我很开心，但不知为何内心会感到不满，我很感激上苍，我快要掉泪了。哦，多么热闹、多么美好的日子啊！
CHAPTER I: ‘… The days fly past….I am happy, and somehow discontent and I am thankful to God, and tears are not far off.Oh these hot bright days!

第一章: “……我还是跟以前那样开心快乐，但偶尔也会觉得有点儿感伤。我很开心。我真的开心吗？
CHAPTER I: ‘… I am still light-hearted as before, and only at times, and only a little, sad.I am happy.Am I happy?

第一章: “……昨天的远足我会牢记在心的。当他猛地抓住那个巨人，像丢皮球似的把他扔到水里的时候，给我留下了极其奇特、新奇又可怕的印象。我并没有因此而感到害怕……但是他却吓到了我。随后——他的脸色变得十分可怕，几乎达到了残忍的地步！他那样说道：‘他自己会游上来的！’这让我十分震惊。很明显，我还是不了解他。接着，当大家都笑起来的时候，我也跟着笑了，我替他感到难过！他有点儿不好意思，我感觉到他在我面前有点儿难为情。当夜晚降临的时候，他在马车里给我说了这些，当时我试图好好地了解一下他，对他我感到有点儿害怕。是的，千万不能戏弄他，他是个强大的战士。然而，他为何会有那样邪恶的面孔，颤抖的双唇和那眼中的怒火呢？或许，这是不可避免的吧？难道和蔼的人就不能成为一个男子汉，不能成为英雄吗？‘生活是残忍的。’他曾经对我说过。我给安德烈·彼得罗维奇重复了这句话，他没有同意德的说法。他们到底谁对呢？但那一天开始的时候！我很高兴能跟他一起走着，即使不说一句话。……不过，对已经发生过的事情，我感到很高兴。我觉得那是很正常的事情。
CHAPTER I: ‘… It will be long before I forget the expedition yesterday.What strange, new, terrible impressions when he suddenly took that great giant and flung him like a ball into the water.I was not frightened … yet he frightened me.And afterwards—what an angry face, almost cruel!How he said, “He will swim out!”It gave me a shock.So I did not understand him.And afterwards when they all laughed, when I was laughing, how I felt for him!He was ashamed, I felt that he was ashamed before me.He told me so afterwards in the carriage in the dark, when I tried to get a good view of him and was afraid of him.Yes, he is not to be trifled with, and he is a splendid champion.But why that wicked look, those trembling lips, that angry fire in his eyes?Or is it, perhaps, inevitable?Isn’t it possible to be a man, a hero, and to remain soft and gentle?“Life is a coarse business,” he said to me once lately.I repeated that saying to Andrei Petrovitch; he did not agree with D. Which of them is right?But the beginning of that day!How happy I was, walking beside him, even without speaking.… But I am glad of what happened.I see that it was quite as it should be.

第一章: “……心里又开始烦躁了……我感到很不舒服……这几天我一点儿日记都没写，因为我没有写的冲动。我觉得，不管我写什么，都不是我内心里的真实想法。……我心里到底在想些什么呢？有一次我跟他谈了很长时间，让我明白了很多事情。他告诉了我他的梦想（顺便说一下，我直到现在才知道他脖子上为何会有那样的一条伤疤……天哪！我一想到他竟然被判过死刑，然后被救了出来，但却受了重伤……）他预言说战争一触即发，并为此感到愉快。然而，我却从来没有见过德会如此地失落。他怎能……他！……失落什么呢？父亲从城里回来，刚好遇到我们两个。他有些奇怪地看着我们。安德烈·彼得罗维奇也过来了，我发现他这段时间瘦了很多，面色苍白。他曾埋怨过我，责怪我对舒宾太冷淡、太不上心了。我已经完全忘记了保罗的存在。以后若是能遇到他，再慢慢地弥补吧。他现在对我来说可有可无……其他人也一样。安德烈·彼得罗维奇跟我说话的时候带着一股伤感的语调。这意味着什么呢？为什么我周围的一切和我的内心都这样地难以捉摸？我好像感觉到在我的周围及内心里，有一个不可捉摸的谜团正在潜滋暗长，而我正在试图找到谜底……我整夜都无法入眠，我的头很疼。写作有什么好处呢？今天他很快就离开了，而我却想跟他谈谈……他好像在故意躲着我。是的，他在躲着我。
CHAPTER I: ‘… Restlessness again…I am not quite well….All these days I have written nothing in this book, because I have had no wish to write.I felt, whatever I write, it won’t be what is in my heart.… And what is in my heart?I have had a long talk with him, which revealed a great deal.He told me his plan (by the way, I know now how he got the wound in his neck….Good God!when I think he was actually condemned to death, that he was only just saved, that he was wounded…. ) He prophesies war and will be glad of it.And for all that, I never saw D. so depressed.What can he…he!… be depressed by?Papa arrived home from town and came upon us two.He looked rather queerly at us.Andrei Petrovitch came; I noticed he had grown very thin and pale.He reproved me, saying I behave too coldly and inconsiderately to Shubin.I had utterly forgotten Paul’s existence.I will see him, and try to smooth over my offence.He is nothing to me now… nor any one else in the world.Andrei Petrovitch talked to me in a sort of commiserating way.What does it all mean?Why is everything around me and within me so dark?I feel as if about me and within me, something mysterious were happening, for which I want to find the right word….I did not sleep all night; my head aches.What’s the good of writing?He went away so quickly to-day and I wanted to talk to him….He almost seems to avoid me.Yes, he avoids me.

第一章: “……我找到了答案，我终于明白了！哦，上帝，同情同情我吧……我爱上了他！”
CHAPTER I: ‘… The word is found, light has dawned on me!My God, have pity on me….I love him!’

第一章: 第十七章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XVII

第一章: 也就在那一天，当埃琳娜把她生命中最重要的一句话写进日记中的时候，因萨罗夫正坐在别尔谢涅夫的房间里，而别尔谢涅夫则一脸困惑地站在他的面前。因萨罗夫刚和他提到自己打算第二天就回莫斯科的想法。
CHAPTER I: On the very day on which Elena had written this last fatal line in her diary, Insarov was sitting in Bersenyev’s room, and Bersenyev was standing before him with a look of perplexity on his face.Insarov had just announced his intention of returning to Moscow the next day.

第一章: “听我说！”别尔谢涅夫叫道，“为什么啊，夏天最美好的时光才刚刚开始。你回莫斯科干什么？这决定实在是太突然了！或者是你听到了什么消息？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Upon my word!’ cried Bersenyev.‘Why, the finest part of the summer is just beginning.What will you do in Moscow?What a sudden decision!Or have you had news of some sort?’

第一章: “我没有听到什么，”因萨罗夫回答说，“然而我考虑再三，我觉得我不适合生活在这里。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I have had no news,’ replied Insarov; ‘but on thinking things over, I find I cannot stop here.’

第一章: “这怎么可能呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘How can that be?’

第一章: “安德烈·彼得罗维奇，”因萨罗夫说，“你就行行好吧……请别再坚持了，我很遗憾不能再和你住在一起，但是只能这样了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Andrei Petrovitch,’ said Insarov, ‘be so kind… don’t insist, please, I am very sorry myself to be leaving you, but it can’t be helped.’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫目不转睛地盯着他。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev looked at him intently.

第一章: “我知道，”他最后说道，“我也不再劝你了。那么，就这样吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I know,’ he said at last, ‘there’s no persuading you.And so, it’s a settled matter.’

第一章: “确定要离开吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Is it?’

第一章: “完全确定。”因萨罗夫回答说，站起身来走了出去。
CHAPTER I: ‘Absolutely settled,’ replied Insarov, getting up and going away.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫在房间里来回走着，然后拿起帽子就朝斯塔霍夫家赶去。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev walked about the room, then took his hat and set off for the Stahovs.

第一章: “你想跟我说些什么吧。”当房间里没有别人时，埃琳娜对他说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘You have something to tell me,’ Elena said to him, directly they were left alone.

第一章: “没错，你怎么猜到的？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, how did you guess?’

第一章: “这不重要，快告诉我发生了什么事情。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Never mind; tell me what it is.’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫告诉了她因萨罗夫的打算。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev told her of Insarov’s intention.

第一章: 埃琳娜惊得脸色苍白。
CHAPTER I: Elena turned white.

第一章: “这是什么意思？”她吃力地说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What does it mean?’ she articulated with effort.

第一章: “你知道的，”别尔谢涅夫说，“德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇从来不会向别人解释自己的行为的。但是我想……埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，我们先坐下，你看上去不太舒服……我想我已经猜到他突然离去的原因了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You know,’ observed Bersenyev, ‘Dmitri Nikanorovitch does not care to give reasons for his actions.But I think… let us sit down, Elena Nikolaevna, you don’t seem very well….I fancy I can guess what is the real cause of this sudden departure.’

第一章: “什么——什么原因？”埃琳娜重复着问，并无意识地用那冰凉的双手紧紧地攥着别尔谢涅夫的手。
CHAPTER I: ‘What—what cause?’ repeated Elena, and unconsciously she gripped tightly Bersenyev’s hand in her chill ringers.

第一章: “你知道的，”别尔谢涅夫开口说道，夹杂着一丝悲哀的笑容，“我怎么给你解释呢？我得从去年春天谈起，那时我跟因萨罗夫的关系刚开始密切起来。有一次，我在一位亲戚家中碰到了他，这位亲戚有一个漂亮的女儿，我感觉到因萨罗夫似乎对她有意思，然后我就把自己的想法说给他听。他听后哈哈大笑，直称我搞错了，还说自己情窦未开，假如碰到了这样的情况，他就会立马走开，因为他不愿意，按他自己的话说，为了感情上的事情而放弃了自己的理想和责任是不对的。“我是一个保加利亚人，”他说道，“我不需要一个俄国人的爱情……”
CHAPTER I: ‘You see,’ began Bersenyev, with a pathetic smile, ’how can I explain to you?I must go back to last spring, to the time when I began to be more intimate with Insarov.I used to meet him then at the house of a relative, who had a daughter, a very pretty girl I thought that Insarov cared for her, and I told him so.He laughed, and answered that I was mistaken, that he was quite heart-whole, but if anything of that sort did happen to him, he should run away directly, as he did not want, in his own words, for the sake of personal feeling, to be false to his cause and his duty.“I am a Bulgarian,” he said, “and I have no need of a Russian love—”

第一章: “那……这样的话……现在您准备……”埃琳娜耳语到。她无意地转过头，就像一个受到重创的人，但是她依然紧握着她已经抓住的手。
CHAPTER I: ‘Well—so—now you—’ whispered Elena.She involuntarily turned away her head, like a man expecting a blow, but she still held the hand she had clutched.

第一章: “我认为，”他说道，声音渐渐低下去，“我认为我曾猜想的事情真的已经发生了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I think,’ he said, and his own voice sank, ‘I think that what I fancied then has really happened now.’

第一章: “那……您认为……不要再折磨我了！”埃琳娜突然说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘That is—you think—don’t torture me!’ broke suddenly from Elena.

第一章: “我觉得，”别尔谢涅夫接着说道，“因萨罗夫现在爱上了一个俄国女孩，因此为了兑现他的诺言，他决心打算要走了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I think,’ Bersenyev continued hurriedly, ‘that Insarov is in love now with a Russian girl, and he is resolved to go, according to his word.’

第一章: 埃琳娜将他的手握得更紧了，她的头也垂得更低，就像要把她那因羞愧而涨红的脸和脖子都从众人的目光中隐藏起来。
CHAPTER I: Elena clasped his hand still tighter, and her head drooped still lower, as if she would hide from other eyes the flush of shame which suddenly blazed over her face and neck.

第一章: “安德烈·彼得罗维奇，你真的如天使般善良，”她说，“但是，他还会来跟我们告别吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Andrei Petrovitch, you are kind as an angel,’ she said, ‘but will he come to say goodbye?’

第一章: “是的，我觉得他肯定会来的。他其实不想走……”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, I imagine so; he will be sure to come.He wouldn’t like to go away—’

第一章: “告诉他，告诉他……’
CHAPTER I: ‘Tell him, tell him—’

第一章: 但是现在这个可怜的女孩已经情绪崩溃了，眼泪从眼眶中滑落，她跑了出去。
CHAPTER I: But here the poor girl broke down; tears rushed streaming from her eyes, and she ran out of the room.

第一章: “她是多么地爱他啊”，别尔谢涅夫一边想着，一边慢慢地向家里走去，“我没有想到是这样的，我没有想到她的感情如此地强烈。她说我很善良，”他回忆着，“谁能告诉我是什么感情让我将这件事情告诉埃琳娜的？肯定不是因为善良，不，肯定不是的。这全是因为我强烈地想确信这把匕首是否真的插在了伤口上。我现在该满意了。他们是那么地相爱，我却利用了他们……未来在科学和俄国公众之间的中间人，舒宾曾这样叫我，现在看来似乎不管天意如何，我都必须要做个中间人了。但是如果我弄错了呢？不，我不会弄错的……”
CHAPTER I: ‘So that’s how she loves him,’ thought Bersenyev, as he walked slowly home.‘I didn’t expect that; I didn’t think she felt so strongly.I am kind, she says.’ he pursued his reflections:… ‘Who can tell what feelings, what impulse drove me to tell Elena all that?It was not kindness; no, not kindness.It was all the accursed desire to make sure whether the dagger is really in the wound.I ought to be content.They love each other, and I have been of use to them….The future go-between between science and the Russian public Shubin calls me; it seems as though it had been decreed at my birth that I should be a go-between.But if I’m mistaken?No, I’m not mistaken—’

第一章: 这令安德烈·彼得罗维奇觉得苦闷，也使得他不会再注意到劳默尔了。
CHAPTER I: It was bitter for Andrei Petrovitch, and he could not turn his mind to Raumer.

第一章: 第二天下午两点，因萨罗夫来到斯塔霍夫家。就像设计好的一样，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜的客厅里有位客人，是邻居牧师的太太，一位优秀杰出的女人，尽管她和警察有些不愉快，因为她执意要在一天中最热的时候，到路旁的湖里沐浴，而一位严肃的将军的家眷总是常常经过那里。一位客人的存在起初对于埃琳娜甚至是一种解放，可因为听到了因萨罗夫的脚步声，她脸上变得毫无血色；但是，想到他告别的时候可能没有机会与她单独说话，她的心一沉。他看起来也有些烦躁，逃避着她的眼光。“他一定不会马上就走吧，”埃琳娜暗想。但事实上，因萨罗夫已经转身去跟安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜道别了，埃琳娜急忙站起来，叫他到窗边去。牧师的夫人很意外，她也想转身，但是她被衣服勒得很紧以至于每动一下就发出咯吱咯吱的声音，所以她还是坐在原来的位置上。
CHAPTER I: The next day at two o’clock Insarov arrived at the Stahovs’.As though by express design, there was a visitor in Anna Vassilyevna’s drawing-room at the time, the wife of a neighbouring chief-priest, an excellent and worthy woman, though she had had a little unpleasantness with the police, because she thought fit, in the hottest part of the day, to bathe in a lake near the road, along which a certain dignified general’s family used often to be passing.The presence of an outside person was at first even a relief to Elena, from whose face every trace of colour vanished, directly she heard Insarov’s step; but her heart sank at the thought that he might go without a word with her alone.He, too, seemed confused, and avoided meeting her eyes.‘Surely he will not go directly,’ thought Elena.Insarov was, in fact, turning to take leave of Anna Vassilyevna; Elena hastily rose and called him aside to the window.The priest’s wife was surprised, and tried to turn round; but she was so tightly laced that her stays creaked at every movement, and she stayed where she was.

第一章: “听着，”埃琳娜急促地说，“我知道你是来干什么的，安德烈·彼得罗维奇已经把你的决定告诉我了，但是我请求你，我请求你今天别跟我们告别，你明天上午早一点，十一点再来吧。我有些话要跟您说。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Listen,’ said Elena hurriedly; ‘I know what you have come for; Andrei Petrovitch told me of your intention, but I beg, I entreat you, do not say good-bye to us to-day, but come here to-morrow rather earlier, at eleven.I must have a few words with you.’

第一章: 因萨罗夫没有说话，只是低下了头。
CHAPTER I: Insarov bent his head without speaking.

第一章: “我不会强留你的……你能答应我吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘I will not keep you….You promise me?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫又一次垂下了头，但是还是没说一句话。
CHAPTER I: Again Insarov bowed, but said nothing.

第一章: “列诺奇卡，快过来，”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜说，“快看看，多漂亮的手提包啊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Lenotchka, come here,’ said Anna Vassilyevna, ‘look, what a charming reticule.’

第一章: “这是我自己亲手做的。”牧师夫人回答道。
CHAPTER I: ‘I worked it myself,’ observed the priest’s wife.

第一章: 埃琳娜从窗户旁边走过来了。
CHAPTER I: Elena came away from the window.

第一章: 因萨罗夫在斯塔霍夫家还没呆到十五分钟。埃琳娜一直安静地看着他。他坐立不安，显得很拘束。像以前一样，他并不知道该望向哪里，然后突然地离开了，似乎就那么消失不见了。
CHAPTER I: Insarov did not stay more than a quarter of an hour at the Stahovs’.Elena watched him secretly.He was restless and ill at ease.As before, he did not know where to look, and he went away strangely and suddenly; he seemed to vanish.

第一章: 这一天对于埃琳娜来说很漫长，慢慢长夜就更加难熬。埃琳娜坐在她的床上，胳膊搭在膝盖上，垂着头；有时候她来到窗户旁，将滚烫的额头靠在冰冷的玻璃上；翻来覆去想了又想，直到自己精疲力尽。她的心变得如石头般坚硬，只是自己未感觉到，但是她头里的血管却在痛苦地跳动着，头发让她烦闷，嘴唇也很干燥。“他肯定会来的……他还没跟妈妈告别呢……他不会骗我的……难道安德烈·彼得罗维奇是对的吗？不会的……他并没有直接答应我要来……我们此生就不能再相见了吗？”这些想法从未离开过她，周而复始地困扰着她，就像是一团迷雾一直盘旋在她的心中。“他是爱我的！”这个念头突然在她大脑中闪过，点燃了她内心的火焰，她凝视着黑夜，一丝不易察觉的微笑绽放在她的唇边，但她马上又甩了甩头，将双手枕在脑后，之前的那个念头，又似乎烟消云散了。天亮前她才脱下衣服，到床上去，但是她却无法入睡。第一缕阳光射进了她的房间……“哦，假如他是真的爱我呢！”她突然喊道，张开怀抱，让阳光照耀着她，再也不感到害羞。她起床，穿上衣服，走下楼去。家里还没有人起床。她走到花园中，那里很安静，满眼绿色，空气清新，小鸟们欢快地歌唱着，花朵们兴奋地仰着头四处张望，但这一切却无法让她感到欢喜。“哦！”她想着，“如果这是真的，我就会比这些花草更愉快，但是这会是真的吗？”她回到了房间去打发时间，她开始换裙子。但是那些裙子都从她手中滑落，她仍衣衫不整地坐在梳妆镜前，直到佣人叫她下去喝早茶。她走下楼去，母亲注意到她脸色苍白，但只是说道：“你今天很有趣啊，”上下打量着她后，又继续说道，“这套裙子真的很适合你啊，如果想让别人欣赏你，你就应该常常穿着它。”埃琳娜什么都没说，在一个角落里坐下。这个时候，钟敲响了九点钟，距离十一点只有两个小时了。埃琳娜尝试去看书，然后去刺绣，然后又拿起书本，接着她强迫自己在小道上来回走了一百遍；再然后，她耐心地注视着安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜摆牌阵……时而看看钟，还没到十点。舒宾走进了客厅。她想与他交谈，来请求他的原谅，但她自己也不知道她哪里做错了……她说的每一句话都并没有让她感到为难，但却让她自己产生了一种诧异的感觉。舒宾向她弯下腰。她就觉得那是在愚弄她，她的眼前浮现的是一张悲伤而怜悯的脸……她对着这张脸微笑，舒宾也笑了，没有说一句话就安静地走了。她打算挽留他，但却想不起来该怎样称呼他。最后终于到十一点。于是她开始等待，等待，而且竖起耳朵听着。她现在做不了任何别的事，连思考都停止了。她的心又一次躁动，跳得越来越快，令人奇怪的是，时间转瞬即逝。一刻钟过去了，半小时过去了，像埃琳娜想的那样，又几分钟过去了，当她突然站起来时，时钟敲响了，不是十二点，而是下午一点。“他没有来，他没有告别就走了。”这个念头令血液一下子涌进她的大脑里。她觉得自己无法呼吸，仿佛下一刻就要哭出来似的。她冲到自己的房间，躺在床上双手掩面。
CHAPTER I: Slowly passed that day for Elena; still more slowly dragged on the long, long night.Elena sat on her bed, her arms clasping her knees, and her head laid on them; then she walked to the window, pressed her burning forehead against the cold glass, and thought and thought, going over and over the same thoughts till she was exhausted.Her heart seemed turned to stone, she did not feel it, but the veins in her head throbbed painfully, her hair stifled her, and her lips were dry.‘He will come… he did not say good-bye to mamma… he will not deceive me…Can Andrei Petrovitch have been right?It cannot be…He didn’t promise to come in words…Can I have parted from him for ever—?’ Those were the thoughts that never left her, literally never left her; they did not come and come again; they were for ever turning like a mist moving about in her brain.‘He loves me!’ suddenly flashed through her, setting her whole nature on fire, and she gazed fixedly into the darkness; a secret smile parted her lips, seen by none, but she quickly shook her head, and clasped her hands behind her neck, and again her former thought hung like a mist about her.Before morning she undressed and went to bed, but she could not sleep.The first fiery ray of sunlight fell upon her room…‘Oh, if he loves me!’ she cried suddenly, and unabashed by the light shining on her, she opened wide her arms…She got up, dressed, and went down.No one in the house was awake yet.She went into the garden, but in the garden it was peaceful, green, and fresh; the birds chirped so confidingly, and the flowers peeped out so gaily that she could not bear it.‘Oh!’ she thought, ‘if it is true, no blade of grass is happy as I. But is it true?’She went back to her room and, to kill time, she began changing her dress.But everything slipped out of her hands, and she was still sitting half-dressed before her looking-glass when she was summoned to morning tea.She went down; her mother noticed her pallor, but only said: ‘How interesting you are to-day,’ and taking her in in a glance, she added: ‘How well that dress suits you; you should always put it on when you want to make an impression on any one.’Elena made no reply, and sat down in a corner.Meanwhile it struck nine o’ clock; there were only two hours now till eleven.Elena tried to read, then to sew, then to read again, then she vowed to herself to walk a hundred times up and down one alley, and paced it a hundred times; then for a long time she watched Anna Vassilyevna laying out the cards for patience… and looked at the clock; it was not yet ten.Shubin came into the drawing-room.She tried to talk to him, and begged his pardon, what for she did not know herself….Every word she uttered did not cost her effort exactly, but roused a kind of amazement in herself.Shubin bent over her.She expected ridicule, raised her eyes, and saw before her a sorrowful and sympathetic face….She smiled at this face.Shubin, too, smiled at her without speaking, and gently left her.She tried to keep him, but could not at once remember what to call him.At last it struck eleven.Then she began to wait, to wait, and to listen.She could do nothing now; she ceased even to think.Her heart was stirred into life again, and began beating louder and louder, and strange, to say, the time seemed flying by.A quarter of an hour passed, then half an hour; a few minutes more, as Elena thought, had passed, when suddenly she started; the clock had struck not twelve, but one.‘He is not coming; he is going away without saying good-bye.’… The blood rushed to her head with this thought.She felt that she was gasping for breath, that she was on the point of sobbing….She ran to her own room, and fell with her face in her clasped hands on to the bed.

第一章: 整整半个小时她一动不动，眼泪透过手指缝隙流到了枕头上。突然，她坐了起来，一个奇怪的念头划过她的大脑，她的脸色变了，湿润的眼睛也干了，开始发出光芒，眉头紧锁，嘴唇也绷紧了。又半个小时过去了。埃琳娜，最后一次竖起耳朵聆听，那个熟悉的声音会不会再次响起？她站起来，戴上帽子和手套，将披肩围在肩膀上，无声地走出了房间，她快速地走在通往别尔谢涅夫公寓的路上。
CHAPTER I: For half an hour she lay motionless; the tears flowed through her fingers on to the pillow.Suddenly she raised herself and sat up, something strange was passing in her, her face changed, her wet eyes grew dry and shining, her brows were bent and her lips compressed.Another half-hour passed.Elena, for the last time, strained her ears to listen: was not that the familiar voice floating up to her?She got up, put on her hat and gloves, threw a cape over her shoulders, and, slipping unnoticed out of the house, she went with swift steps along the road leading to Bersenyev’s lodging.

第一章: 第十八章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XVIII

第一章: 埃琳娜埋头走着，眼睛直直地盯着前方的路。她什么都不怕，什么都不在乎，只是想再见因萨罗夫一面。她继续走着，没有注意到太阳早已躲进厚厚的乌云后面，不见了；风在树林里咆哮着，将她的连衣裙吹来吹去；尘土猛地被吹起，像云团一般在路上飞来飞去……她甚至都没有注意到天上下起了大滴大滴的雨。但是，雨点越下越大，越下越密，还伴有一道道闪电和一声声雷鸣。埃琳娜静静地站着，看着四周……幸运的是，在一口已经干涸的水井旁有一座年久失修的小教堂，离她遭遇暴雨的地点不远。她跑过去，躲到低矮的屋檐下。大雨如注，天空也完全被乌云所笼罩。埃琳娜注视着如注的雨水，感到无比绝望。想和因萨罗夫见一面的最后心愿越来越渺茫。一个身材矮小、要饭的老太太走进小教堂，抖了抖身上的雨水，行了个礼说：“避避雨吧，好姑娘。”她一边呻吟、叹息，一边坐在了水井旁边的一块岩石上。埃琳娜把一只手伸进口袋里。老太太注意到了这个动作，她那曾经美丽现在却颜色蜡黄、皱纹满面的脸庞上突然有了一道光。“谢谢你了，好心的姑娘。”她开口说道。埃琳娜口袋里刚好没有钱包，但是老太太仍然伸着一只手。
CHAPTER I: Elena walked with her head bent and her eyes fixed straight before her.She feared nothing, she considered nothing; she wanted to see Insarov once more.She went on, not noticing that the sun had long ago disappeared behind heavy black clouds, that the wind was roaring by gusts in the trees and blowing her dress about her, that the dust had suddenly risen and was flying in a cloud along the road….Large drops of rain were falling, she did not even notice it; but it fell faster and heavier, there were flashes of lightning and peals of thunder.Elena stood still looking round….Fortunately for her, there was a little old broken-down chapel that had been built over a disused well not far from the place where she was overtaken by the storm.She ran to it and got under the low roof.The rain fell in torrents; the sky was completely overcast.In dumb despair Elena stared at the thick network of fast-falling drops.Her last hope of getting a sight of Insarov was vanishing.A little old beggar-woman came into the chapel, shook herself, said with a curtsy: ‘Out of the rain, good lady,’ and with many sighs and groans sat down on a ledge near the well.Elena put her hand into her pocket; the old woman noticed this action and a light came into her face, yellow and wrinkled now, though once handsome.‘Thank you, dear gracious lady,’ she was beginning.There happened to be no purse in Elena’s pocket, but the old woman was still holding out her hand.

第一章: “我没有带钱，老奶奶，”埃琳娜说，“但是，请您拿着这个吧，它会有用的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I have no money, grannie,’ said Elena, ‘but here, take this, it will be of use for something.’

第一章: 她把自己的手帕给了老太太。
CHAPTER I: She gave her her handkerchief.

第一章: “哦，可爱的姑娘，”要饭的说道，“你给我你的手帕干什么呢？作为我孙女结婚时给她的结婚礼物吗？上帝会奖励你的善良的！”
CHAPTER I: ‘O-oh, my pretty lady,’ said the beggar, ‘what do you give your handkerchief to me for?For a wedding-present to my grandchild when she’s married?God reward you for your goodness!’

第一章: 一阵雷声响起。
CHAPTER I: A peal of thunder was heard.

第一章: “我主耶稣基督。”要饭的老太太默念着，在胸前划了三次十字，“咦，我以前见过你。”她顿了顿说道。“你以耶稣之名给过我施舍的，还记得吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Lord Jesus Christ,’ muttered the beggar-woman, and she crossed herself three times.‘Why, haven’t I seen you before,’ she added after a brief pause.‘Didn’t you give me alms in Christ’s name?’

第一章: 埃琳娜仔细打量了一下这个老太太，然后认出了她。
CHAPTER I: Elena looked more attentively at the old woman and recognised her.

第一章: “没错，老奶奶，”她回答道，“您那时是不是还问过我为什么那么伤心？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, grannie,’ she answered, ‘wasn’t it you asked me why I was so sorrowful?’

第一章: “没错，亲爱的，我问过。我就觉得我认识你。我觉得你还在心痛。你看起来很困扰啊。还有你的手帕，肯定也是被泪水弄湿的。哎，你们这些年轻人都有着同样的伤心事。它确实让人很痛苦。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, darling, yes.I fancied I knew you.And I think you’ve a heart-ache still.You seem in trouble now.Here’s your handkerchief, too, wet from tears to be sure.Oh, you young people, you all have the same sorrow, a terrible woe it is!’

第一章: “什么样的伤心事，老奶奶？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What sorrow, grannie?’

第一章: “哎，我的好姑娘，你可骗不了像我这么大岁数的老太太。我知道你为什么而痛苦，大多数人都会经历这种痛苦。当然了，亲爱的，我也曾年轻过。我也曾经遇到过这样的麻烦。没错。看在你对我如此善意的份儿上，我告诉你一些事吧：你已经赢得了一个好男人的心，这爱很深，你只依恋他一个，宁死也要跟着他。如果成了，那就成了——如果不成，那也是上帝的旨意。没错。你为什么疑惑地看着我呢？我是个算命的。现在，我将把你的伤悲和你的手帕一起带走。我会把它们一起带走，一切都结束了。你看，雨下小了，你再等一下吧。这也不是我第一次淋雨了。记住，亲爱的，你有过悲伤，但悲伤已经飞走了，你的记忆里不再有悲伤了。仁慈的上帝啊，请保佑我们吧！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah, my good young lady, you can’t deceive an old woman like me.I know what your heart is heavy over; your sorrow’s not an uncommon one.Sure, I have been young too, darling.I have been through that trouble too.Yes.And I’ll tell you something, for your goodness to me; you’ve won a good man, not a light of love, you cling to him alone; cling to him stronger than death.If it comes off, it comes off,—if not, it’s in God’s hands.Yes.Why are you wondering at me?I’m a fortune-teller.There, I’ll carry away your sorrow with your handkerchief.I’ll carry it away, and it’s over.See the rain’s less; you wait a little longer.It’s not the first time I’ve been wet.Remember, darling; you had a sorrow, the sorrow has flown, and there’s no memory of it.Good Lord, have mercy on us!’

第一章: 要饭的老太太从井边站起来，离开小教堂，步履蹒跚地向前走着。埃琳娜充满迷惑地看着她的背影。“这是什么意思呢？”她不自觉地嘟囔着。
CHAPTER I: The beggar-woman got up from the edge of the well, went out of the chapel, and stole off on her way.Elena stared after her in bewilderment.‘What does this mean?’ she murmured involuntarily.

第一章: 雨越下越小，有那么一瞬，太阳也向外瞥了几眼。埃琳娜正准备从避雨的地方走出去……突然，就在离小教堂十步之遥的地方，她看见了因萨罗夫。他披着斗篷，沿着埃琳娜来时的路走着，看起来正在往家里赶。
CHAPTER I: The rain grew less and less, the sun peeped out for an instant.Elena was just preparing to leave her shelter….Suddenly, ten paces from the chapel, she saw Insarov.Wrapt in a cloak he was walking along the very road by which Elena had come; he seemed to be hurrying home.

第一章: 她抓紧台阶的旧栏杆作为支撑，想要叫住他，却叫不出声……因萨罗夫已经埋着头走过去了。
CHAPTER I: She clasped the old rail of the steps for support, and tried to call to him, but her voice failed her…Insarov had already passed by without raising his head.

第一章: “德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇！”她最后还是叫了一声。
CHAPTER I: ‘Dmitri Nikanorovitch!’ she said at last.

第一章: 因萨罗夫猛地停住脚步，扭头一看……一开始他没有认出是埃琳娜，但是他立刻向她走了过来。“你！你在这里！”他叫道。
CHAPTER I: Insarov stopped abruptly, looked round….For the first minute he did not know Elena, but he went up to her at once.‘You! you here!’ he cried.

第一章: 她一声不吭地走回了小教堂。因萨罗夫跟着她。“你在这里？”他重复道。
CHAPTER I: She walked back in silence into the chapel.Insarov followed Elena.‘You here?’ he repeated.

第一章: 她依然未吭一声，只是用一种陌生、缓慢却深情的眼光注视着他。他闭上了眼睛。
CHAPTER I: She was still silent, and only gazed upon him with a strange, slow, tender look.He dropped his eyes.

第一章: “你从我家过来？”她问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘You have come from our house?’ she asked.

第一章: “不……不是从你家里。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No… not from your house.’

第一章: “不是？”埃琳娜重复着，她试图微笑，“你就是这样履行诺言的吗？我从早上开始就在等你了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No?’ repeated Elena, and she tried to smile.‘Is that how you keep your promises?I have been expecting you ever since the morning.’

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，你应该没有忘记，我昨天并没有许下任何诺言。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I made no promise yesterday, if you remember, Elena Nikolaevna.’

第一章: 埃琳娜又微微一笑，用手擦了一把脸。她的面孔和手都那么苍白。
CHAPTER I: Again Elena faintly smiled, and she passed her hand over her face.Both face and hands were very white.

第一章: “那么，你是打算不跟我们说一声再见就离开？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You meant, then, to go away without saying good-bye to us?’

第一章: “是的。”因萨罗夫用确定而厚重的声音回答道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes,’ replied Insarov in a surly, thick voice.

第一章: “什么？在我们认识、聊天，在所有的一切发生之后……如果不是我在这里偶然碰到你，”（埃琳娜的声音开始颤抖，她停了一小会儿，）“你就打算这样离开，甚至不最后一次握握手，你就真的一点儿都不在乎？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What?After our friendship, after the talks, after everything….Then if I had not met you here by chance.’ (Elena’s voice began to break, and she paused an instant)… ‘you would have gone away like that, without even shaking hands for the last time, and you would not have cared?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫掉过头去：“埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，请不要这样说。我本来就很难过了。相信我，我费了很大的勇气才下了这个决定。如果你知道——”
CHAPTER I: Insarov turned away.‘Elena Nikolaevnas don’t talk like that, please.I’m not over happy as it is.Believe me, my decision has cost me great effort.If you knew—’

第一章: “我不想知道，”埃琳娜沮丧地打断了他，“你为什么要走……看来这是很必要的。看来我们必须要分开了。你是不会毫无原因让你的朋友伤心的。但是，有朋友是这样分别的吗？我们是朋友，对吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t want to know,’ Elena interposed with dismay, ‘why you are going….It seems it’s necessary.It seems we must part.You would not wound your friends without good reason.But, can friends part like this?And we are friends, aren’t we?’

第一章: “不是。”因萨罗夫说。
CHAPTER I: ‘No,’ said Insarov.

第一章: “什么？”埃琳娜轻轻说道。她的脸颊上泛起了一层淡淡的红晕。
CHAPTER I: ‘What?’ murmured Elena.Her cheeks were overspread with a faint flush.

第一章: “这正是我要离开的原因——因为我们不是朋友。不要逼我说些我不愿意说，也绝不会说的话。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That’s just why I am going away—because we are not friends.Don’t force me into saying what I don’t want to say, and what I won’t say.’

第一章: “你曾经跟我无话不谈。”埃琳娜有些怪罪地说，“你还记得吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You used to be so open with me,’ said Elena rather reproachfully.‘Do you remember?’

第一章: “我过去能对你敞开心胸，因为那时我没有什么需要隐瞒的，但是，现在——”
CHAPTER I: ‘I used to be able to be open, then I had nothing to conceal; but now—’

第一章: “但是现在？”埃琳娜问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘But now?’ queried Elena.

第一章: “但是现在……现在我必须要走了。再见。”
CHAPTER I: ‘But now… now I must go away.Goodbye.’

第一章: 如果在那一瞬间因萨罗夫抬起头看埃琳娜的话，他会发现，自己越是烦恼、痛苦，埃琳娜的脸上就越发开心，但是他一直都盯着地板。
CHAPTER I: If, at that instant, Insarov had lifted his eyes to Elena, he would have seen that her face grew brighter and brighter as he frowned and looked gloomy; but he kept his eyes obstinately fixed on the ground.

第一章: “好吧，那再见吧，德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇。”她说道，“但是，既然我们遇见了，现在至少把你的手递给我吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, good-bye, Dmitri Nikanorovitch,’ she began.‘But at least, since we have met, give me your hand now.’

第一章: 因萨罗夫伸出手。“不，就连这我也不能做。”他说着，再次掉过头去。
CHAPTER I: Insarov was stretching out his hand.‘No, I can’t even do that,’ he said, and turned away again.

第一章: “你做不到？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You can’t?’

第一章: “是的，我不能。再见吧。”他走到小教堂的入口。
CHAPTER I: ‘No, I can’t.Good-bye.’And he moved away to the entrance of the chapel.

第一章: “请稍等片刻。”埃琳娜说，“你看起来很怕我。但是我比你勇敢。”她说道，全身突然轻轻颤抖了起来，“我能告诉你……我可以吗？你怎么会发现我在这里的？你知道我要去哪里吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Wait a little longer,’ said Elena.‘You seem afraid of me.But I am braver than you,’ she added, a faint tremor passing suddenly over her whole body.‘I can tell you… shall I?…how it was you found me here?Do you know where I was going?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫困惑地看着埃琳娜。
CHAPTER I: Insarov looked in bewilderment at Elena,

第一章: “我是去找你的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I was going to you.’

第一章: “找我？”
CHAPTER I: ‘To me?’

第一章: 埃琳娜低下头。“您这是在逼我说我爱你吗？”她小声说道，“那，我已经说了。”
CHAPTER I: Elena hid her face.‘You mean to force me to say that I love you,’ she whispered.‘There, I have said it.’

第一章: “埃琳娜！”因萨罗夫喊道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena!’ cried Insarov.

第一章: 她握着他的手，看着他，投入了他的怀中。
CHAPTER I: She took his hands, looked at him, and fell on his breast.

第一章: 他紧紧地抱着她，一句话也说不出来。他不需要告诉她他也爱着她。仅仅从那一声呼喊，从他整个人突然间的改变，从她紧紧贴着的起伏的胸膛，从他深情地抚摸着她长发的指尖，埃琳娜可以感受到，他也是爱着她的。他没有说话，她不需要任何言语。“他就在这里，他爱着我……那还需要什么呢？”一种快乐的宁静充斥着她的心。那是一种暴风雨后驶入港湾、到达彼岸的宁静，一种天国般的、能让死亡都变得重大、美丽的宁静。她什么都不想要，因为她什么都有了。“啊！我的兄弟，我的朋友，我最亲爱的人！”她轻轻说道。她不知道是谁的心这么幸福地跳跃着，在她的胸前融化着，是他的还是自己的呢？
CHAPTER I: He held her close to him, and said nothing.There was no need for him to tell her he loved her.From that cry alone, from the instant transformation of the whole man, from the heaving of the breast to which she clung so confidingly, from the touch of his finger tips in her hair, Elena could feel that she was loved.He did not speak, and she needed no words.‘He is here, he loves me… what need of more?’The peace of perfect bliss, the peace of the harbour reached after storm, of the end attained, that heavenly peace which gives significance and beauty even to death, filled her with its divine flood.She desired nothing, for she had gained all.‘O my brother, my friend, my dear one!’ her lips were whispering, while she did not know whose was this heart, his or her own, which beat so blissfully, and melted against her bosom.

第一章: 他静静地站在那里，紧紧地拥抱着这个已经托付给他的年轻生命。他感受到自己怀中这个前所未有的、无比珍贵的负担。一种温柔的激情、一种无法言喻的感激之情已经彻底征服了他那颗无法撼动的心。此刻他的眼角流下了莫名的泪水。
CHAPTER I: He stood motionless, folding in his strong embrace the young life surrendered to him; he felt against his heart this new, infinitely precious burden; a passion of tenderness, of gratitude unutterable, was crumbling his hard will to dust, and tears unknown till now stood in his eyes.

第一章: 她没有流泪，她只是不停地重复：“我的朋友，我的兄弟！”
CHAPTER I: She did not weep; she could only repeat, ‘O my friend, my brother!’

第一章: “你会跟我一起浪迹天涯吗？”过了一会儿，他问她，依然把她紧紧地抱在自己的怀里。
CHAPTER I: ’So you will follow me everywhere?’ he said to her, a quarter of an hour later, still enfolding her and keeping her close to him in his arms.

第一章: “我会陪你到天涯海角。你在哪里，我就在哪里。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Everywhere, to the ends of the earth.Where you are, I will be.’

第一章: “不过，你不要欺骗自己，你知道的，你的父母是不会让我们结婚的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘And you are not deceiving yourself, you know your parents will never consent to our marriage?’

第一章: “我清楚地知道我没有欺骗自己。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t deceive myself; I know that.’

第一章: “你知道我很穷——几乎就是一个乞丐。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You know that I’m poor—almost a beggar.’

第一章: “我知道。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I know.’

第一章: “我不是俄国人，我不会长久地住在俄国，所以，你将不得不失去所有与你的祖国、人民的联系。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That I’m not a Russian, that it won’t be my fate to live in Russia, that you will have to break all your ties with your country, with your people.’

第一章: “我知道，我知道。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I know, I know.’

第一章: “你知道吗？我已经把自己奉献给了一个苦难重重、不求回报的事业，我……我们可能会面对的不仅仅是危险，还有困苦的生活，还会受人欺侮，也许——”
CHAPTER I: ‘Do you know, too, that I have given myself up to a difficult, thankless cause, that I… that we shall have to expose ourselves not to dangers only, but to privation, humiliation, perhaps—’

第一章: “我知道，这些我都知道——我爱你——”
CHAPTER I: ‘I know, I know all—I love you—’

第一章: “你要抛弃过去所有的生活习惯，一个人生活在陌生的人群中，可能还要被迫去做工——”
CHAPTER I: ‘That you will have to give up all you are accustomed to, that out there alone among strangers, you will be forced perhaps to work—’

第一章: 她把手放在他的嘴唇上。“我爱你，我最亲爱的。”
CHAPTER I: She laid her hand on his lips.‘I love you, my dear one.’

第一章: 他开始激烈地亲吻她那修长、红润的手。埃琳娜没有把手从他的嘴边拿开。她带着一种天真的愉悦，微笑着，好奇地看着他先亲吻她的手掌、然后是手指……
CHAPTER I: He began hotly kissing her slender, rosy hand.Elena did not draw it away from his lips, and with a kind of childish delight, with smiling curiosity, watched how he covered with kisses, first the palm, then the fingers….

第一章: 突然，她的脸刷地一下变得通红，她把头埋进了他的胸膛。
CHAPTER I: All at once she blushed and hid her face upon his breast.

第一章: 他温柔地抬起她的头，久久地凝视着她的眼睛。“那么好吧，欢迎你来到我的身边，我的妻子，让上帝和众人为我们见证！”
CHAPTER I: He lifted her head tenderly and looked steadily into her eyes.‘Welcome, then, my wife, before God and men!’

第一章: 第十九章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XIX

第一章: 一个小时后，埃琳娜一手拿着帽子，另一只手拿着披肩，缓步走入了别墅的客厅。她的头发稍显凌乱，两颊上还留着小小的、鲜红的吻痕，嘴角依然挂着微笑。她的眼睛几乎闭上，被眼帘遮去了一半，也带着笑意。她疲倦得几乎迈不开步子，但是这种疲倦让她很开心，事实上，所有的一切都让她很开心。在她看来，所有的一切都那么甜蜜和亲切。尤瓦·伊万诺维奇坐在窗边。她走向他，把一只手放在了他的肩膀上，微微伸展，看似不自觉地笑了起来。
CHAPTER I: An hour later, Elena, with her hat in one hand, her cape in the other, walked slowly into the drawing-room of the villa.Her hair was in slight disorder; on each cheek was to be seen a small bright spot of colour, the smile would not leave her lips, her eyes were nearly shutting and half hidden under the lids; they, too, were smiling.She could scarcely move for weariness, and this weariness was pleasant to her; everything, indeed, was pleasant to her.Everything seemed sweet and friendly to her.Uvar Ivanovitch was sitting at the window; she went up to him, laid her hand on his shoulder, stretched a little, and involuntarily, as it seemed, she laughed.

第一章: “笑什么呢？”他有些惊讶地问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What is it?’ he inquired, astonished.

第一章: 她不知道该说什么。她有种想要亲吻尤瓦·伊万诺维奇的冲动。
CHAPTER I: She did not know what to say.She felt inclined to kiss Uvar Ivanovitch.

第一章: 终于，她解释说：“那人溅了一身的水！”
CHAPTER I: ‘How he splashed!’ she explained at last.

第一章: 尤瓦·伊万诺维奇却纹丝不动，仍然惊讶地看着埃琳娜。她把她的帽子和披肩放在他身上。
CHAPTER I: But Uvar Ivanovitch did not stir a muscle, and continued to look with amazement at Elena.She dropped her hat and cape on to him.

第一章: 她说：“亲爱的尤瓦·伊万诺维奇，我现在又累又困。”然后再次笑起来，蜷缩进他旁边一张低矮的椅子里。
CHAPTER I: ‘Dear Uvar Ivanovitch,’ she said, ‘I am sleepy and tired,’ and again she laughed and sank into a low chair near him.

第一章: “嗯，”尤瓦·伊万诺维奇一边晃着手指，一边嘟囔着说，“那你应该——对——”
CHAPTER I: ‘H’m,’ grunted Uvar Ivanovitch, flourishing his fingers, ‘then you ought—yes—’

第一章: 埃琳娜看了看自己的周围，想道：“这一切很快就要不属于我了……不可思议的是——我一点儿都不害怕、不迟疑、也不后悔……不，我对不起母亲。”然后，那个小教堂又浮现在她的脑海中，自己的声音再次回荡其中，她感觉被他的双臂拥抱着。她快乐地感到一丝不安，但这不安被舒适的幸福感给压了下去。那个要饭的老太太又浮现在她的脑海里。“她的确带走了我的悲伤。”她想着，“哦，我真的很快乐！这是多么不应该啊！太迅速了！”如果她稍微放纵自己的情绪的话，她将会难以遏止地流下甜蜜的泪水。她只能用欢笑来抑制这泪水。任何一种表情对她来说都是最舒适安逸的。她感觉自己就像躺在摇篮中，缓缓入睡。她的所有动作都那么轻柔和缓慢。她的狼狈，她的急躁都去了哪里？卓娅走了进来，埃琳娜觉得自己从未看到过比这更迷人的脸孔；安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜也走了进来，埃琳娜心中感到一阵剧痛，但她满怀柔情地拥抱了母亲，并且亲吻了母亲那已经有些许白发的前额！然后，她走进自己的房间。那里的一切都在向她微笑！她带着一种害羞的胜利和宁静的心情坐到了自己的床上——仅三个小时之前，她就是坐在这张床上度过了那段苦涩的时光。“尽管，在那时，我就知道他爱着我，”她思索着，“尽管之前……啊，不！这是错误的。你是我的妻子。”她嘴中轻轻地念道，用双手蒙着脸，趴在膝盖上。
CHAPTER I: Elena was looking round her and thinking, ‘From all this I soon must part… and strange—I have no dread, no doubt, no regret….No, I am sorry for mamma.’Then the little chapel rose again before her mind, again her voice was echoing in it, and she felt his arms about her.Joyously, though faintly, her heart fluttered; weighed down by the languor of happiness.The old beggar-woman recurred to her mind.’She did really bear away my sorrow,‘ she thought.’Oh, how happy I am!how undeservedly!how soon!‘If she had let herself go in the least she would have melted into sweet, endless tears.She could only restrain them by laughing.Whatever attitude she fell into seemed to her the easiest, most comfortable possible; she felt as if she were being rocked to sleep.All her movements were slow and soft; what had become of her awkwardness, her haste?Zoya came in; Elena decided that she had never seen a more charming little face; Anna Vassilyevna came in; Elena felt a pang—but with what tenderness she embraced her mother and kissed her on the forehead near the hair, already slightly grey!Then she went away to her own room; how everything smiled upon her there!With what a sense of shamefaced triumph and tranquillity she sat down on her bed—the very bed on which, only three hours ago, she had spent such bitter moments!‘And yet, even then, I knew he loved me,’ she thought, ‘even before…Ah, no!it’s a sin.You are my wife,’ she whispered, hiding her face in her hands and falling on her knees.

第一章: 傍晚时分，她陷入了更深的思索。她一想到无法立刻与因萨罗夫相见，一种悲伤的情绪便向她袭来。要是继续留在别尔谢涅夫那里，他就会引起别人的怀疑，所以他和埃琳娜商量了解决办法。因萨罗夫先回莫斯科，然后在秋天前来看她们两次；她则许诺给他写信，如果条件允许，在孔佐沃附近的某个地方安排与他见一面。她下楼到客厅喝茶，发现全家人和舒宾都在。她一出现，舒宾就直勾勾地仔细打量她。她想同过去一样亲切地跟他聊聊，但又害怕自己在他敏锐的洞察力面前露出破绽。她敢肯定，这两个星期他都没有惹过她是有原因的。不一会儿，别尔谢涅夫到了。他代表因萨罗夫问候了安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜，同时传达了因萨罗夫回莫斯科前没有来向她告别的歉意。这是那天因萨罗夫的名字第一次在埃琳娜面前提起。她觉得自己的脸红了起来。她觉得自己应当为这样一个好朋友的突然离开而表示遗憾，但又无法逼迫自己表现得那么虚伪，于是她继续老老实实、一声不吭地坐着，然而安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜倒是叹了口气，表示惋惜。埃琳娜尽量站在别尔谢涅夫的身边。她并不害怕他，虽然他甚至知道她的一些秘密。她觉得在他的身旁似乎能躲开舒宾一直注视的目光——没有任何嘲弄却充满了关怀。当晚，别尔谢涅夫的心里也感到惶惑，他原以为埃琳娜会更加难过。她很高兴别尔谢涅夫和舒宾就艺术而开始了一场辩论。她走到一旁，听到他们的声音仿佛是从梦中传来的一样。渐渐的，不光是他们，整个房间、她周围的一切都像是在梦中——所有这一切：桌上的茶壶、尤瓦·伊万诺维奇的短背心、卓娅光亮的手指甲、墙上康斯坦丁·帕夫洛维奇大公的油画肖像，全部都在慢慢淡化，仿佛笼罩上了一层薄雾，一切都在逐渐消失。只留下她为他们所感到的悲哀。“他们是为什么而活着呢？”她思索着。
CHAPTER I: Towards the evening, she grew more thoughtful.Sadness came upon her at the thought that she would not soon see Insarov.He could not without awakening suspicion remain at Bersenyev’s, and so this was what he and Elena had resolved on.Insarov was to return to Moscow and to come over to visit them twice before the autumn; on her side she promised to write him letters, and, if it were possible, to arrange a meeting with him somewhere near Kuntsov.She went down to the drawing-room to tea, and found there all the household and Shubin, who looked at her sharply directly she came in; she tried to talk to him in a friendly way as of old, but she dreaded his penetration, she was afraid of herself.She felt sure that there was good reason for his having left her alone for more than a fortnight.Soon Bersenyev arrived, and gave Insarov’s respects to Anna Vassilyevna with an apology for having gone back to Moscow without calling to take leave of her.Insarov’s name was for the first time during the day pronounced before Elena.She felt that she reddened; she realised at the same time that she ought to express regret at the sudden departure of such a pleasant acquaintance; but she could not force herself to hypocrisy, and continued to sit without stirring or speaking, while Anna Vassilyevna sighed and lamented.Elena tried to keep near Bersenyev; she was not afraid of him, though he even knew part of her secret; she was safe under his wing from Shubin, who still persisted in staring at her—not mockingly but attentively.Bersenyev, too, was thrown into perplexity during the evening: he had expected to see Elena more gloomy.Happily for her, an argument sprang up about art between him and Shubin; she moved apart and heard their voices as it were through a dream.By degrees, not only they, but the whole room, everything surrounding her, seemed like a dream—everything: the samovar on the table, and Uvar Ivanovitch’s short waistcoat, and Zoya’s polished finger-nails, and the portrait in oils of the Grand Duke Constantine Pavlovitch on the wall; everything retreated, everything was wrapped in mist, everything ceased to exist.Only she felt sorry for them all.‘What are they living for?’ she thought.

第一章: “你要睡着了么，列诺奇卡？”她母亲问道。她没有听到母亲的询问。
CHAPTER I: ‘Are you sleepy, Lenotchka?’ her mother asked her.She did not hear the question.

第一章: “你是说这是一种半实半虚的影射？”舒宾激烈的言辞突然唤回了埃琳娜的注意力。“其实，”他继续说道，“它的作用就在这里。完全明显的影射让人无法接受——这太粗鲁了——而虚幻的影射又无法提起别人的兴趣——这很愚蠢；但半实半虚的影射就能让人又生气又烦躁。例如，如果我说埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜喜欢上了我们中的一个，这属于哪一种影射呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘A half untrue insinuation, do you say?’These words, sharply uttered by Shubin, suddenly awakened Elena’s attention.‘Why,’ he continued, ‘the whole sting lies in that.A true insinuation makes one wretched—that’s unchristian—and to an untrue insinuation a man is indifferent—that’s stupid, but at a half true one he feels vexed and impatient.For instance, if I say that Elena Nikolaevna is in love with one of us, what sort of insinuation would that be, eh?’

第一章: “啊，保罗先生，”埃琳娜说，“我应该对您表示生气，不过我实在是做不到。我太累了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah, Monsieur Paul,’ said Elena, ‘I should like to show myself vexed, but really I can’t.I am so tired.’

第一章: “你怎么不去休息呢？”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜说道。她自己一到晚上就总觉得昏昏欲睡，因此喜欢催促别人去睡觉。“和我说晚安，上帝会保佑你睡个好觉的，安德烈·彼得罗维奇先生不会生你的气。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why don’t you go to bed?’ observed Anna Vassilyevna, who was always drowsy in the evening herself, and consequently always eager to send the others to bed.‘Say good-night to me, and go in God’s name; Andrei Petrovitch will excuse you.’

第一章: 埃琳娜亲吻了她的母亲，向大家欠了欠身子就离开了。舒宾陪着她一直走到门口。“埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”他在门口悄悄跟她说道，“虽然你伤害了保罗先生，你毫不留情地从他身上踩过，但是保罗先生依然祝福你和你那双小脚，祝福你小脚上穿的拖鞋和那双小拖鞋的鞋底。”
CHAPTER I: Elena kissed her mother, bowed to all and went away.Shubin accompanied her to the door.‘Elena Nikolaevna,’ he whispered to her in the doorway, ‘you trample on Monsieur Paul, you mercilessly walk over him, but Monsieur Paul blesses you and your little feet, and the slippers on your little feet, and the soles of your little slippers.’

第一章: 埃琳娜耸了耸肩，不情愿地把手伸向了他——不是因萨罗夫亲吻过的那一只——然后走进了自己的房间，马上脱掉衣服，钻进被子里，进入了梦乡。她睡得很沉、很安详，就连小孩子也很少有睡得这么香甜的——只有疾病初愈的小孩才睡得这么香甜，而她的妈妈则守护在摇篮旁边，注视着她，聆听着她的呼吸。
CHAPTER I: Elena shrugged her shoulders, reluctantly held out her hand to him—not the one Insarov had kissed—and going up to her room, at once undressed, got into bed, and fell asleep.She slept a deep, unstirring sleep, as even children rarely sleep—the sleep of a child convalescent after sickness, when its mother sits near its cradle and watches it, and listens to its breathing.

第一章: 第二十章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XX

第一章: “去我屋里呆一会儿吧，”别尔谢涅夫刚向安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜道过别，舒宾就对他说道，“我有些东西想给你看看。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Come to my room for a minute,’ Shubin said to Bersenyev, directly the latter had taken leave of Anna Vassilyevna: ‘I have something to show you.’

第一章: 他随舒宾来到他的阁楼里。他惊讶地看到许多雕塑作品、小雕像、半身像被湿布包裹着摆放在房间的各个角落。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev followed him to his attic.He was surprised to see a number of studies, statuettes, and busts, covered with damp cloths, set about in all the corners of the room.

第一章: “哇，看来你一直在潜心工作。”他对舒宾说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Well I see you have been at work in earnest,’ he observed to Shubin.

第一章: “一个人总要有点儿事做。”舒宾回答道，“如果一件事做不成，一定要试试其他的。然而，正如一个真正的科西嘉人，相比起纯粹的艺术，我更专注于复仇。颤抖吧，彼桑齐亚！”
CHAPTER I: ‘One must do something,’ he answered.‘If one thing doesn’t do, one must try another.However, like a true Corsican, I am more concerned with revenge than with pure art.Trema, Bisanzia!’

第一章: “我不知道你在说什么。”别尔谢涅夫说。
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t understand you,’ said Bersenyev.

第一章: “那好，请稍等。朝这边看，我亲爱的朋友和恩人，这是我的头号仇人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, wait a minute.Deign to look this way, gracious friend and benefactor, my vengeance number one.’

第一章: 舒宾揭开了一座雕像，然后别尔谢涅夫看到了一尊惟妙惟肖的因萨罗夫的半身雕像。舒宾把因萨罗夫的面部特征拿捏得细致入微，同时赋予了他很精妙的表情：诚实、慷慨、勇敢。
CHAPTER I: Shubin uncovered one figure, and Bersenyev saw a capital bust of Insarov, an excellent likeness.The features of the face had been correctly caught by Shubin to the minutest detail, and he had given him a fine expression, honest, generous, and bold.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫看后十分欢喜。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev went into raptures over it.

第一章: “太精妙了！”他大声地说，“恭喜你。你一定要把它拿去参展！为什么要把这个优秀的作品称作你的仇人呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘That’s simply exquisite!’ he cried.‘I congratulate you.You must send it to the exhibition!Why do you call that magnificent work your vengeance?’

第一章: “那是因为，先生，我要把这个你口中的优秀的作品在埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜命名日的那天送给她。你知道这象征着什么吗？我们都没有瞎，我们都知道周围发生了什么，但是我们是绅士，我亲爱的先生，因此我们要像一个绅士那样来进行报复……但是，看这里，”舒宾接着说，同时掀起盖在另一尊雕像上的布，“根据现代美学的理念，艺术家享有一个令人羡慕的特权，那就是能够把各种丑恶当成是艺术创作的精髓并且在自己的作品中展现出来。我在创作二号作品时，就把仇人看成是一个彻底的无赖，而非绅士。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Because, sir, I intended to offer this magnificent work as you call it to Elena Nikolaevna on her name day.Do you see the allegory?We are not blind, we see what goes on about us, but we are gentlemen, my dear sir, and we take our revenge like gentlemen….But here,’ added Shubin, uncovering another figure, ‘as the artist according to modern aesthetic principles enjoys the enviable privilege of embodying in himself every sort of baseness which he can turn into a gem of creative art, we in the production of this gem, number two, have taken vengeance not as gentlemen, but simply en canaille.’

第一章: 他灵巧地拉下盖布，于是一个有着丹唐风格的、同样是因萨罗夫的小雕像呈现在别尔谢涅夫的眼前。再也无法想象有比这更精明、更刻薄的雕像了。那个年轻的保加利亚人被塑造成一只公羊的形象，后脚蹬地，准备用一对犄角进行冲撞。死板的庄严、挑衅、固执、笨拙、狭隘都呈现在那“母绵羊的配偶”的脸上，而这些表情又的确与因萨罗夫非常相像，这让别尔谢涅夫情不自禁地大笑起来。
CHAPTER I: He deftly drew off the cloth, and displayed to Bersenyev’s eyes a statuette in Dantan’s style, also of Insarov.Anything cleverer and more spiteful could not be imagined.The young Bulgarian was represented as a ram standing on his hind-legs, butting forward with his horns.Dull solemnity and aggressiveness, obstinacy, clumsiness and narrowness were simply printed on the visage of the ‘sire of the woolly flock,’ and yet the likeness to Insarov was so striking that Bersenyev could not help laughing.

第一章: “怎么样？有趣吗？”舒宾说，“你认出这个英雄了么？你建不建议我把它也送去参展呢？这个，我亲爱的朋友，我打算把它在我的命名日送给我自己……阁下请允许我胡闹一次。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Eh?is it amusing?’ said Shubin.‘Do you recognise the hero?Do you advise me to send it too to the exhibition?That, my dear fellow, I intend as a present for myself on my own name day….Your honour will permit me to play the fool.’

第一章: 于是舒宾连跳三次，脚后跟都踢到了屁股。
CHAPTER I: And Shubin gave three little leaps, kicking himself behind with his heels.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫从地上捡起盖布——盖到这尊小雕像上。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev picked up the cloth off the floor—and threw it over the statuette.

第一章: “啊，你实在是很有雅量。”舒宾说，“历史上到底有没有一个这么有雅量的人呢？嗯，随便说说，别介意！“那么，现在，”他继续说着，带着一种忧伤的胜利之情揭开了第三尊有些巨大的雕像，“你将看到的东西会向你展示出你朋友谦逊、敏感的一面。你将会发现他又一次像一个真正的艺术家一样感受到自我批评的必要性和作用。仔细看！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah, you, magnanimous’—began Shubin.‘Who the devil was it in history was so particularly magnanimous?Well, never mind!And now,’ he continued, with melancholy triumph, uncovering a third rather large mass of clay, ‘you shall behold something which will show you the humility and discernment of your friend.You will realise that he, like a true artist again, feels the need and the use of self-castigation.Behold!’

第一章: 盖布被掀开了，别尔涅夫看到了两个头像，它们紧紧靠着，就像长在一起一样……他没有立刻看出这尊雕塑的主人公，但靠近一看，才发现其中一个是安努什卡，另一个是舒宾本人。不过，与其把他们称之为画像，不如称之为讽刺像。安努什卡被塑造成一个健壮丰满的女孩，前额低低的，肥肿的眼皮遮住了眼睛，鼻孔傲慢地朝着天。她那厚厚的嘴唇有一种傲慢的曲线，整个面孔表达出一种肉欲、淡漠和大胆，却不失美好的品性。而舒宾则把自己塑造成了一个削瘦的浪子，两颊内陷，几缕发丝无力地垂在他的脸上，双眼空洞无神，鼻子又尖又薄，跟死人一般。
CHAPTER I: The cloth was lifted and Bersenyev saw two heads, modelled side by side and close as though growing together….He did not at once know what was the subject, but looking closer, he recognised in one of them Annushka, in the other Shubin himself.They were, however, rather caricatures than portraits.Annushka was represented as a handsome fat girl with a low forehead, eyes lost in layers of fat, and a saucily turned-up nose.Her thick lips had an insolent curve; her whole face expressed sensuality, carelessness, and boldness, not without goodnature.Himself Shubin had modelled as a lean emaciated rake, with sunken cheeks, his thin hair hanging in weak wisps about his face, a meaningless expression in his dim eyes, and his nose sharp and thin as a dead man’s.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫厌恶地转过头去。“很不错的一对儿，不是吗，我亲爱的朋友？”舒宾说，“能有幸让你为它命名么？前两尊雕塑的名字我已经想好了。在半身像上可以刻上“决心解放祖国的英雄”。在小雕像上可以刻上“小心，吃香肠的德国佬！”至于这个雕塑么，你觉得叫“艺术家帕维尔·雅克夫利奇·舒宾的未来”如何？这个可以吗？”
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev turned away with disgust.‘A nice pair, aren’t they, my dear fellow?’ said Shubin; ‘won’t you graciously compose a suitable title?For the first two I have already thought of titles.On the bust shall be inscribed: “A hero resolving to liberate his country.”On the statuette: “Look out, sausage-eating Germans!”And for this work what do you think of “The future of the artist Pavel Yakovlitch Shubin?”Will that do?’

第一章: “够了。”别尔谢涅夫说道，“你到底值不值得把时间花在这——”他一时间也找不到一个恰当的词。
CHAPTER I: ‘Leave off,’ replied Bersenyev.‘Was it worth while to waste your time on such a —’ He could not at once fix on a suitable word.

第一章: “你的意思是这是恶心的东西？不，我亲爱的朋友，请原谅我，我认为拿这组作品去参展再合适不过了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Disgusting thing, you mean?No, my dear fellow, excuse me, if anything ought to go to the exhibition, it’s that group.’

第一章: “它让人感觉很不舒服。”别尔谢涅夫又说道，“更何况，它毫无意义可言。你肯定不会把自己的品味降低到这种层次。但不幸的是，我们的艺术家们现在经常会有这样的倾向。你这是在糟蹋你自己。”
CHAPTER I: ‘It’s simply disgusting,’ repeated Bersenyev.‘And besides, it’s nonsense.You have absolutely no such degrading tendencies to which, unhappily, our artists have such a frequent bent.You have simply libelled yourself.’

第一章: “你是这样认为的么？”舒宾有些阴郁地说道，“我没有那些问题，但是如果它们找上我的话，这都得怪一个人。”“你知道吗？”他又说道，眉头揪成一团，一片愁云惨淡，“我最近试着喝酒了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Do you think so?’ said Shubin gloomily.‘I have none of them, and if they come upon me, the fault is all one person’s.Do you know,’ he added, tragically knitting his brows, ‘that I have been trying drinking?’

第一章: “胡闹！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Nonsense?’

第一章: “这是真的，以上帝为证，”舒宾说，然后突然咧开嘴笑起来，满脸放光，“但是我不喜欢喝酒，我亲爱的朋友，它刺痛了我的嗓子，然后我的脑袋就像在敲锣打鼓一样痛了起来。伟大的卢西欣——哈尔兰皮·卢西欣——那个莫斯科乃至整个俄国出了名的酒鬼就曾告诉我说，我喝不了酒。用他的话来说，酒瓶不和我交谈。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, I have, by God,’ rejoined Shubin; and suddenly grinning and brightening,—‘but I didn’t like it, my dear boy, the stuff sticks in my throat, and my head afterwards is a perfect drum.The great Lushtchihin himself—Harlampy Lushtchihin—the greatest drunkard in Moscow, and a Great Russian drunkard too, declared there was nothing to be made of me.In his words, the bottle does not speak to me.’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫正要向那组雕像砸过去，舒宾阻止了他。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev was just going to knock the group over but Shubin stopped him.

第一章: “算了吧，我亲爱的朋友，别砸碎它，它能让我引以为戒，时刻提醒我。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That’ll do, my dear boy, don’t smash it; it will serve as a lesson, a scare-crow.’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫笑了。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev laughed.

第一章: “要真是这样的话，我就不砸它了。”他说。然后他又补充道：“伟大而纯粹的艺术万岁！”
CHAPTER I: ‘If that’s what it is, I will spare your scarecrow then,’ he said.And now, ‘Long live eternal true art!’

第一章: “纯粹的艺术万岁！”舒宾附和道，“就艺术而言，好的更好，糟糕的也并非一无是处！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Long live true art!’ put in Shubin.‘By art the good is better and the bad is not all loss!’

第一章: 两人亲切地握了握手就相互道别了。
CHAPTER I: The friends shook hands warmly and parted.

第一章: 第二十一章
