CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXI

第一章: 埃琳娜睁开眼睛的第一个感觉是一种开心的错愕。“这可能么？这真的发生了吗？”她问自己，心里感受着幸福带来的眩晕。往事涌上心头……她已深陷其中。不一会儿，她的心又回归于幸福的平静。然而整个上午，埃琳娜变得有些心绪不宁，而在这天接下来的时间中她感觉倦怠、乏味。她真正清楚自己现在想要的究竟是什么，但这并没有让她好过一点儿。那永生难忘的会面让她从原来的生活轨迹中彻底地脱离了出来。她不再停留在过去的位置上，她走远了，然而周遭的一切还是以它们的既定轨道运行着，一切都还是老样子，仿佛没有丝毫的改变。过去的生活仍然以过去的方式继续着，指望着埃琳娜还能像过去一样配合、有兴趣。她试着给因萨罗夫写信，但也失败了。那些文字一到纸上要么变得毫无生气，要么变得虚情假意。她在日记的最后一行文字下画了一道粗线，以此宣告结束。那些都是过去的事情，现在她的所有思绪、她的整个灵魂都面向未来。她心情沉重。对于埃琳娜来说，现在跟毫不知情的母亲坐在一起、听她说话、回答她的问题、与她交谈都是一种邪恶的行为。她感到自己有种做错事的感觉，心里很难受，虽然并没有什么值得自责的。她心里不止一次地跳出一种无法抑制的冲动，想把这一切毫无保留地吐露出来，无论接下来将发生什么。“为什么，”她想道，“德米特里不把我从那个小教堂里带走，去他想去的任何地方呢？他不是在上帝面前宣告过我是他的妻子吗？我为什么要在这里？”她突然开始觉得愧对所有人，甚至包括尤瓦·伊万诺维奇。尤瓦的手指此时晃动得更加厉害。现在，她身边的一切都显得既不甜蜜也不友好，也不像是场梦，但却像梦魇一样挥之不去，压迫着她的心，指责她，对她表示愤慨，而且一点儿也不想去了解她……”“无论如何，你都是属于我们的。”她仿佛听到这么一句话。就连她那些可怜的宠物们，那些遭到虐待的鸟儿们和动物们——至少她是这样认为的——也用一种充满猜疑和敌意的眼光看着她。她深感良心所受到的谴责并且为那些感觉而羞愧。“这里毕竟是我的家，”她思索道，“我的家，我的祖国。”……“不，这里不再是你的祖国，也不再是你的家了。”心里有个声音不停地告诉她。恐怖的感觉淹没了她，她为自己的弱小而恼怒。考验才刚刚开始，她就已经失去了耐心……这就是她曾经的许诺吗？
CHAPTER I: Elena’s first sensation on awakening was one of happy consternation.‘Is it possible?Is it possible?’ she asked herself, and her heart grew faint with happiness.Recollections came rushing on her… she was overwhelmed by them.Then again she was enfolded by the blissful peace of triumph.But in the course of the morning, Elena gradually became possessed by a spirit of unrest, and for the remainder of the day she felt listless and weary.It was true she knew now what she wanted, but that made it no easier for her.That never-to-be forgotten meeting had cast her for ever out of the old groove; she was no longer at the same standpoint, she was far away, and yet everything went on about her in its accustomed order, everything pursued its own course as though nothing were changed; the old life moved on its old way, reckoning on Elena’s interest and co-operation as of old.She tried to begin a letter to Insarov, but that too was a failure; the words came on to paper either lifeless or false.Her diary she had put an end to by drawing a thick stroke under the last line.That was the past, and every thought, all her soul, was turned now to the future.Her heart was heavy.To sit with her mother who suspected nothing, to listen to her, answer her and talk to her, seemed to Elena something wicked; she felt the presence of a kind of falseness in her, she suffered though she had nothing to blush for; more than once an almost irresistible desire sprang up in her heart to tell everything without reserve, whatever might come of it afterwards.‘Why,’ she thought, ’did not Dmitri take me away then, from that little chapel, wherever he wanted to go?Didn’t he tell me I was his wife before God?What am I here for?‘She suddenly began to feel shy of every one, even of Uvar Ivanovitch, who was flourishing his fingers in more perplexity than ever.Now everything about her seemed neither sweet nor friendly, nor even a dream, but, like a nightmare, lay, an immovable dead load, on her heart; seeming to reproach her and be indignant with her, and not to care to know about her….’‘You are ours in spite of everything,’ she seemed to hear.Even her poor pets, her ill-used birds and animals looked at her—so at least she fancied—with suspicion and hostility.She felt conscience-stricken and ashamed of her feelings.‘This is my home after all,’ she thought, ‘my family, my country.’… ‘No, it’s no longer your country, nor your family,’ another voice affirmed within her.Terror was overmastering her, and she was vexed with her own feebleness.The trial was only beginning and she was losing patience already…Was this what she had promised?

第一章: 她没有立刻控制住自己。不过，一个星期又一个星期过去了……埃琳娜的心里才稍稍平静，开始适应新的处境。她给因萨罗夫写了两封短信，而且亲自到邮局去发信。她无论如何也无法——因为羞愧和自尊——信任佣人来帮她做这件事。她已经开始期待他能出现在自己的面前……但是，在一个风和日丽的早晨，因萨罗夫没有来，尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇却到了。
CHAPTER I: She did not soon gain control of herself.But a week passed and then another….Elena became a little calmer, and grew used to her new position.She wrote two little notes to Insarov, and carried them herself to the post: she could not for anything—through shame and through pride—have brought herself to confide in a maid.She was already beginning to expect him in person….But instead of Insarov, one fine morning Nikolai Artemyevitch made his appearance.

第一章: 第二十二章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXII

第一章: 在退役禁卫军中尉斯塔霍夫家中，还没有人见过他像这一天这样生这么大的气，并且摆出这样一种盛气凌人的架势。他穿着大衣，戴着帽子，悠闲地大步走进客厅，鞋跟踏得地面咚咚响。他走到镜子前，打量了自己很长时间，泰然自若地晃了晃脑袋，咬了咬嘴唇。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜怀着显而易见的激动和暗地里的喜悦看着他（事实上，她每次见到他是都是这幅情形）。他连帽子都没有脱掉，也没有向她打一声招呼，只是静静地把他那带着鹿皮手套的手伸向埃琳娜，让她亲吻。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜开始询问他治疗的状况，他没有理睬她。尤瓦·伊万诺维奇出现了。斯塔霍夫瞥了一眼他，嘴里轻哼了一声。他对待尤瓦·伊万诺维奇的态度一向冷酷、傲慢，尽管他承认尤瓦具有“真正的斯塔霍夫血统”。众所周知，几乎所有的俄国贵族世家都坚信，只有他们才具有那种独有的血统特征。我们不止一次地听到他们在所谓的“自己人中”讨论诸如波德萨拉斯金斯基家的“鼻子”、佩里普列耶夫斯基家的“脖子”之类的事情。卓娅走了过来，正对着尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇坐了下来。他嘴里咕哝了一声，躺在了一张扶椅上，要了一杯咖啡，然后只是脱掉了帽子。咖啡来了，他喝了一杯，然后依次打量了每个人，呲牙咧嘴地说：“请你们都先离开吧，”然后把头转向他的妻子，补充道，“夫人，您呆在这里。”
CHAPTER I: No one in the house of the retired lieutenant of guards, Stahov, had ever seen him so sour, and at the same time so self-confident and important as on that day.He walked into the drawing-room in his overcoat and hat, with long deliberate stride, stamping with his heels; he approached the looking-glass and took a long look at himself, shaking his head and biting his lips with imperturbable severity.Anna Vassilyevna met him with obvious agitation and secret delight (she never met him otherwise); he did not even take off his hat, nor greet her, and in silence gave Elena his doe-skin glove to kiss.Anna Vassilyevna began questioning him about the progress of his cure; he made her no reply.Uvar Ivanovitch made his appearance; he glanced at him and said, ‘bah!’He usually behaved coldly and haughtily to Uvar Ivanovitch, though he acknowledged in him ‘traces of the true Stahov blood.’Almost all Russian families of the nobility are convinced, as is well known, of the existence of exceptional hereditary characteristics, peculiar to them alone; we have more than once heard discussions ‘among ourselves’ of the Podsalaskinsky ‘noses,’ and the ‘Perepreyevsky’ necks.Zoya came in and sat down facing Nikolai Artemyevitch.He grunted, sank into an armchair, asked for coffee, and only then took off his hat.Coffee was brought him; he drank a cup, and looking at everybody in turn, he growled between his teeth, ’Sortes, s‘il vous plait,’ and turning to his wife he added, ‘et vous, madame, restez, je vous prie.’

第一章: 她们都走出了客厅，只有安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜留在了那里。她的头激动地颤抖了起来。尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇严肃的神情让她有些意外。她在想是不是发生了什么大事。
CHAPTER I: They all left the room, except Anna Vassilyevna.Her head was trembling with agitation.The solemnity of Nikolai Artemyevitch’s preparations impressed her.She was expecting something extraordinary.

第一章: “到底怎么了？”门一关上，她就高声喊道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What is it?’ she cried, directly the door was closed.

第一章: 尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇冷漠地瞟了一眼安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜。
CHAPTER I: Nikolai Artemyevitch flung an indifferent glance at Anna Vassilyevna.

第一章: “也没什么大不了的事情。你老是一副立马认定自己是受害者的样子！”他开始说道，每说一个字，就会毫无必要地瘪一下嘴，“我只是想要提前告诉你，今天会有一位新朋友到我们家来用餐。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Nothing special; what a way you have of assuming the air of a victim at once!’ he began, quite needlessly dropping the corners of his mouth at every word.‘I only want to forewarn you that we shall have a new guest dining here to-day.’

第一章: “是谁？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Who is it?’

第一章: “库尔纳托夫斯基，叶戈尔·安德烈耶维奇。你不认识他。他是枢密院的高级秘书。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Kurnatovsky, Yegor Andreyevitch.You don’t know him.The head secretary in the senate.’

第一章: “他今天就要来我们家用餐？”
CHAPTER I: ‘He is to dine with us to-day?’

第一章: “是的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.’

第一章: “你让大家都走开就只是想跟我说这个？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And was it only to tell me this that you made every one go away?’

第一章: 尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇又瞟了一眼安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜——目光中带着一丝嘲弄。
CHAPTER I: Nikolai Artemyevitch again flung a glance—this time one of irony—at Anna Vassilyevna.

第一章: “这就让你吃惊了？你过一会儿再吃惊吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Does that surprise you?Defer your surprise a little.’

第一章: 他闭上了嘴巴。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜也安静了一会儿。
CHAPTER I: He ceased speaking.Anna Vassilyevna too was silent for a little time.

第一章: “我本来以为……”她开口道。
CHAPTER I: ‘I could have wished—’ she was beginning.

第一章: “我知道你一直把我看成一个‘道德败坏’的人。”尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇突然说道。
CHAPTER I: ‘I know you have always looked on me as an “immoral” man,’ began Nikolai Artemyevitch suddenly.

第一章: “我！”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜带着震惊嘀咕了一句。
CHAPTER I: ‘I!’ muttered Anna Vassilyevna, astounded.

第一章: “可能你是对的。我并不想否认在某些时候确实做了一些让你生气的事（‘我的那些灰马！’安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜突然想起了这件事），但是你自己也得承认，你也清楚，你的身体状况——”
CHAPTER I: ‘And very likely you are right.I don’t wish to deny that I have in fact sometimes given you just grounds for dissatisfaction’ (“my greys!” flashed through Anna Vassilyevna’s head), ‘though you must yourself allow, that in the condition, as you are aware, of your constitution—’

第一章: “可是我并没有因此而抱怨过啊，尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇。”
CHAPTER I: ‘And I make no complaint against you, Nikolai Artemyevitch.’

第一章: “可能吧。无论如何，我并不是想为自己辩驳。时间会证明我的清白。但是我认为，我有责任向你证明，我很清楚我的责任，而且我也会处理好——那些托付于我的——家庭幸福。”
CHAPTER I: ‘C’est possible.In any case, I have no intention of justifying myself.Time will justify me.But I regard it as my duty to prove to you that I understand my duties, and know how to care for—for the welfare of the family entrusted—entrusted to me.’

第一章: “说这些是为了什么呢？”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜思索着。（她无论如何也想不到前一天晚上，在一个英国俱乐部的一间休息室的角落里展开过一场有关俄国人没有演讲才华的讨论。“我们中的哪位精于说话之道？请说出一个！”争论者中的一人大声喊道，“好吧，那就斯塔霍夫吧。”另一个人答道，指着那时正站立着、兴奋地快要叫起来的尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇。）
CHAPTER I: ‘What’s the meaning of all this?’Anna Vassilyevna was thinking.(She could not guess that the preceding evening at the English club a discussion had arisen in a corner of the smoking-room as to the incapacity of Russians to make speeches.‘Which of us can speak?Mention any one!’ one of the disputants had exclaimed.‘Well, Stahov, for instance,’ had answered the other, pointing to Nikolai Artemyevitch, who stood up on the spot almost squealing with delight.)

第一章: “比如说，”尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇接着说，“我的女儿埃琳娜。你不觉得她是时候该做出人生中的一项重大抉择了么——我是说，她该结婚了。她对知识、慈善这些的追求都很好，但是这些都应该适度、适时而止。现在是时候让她从虚幻中清醒过来，从艺术家、学者和黑山人的圈子中脱离出来，回归一个正常人的生活。”
CHAPTER I: ‘For instance,’ pursued Nikolai Artemyevitch, ’my daughter Elena.Don’t you consider that the time has come for her to take a decisive step along the path—to be married, I mean to say.All these intellectual and philanthropic pursuits are all very well, but only up to a certain point, up to a certain age.It’s time for her to drop her mistiness, to get out of the society of all these artists, scholars, and Montenegrins, and do like everybody else.’

第一章: “我该如何理解你所说的这些呢？”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘How am I to understand you?’ asked Anna Vassilyevna.

第一章: “好吧，只要你好好听我说，”尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇说，还是不时地瘪瘪嘴角，“我就不绕圈子、坦白跟你讲。我认识并且熟识了这个叫做库尔纳托夫斯基先生的年轻人，我想让他成为我的女婿。我敢肯定，你见到他后绝不会认为我偏心或者决定下得太过仓促。”（尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇说着，并为自己的口才而洋洋自得。）“他受过良好的教育，曾就读于最高等的法学院，知书达礼，今年33岁，是高级秘书和议员，还获得过一枚斯坦尼斯拉斯勋章。你也知道，我不是那种为了所谓的地位而钻营的贵族，然而你也告诉过我，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜喜欢那种务实的商人。首先，叶戈尔·安德烈耶维奇就是一个商人，另外，我们的女儿特别欣赏慷慨大方的人，那么让我告诉你吧，叶戈尔·安德烈耶维奇一有能力——你明白我的意思——赚钱养活自己之后，就为了兄弟的利益而拒绝了父亲每年对他物质上的援助。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, if you will kindly listen,’ answered Nikolai Artemyevitch, still with the same dropping of the corners of his lips, ‘I will tell you plainly, without beating about the bush.I have made acquaintance, I have become intimate with this young man, Mr. Kurnatovsky, in the hope of having him for a son-in-law.I venture to think that when you see him, you will not accuse me of partiality or precipitate judgment.’ (Nikolai Artemyevitch was admiring his own eloquence as he talked.)‘Of excellent education—educated in the highest legal college—excellent manners, thirty-three years old, and upper-secretary, a councillor, and a Stanislas cross on his neck.You, I hope, will do me the justice to allow that I do not belong to the number of those peres de famille who are mad for position; but you yourself told me that Elena Nikolaevna likes practical business men; Yegor Andreyevitch is in the first place a business man; now on the other side, my daughter has a weakness for generous actions; so let me tell you that Yegor Andreyevitch, directly he had attained the possibility—you understand me—the possibility of living without privation on his salary, at once gave up the yearly income assigned him by his father, for the benefit of his brothers.’

第一章: “他的父亲是？”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Who is his father?’ inquired Anna Vassilyevna.

第一章: “他的父亲？他的父亲在他的家族中也是个了不起的人物，声望很高，性格坚韧不拔，据我所知好像是个退役的少校，打理着布——伯爵的全部产业。”
CHAPTER I: ‘His father?His father is a man well-known in his own line, of the highest moral character, un vrai stoicien, a retired major, I think, overseer of all the estates of the Count B—’

第一章: “啊！”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜喊了出来。
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah!’ observed Anna Vassilyevna.

第一章: “啊！啊什么？”尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇说，“你有什么意见吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah!why ah?’ interposed Nikolai Artemyevitch.‘Can you be infected with prejudice?’

第一章: “没有啊，我什么也没说……”安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Why, I said nothing—’ Anna Vassilyevna was beginning.

第一章: “不，你说了声，啊！无论如何我都觉得应该让你知道我的想法，而且我认为、希望库尔纳托夫斯基先生能受到热情的款待。他可不是什么黑山的无赖。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, you said, ah!—However that may be, I have thought it well to acquaint you with my way of thinking; and I venture to think—I venture to hope Mr. Kurnatovsky will be received a bras ouverts.He is no Montenegrin vagrant.’

第一章: “当然。我只需要把厨师万卡叫来，叫他多做些菜就行了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Of course; I need only call Vanka the cook and order a few extra dishes.’

第一章: “你知道我顾不上这些。”尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇说道。他站起身来，戴上了帽子，吹着口哨（他曾听别人说过，只有在乡间别墅和马场吹口哨才是得体的行为）去花园里散步了。舒宾从自己房间的小窗户看着他走了出去，暗自朝他吐了吐舌头。
CHAPTER I: ‘You are aware that I will not enter into that,’ said Nikolai Artemyevitch; and he got up, put on his hat, and whistling (he had heard some one say that whistling was only permissible in a country villa and a riding court) went out for a stroll in the garden.Shubin watched him out of the little window of his lodge, and in silence put out his tongue at him.

第一章: 差十分四点的时候，一架出租马车停在了斯塔霍夫家别墅的台阶前，一个外表俊朗、穿着简单而优雅的年轻人走下了马车，报了自己的姓名。这就是叶戈尔·安德烈耶维奇·库尔纳托夫斯基。
CHAPTER I: At ten minutes to four, a hackney-carriage drove up to the steps of the Stahovs’s villa, and a man, still young, of prepossessing appearance, simply and elegantly dressed, stepped out of it and sent up his name.This was Yegor Andreyevitch Kurnatovsky.

第一章: 于是，除去其他事情，埃琳娜在次日给因萨罗夫的信中还写道：
CHAPTER I: This was what, among other things, Elena wrote next day to Insarov:

第一章: “恭喜我吧，亲爱的德米特里，我有了一个追求者。他昨天和我们一起共进晚餐。我想父亲是在英国俱乐部跟他认识的，并且邀请了他到我家来。当然，他昨天还没有表现出要追求我的意思。但是我好心的母亲知道父亲的期望，悄悄地告诉了我这个客人是谁。他叫叶戈尔·安德烈耶维奇·库尔纳托夫斯基，是枢密院的高级秘书。我先给你说说他的长相吧。他中等个头，比你矮一点儿，身材不错，五官端正，小平头，留着浓浓的络腮胡。他的眼睛不大（跟你一样），棕色，很灵活，嘴巴扁而宽。他的眼睛和嘴永远露出职业化的微笑，就像一直都在上班一样。他的动作简洁，谈吐清晰，整个人都很严谨。他走起路来、笑起来以及吃东西的时候都像在上班一样。你现在可能在想‘她打量得可真仔细啊！’是的，只有这样才能把他清楚地描述给你听啊。更何况，谁不会仔细地观察追求她的人呢！他感觉上很坚韧——同时也很呆板、无趣——很诚恳，他们说他真的非常诚恳。你也是个坚韧的人，但是跟他又不一样。吃饭的时候，他坐在我旁边，舒宾坐在我们对面。一开始，他们在谈论有关商业方面的一些事情。他们说他在商业方面特别有头脑，差点儿就放弃政府职员的工作而去管理一个大型的制造工厂。真可惜他没有这样做！然后舒宾开始谈戏剧。库尔纳托夫斯基先生就声明——我必须承认——他对艺术一窍不通，这绝不是故作谦虚。这让我想起了你，但是随后我又想道，不，德米特里和我所谓的不懂艺术又与他不同。这位先生的意思似乎是‘我对艺术一无所知，而且艺术是多余的，尽管在一个秩序井然的国度，它是受到认可的’。然而，他似乎对彼得堡相当不以为然。他还一度称自己为无产阶级。他说‘我们是劳动者。’我就想，如果是德米特里这样说的话，我会不高兴的，但是他嘛，随便他怎么吹嘘自己好了。他待我时很有礼节，但我一直觉得他就像是一个屈尊来跟我说话的首长。他夸奖别人的时候就会说谁谁谁是一个高尚的人——那是他的口头禅。他看起来很有自信、很努力，而且有自我牺牲精神（看吧，我是很公正的），就是说，他可以牺牲自己的一切利益，但是又很专横。如果被他所左右那可真是一种悲哀！吃饭的时候他们还谈到了行贿的问题。
CHAPTER I: ‘Congratulate me, dear Dmitri, I have a suitor.He dined with us yesterday: papa made his acquaintance at the English club, I fancy, and invited him.Of course he did not come yesterday as a suitor.But good mamma, to whom papa had made known his hopes, whispered in my ear what this guest was.His name is Yegor Andreyevitch Kurnatovsky; he is upper-secretary to the Senate.I will first describe to you his appearance.He is of medium height, shorter than you, and a good figure; his features are regular, he is close-cropped, and wears large whiskers.His eyes are rather small (like yours), brown, and quick; he has a flat wide mouth; in his eyes and on his lips there is a perpetual sort of official smile; it seems to be always on duty there.He behaves very simply and speaks precisely, and everything about him is precise; he moves, laughs, and eats as though he were doing a duty.“How carefully she has studied him!” you are thinking, perhaps, at this minute.Yes; so as to be able to describe him to you.And besides, who wouldn’t study her suitor!There’s something of iron in him—and dull and empty at the same time—and honest; they say he is really very honest.You, too, are made of iron; but not like this man.At dinner he sat next me, and facing us sat Shubin.At first the conversation turned on commercial undertakings; they say he is very clever in business matters, and was almost throwing up his government post to take charge of a large manufacturing business.Pity he didn’t do it!Then Shubin began to talk about the theatre; Mr. Kurnatovsky declared and—I must confess—without false modesty, that he has no ideas about art.That reminded me of you—but I thought; no, Dmitri and I are ignorant of art in a very different way though.This man seemed to mean, “I know nothing of it, and it’s quite superfluous, still it may be admitted in a well-ordered state.”He seems, however, to think very little about Petersburg and comme il faut: he once even called himself one of the proletariat.‘We are working people,’ he said; I thought if Dmitri had said that, I shouldn’t have liked it; but he may talk about himself, he may boast if he likes.With me he is very attentive; but I kept feeling that a very, very condescending superior was talking with me.When he means to praise any one, he says So-and-so is a man of principle—that’s his favourite word.He seems to be self-confident, hardworking, capable of self-sacrifice (you see, I am impartial), that’s to say, of sacrificing his own interest; but he is a great despot.It would be woeful to fall into his power!At dinner they began talking about bribes.

第一章: “他说‘我清楚，在很多情况下，收受贿赂的人是不该受到批评的，他也是无可奈何。但是，他要是被查出来了，就应该受到严惩。’”我叫道‘惩罚一个没有过错的人！’“‘是的，要坚持原则。’”‘什么原则？’舒宾问道。库尔纳托夫斯基看起来不知道是尴尬还是惊讶地说‘这不需要解释吧。’
CHAPTER I: ‘“I know,” he said, “that in many cases the man who accepts a bribe is not to blame; he cannot do otherwise.Still, if he is found out, he must be punished without mercy.”’ I cried, “Punish an innocent man!”‘“Yes; for the sake of principle.” ’“What principle?” asked Shubin.Kurnatovsky seemed annoyed or surprised, and said, “That needs no explanation.”

第一章: “似乎一直对他很尊重的父亲也附和道‘当然不需要解释。’于是这次谈话在我的恼怒中结束了。晚上，别尔谢涅夫来了，跟他进行了一场非常激烈的辩论。我从来没有发现过我们平易近人的安德烈·彼得罗维奇这么激动过。库尔纳托夫斯基先生也没有完全否定科学、大学等等的作用，但是我充分理解安德烈·彼得罗维奇的愤怒。这个家伙竟然把这一切都看作体操一类的东西。晚饭后，舒宾走到我身边说‘这人和那人（他从不讲出你的名字）都很实际，但是看吧，差别太大了。那人在生活中追寻自己的理想；这人却几乎没有一点儿责任感，只会官场上的那一套，没有任何内涵。’舒宾很聪明，我把他的话记了下来，转达给你，但是在我心里，你们俩没有丝毫的相同之处。你有信仰，但他没有，因为一个人不能仅仅只相信自己。
CHAPTER I: ‘Papa, who seems to worship him, put in “of course not”; and to my vexation the conversation stopped there.In the evening Bersenyev came and got into a terrific argument with him.I have never seen our good Andrei Petrovitch so excited.Mr. Kurnatovsky did not at all deny the utility of science, universities, and so on, but still I understood Andrei Petrovitch’s indignation.The man looks at it all as a sort of gymnastics.Shubin came up to me after dinner, and said, “This fellow here and some one else (he can never bring himself to utter your name) are both practical men, but see what a difference; there’s the real living ideal given to life; and here there’s not even a feeling of duty, simply official honesty and activity without anything inside it.”Shubin is clever, and I remembered his words to tell you; but to my mind there is nothing in common between you.You have faith, and he has not; for a man cannot have faith in himself only.

第一章: 他离开时已经很晚了，但母亲还是花时间告诉我说他对我的感觉很好，父亲也非常高兴。我在想，他有没有说我是一个高尚的女人呢？我差一点儿就告诉母亲，很抱歉，我已经是一个有丈夫的人了。为什么父亲这么不喜欢你呢？母亲嘛，我们还可以很快地改变她的观点。
CHAPTER I: ‘He did not go away till late; but mamma had time to inform me that he was pleased with me, and papa is in ecstasies.Did he say, I wonder, that I was a woman of principle?I was almost telling mamma that I was very sorry, but I had a husband already.Why is it papa dislikes you so?Mamma, we could soon manage to bring round.

第一章: 哦，亲爱的！我如此细致地向你描述这位先生只是为了减轻我的心痛。离开你，我无法生存。我感觉你一直在我的眼前，对我说话。我期待与你相见——只是不要像你所打算的在我们的家中——试想一下我们会有多么地尴尬和不安！你知道我是在哪儿给你写的信吗——在那片小树林里。哦，亲爱的！我是多么爱你！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Oh, my dear one!I have described this gentleman in such detail to deaden my heartache.I don’t live without you; I am constantly seeing you, hearing you.I look forward to seeing you—only not at our house, as you intended—fancy how wretched and ill at ease we should be!—but you know where I wrote to you—in that wood.Oh, my dear one!How I love you!’

第一章: 第二十三章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXIII

第一章: 库尔纳托夫斯基初次到访后的第三个星期，让埃琳娜十分高兴的是，安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜回到了莫斯科，住进了她那间离普列奇斯坚卡不远的大木屋中。那是一个有着廊柱的房子，所有的窗户上都点缀着白色的七弦琴和花环。房子里有一间阁楼、几间办公室，有一排木栅栏，还有一个巨大的绿草如茵的庭院。庭院中有一口井，井旁边有一个狗舍。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜从没有这么早从乡间别墅搬出来过，但是今年，随着秋天第一场寒潮的降临，她的脸肿了起来。而对于尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇来说，随着他疗程的结束，他也开始思念他的妻子。再者，奥古斯丁娜·克里斯蒂亚诺夫娜又去了雷瓦尔看望她的表妹。另外，一个名叫“活体雕像”的国外家庭杂技团来到了莫斯科，《莫斯科公报》对他们精彩表演的描述激起了安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜浓烈的兴趣。简而言之，继续在乡间别墅住下去似乎不方便了，而且用尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇的话说，甚至将会影响到他完成那个“倍受珍视的计划”了。最后的那两个星期对埃琳娜来说似乎相当漫长。库尔纳托夫斯基在周日来过两次。别的时间他都在忙。他实际上是为了见埃琳娜而来，但却跟卓娅相谈甚欢。卓雅十分欣赏他。“这是个真正的男人！”她一边看着他那充满男人味的脸庞，听着他那自信而又谦逊的言辞，一边默默思考着。在她看来，没有一个人有如此充满磁性的嗓音，没有一个人能把“我有此荣幸——”或者“我很开心——”说得这么动听。因萨罗夫没有来过斯塔霍夫的家中，但是埃琳娜悄悄地在莫斯科湖边的一片小树林中和他见了一面。那个地点是埃琳娜选的。他们相互之间只是短短地说了几句话。舒宾和安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜一起回的莫斯科，而别尔谢涅夫则晚了几天才回去。
CHAPTER I: Three weeks after Kurnatovsky’s first visit, Anna Vassilyevna, to Elena’s great delight, returned to Moscow, to her large wooden house near Prechistenka; a house with columns, white lyres and wreaths over every window, with an attic, offices, a palisade, a huge green court, a well in the court and a dog’s kennel near the well.Anna Vassilyevna had never left her country villa so early, but this year with the first autumn chills her face swelled; Nikolai Artemyevitch for his part, having finished his cure, began to want his wife; besides, Augustina Christianovna had gone away on a visit to her cousin in Revel; a family of foreigners, known as ‘living statues,’ des poses plastiques, had come to Moscow, and the description of them in the Moscow Gazette had aroused Anna Vassilyevna’s liveliest curiosity.In short, to stay longer at the villa seemed inconvenient, and even, in Nikolai Artemyevitch’s words, incompatible with the fulfilment of his ‘cherished projects.’The last fortnight seemed very long to Elena.Kurnatovsky came over twice on Sundays; on other days he was busy.He came really to see Elena, but talked more to Zoya, who was much pleased with him.‘Das ist ein Mann!’ she thought to herself, as she looked at his full manly face and listened to his self-confident, condescending talk.To her mind, no one had such a wonderful voice, no one could pronounce so nicely, ‘I had the hon-our,’ or, ‘I am most de-lighted.’Insarov did not come to the Stahovs, but Elena saw him once in secret in a little copse by the Moskva river, where she arranged to meet him.They hardly had time to say more than a few words to each other.Shubin returned to Moscow with Anna Vassilyevna; Bersenyev, a few days later.

第一章: 因萨罗夫坐在自己的房间里，第三遍看着那些让人从保加利亚带过来的信件。他们不敢让邮局投递这些信件。他被这些信搅得一团糟。东欧各国的局势发展得很迅猛。俄国军队对各公国的侵略让每个人的心都提到了嗓子眼。风暴正在酝酿之中——已经能嗅到一场不可避免的战争即将到来的气息。到处燃起战争的火焰，没有人能够预见它将烧到何方——会在哪里熄灭。过去的纷争，长久以来的美好希望——所有这一切再次蠢蠢欲动了起来。因萨罗夫的心也在狂野地跳动着。他的希望也快要实现了。“可是，这一切是不是来得太快了，不会功亏一篑吧？”他紧紧握住双手，思索着，“我们还没有准备好，但是就这样吧！我必须走！”
CHAPTER I: Insarov was sitting in his room, and for the third time looking through the letters brought him from Bulgaria by hand; they were afraid to send them by post.He was much disturbed by them.Events were developing rapidly in the East; the occupation of the Principalities by Russian troops had thrown all men’s minds into a ferment; the storm was growing—already could be felt the breath of approaching inevitable war.The fire was kindling all round, and no one could foresee how far it would go—where it would stop.Old wrongs, long cherished hopes—all were astir again.Insarov’s heart throbbed eagerly; his hopes too were being realised.‘But is it not too soon, will it not be in vain?’ he thought, tightly clasping his hands.‘We are not ready, but so be it!I must go.’

第一章: 门外沙沙作响，门飞快地开了，埃琳娜跑进屋里来。
CHAPTER I: Something rustled lightly at the door, it flew quickly open, and into the room ran Elena.

第一章: 因萨罗夫浑身颤抖着奔向她，跪在她的面前，紧紧抱住她的腰，把头用力地靠在上面。
CHAPTER I: Insarov, all in a tremor, rushed to her, fell on his knees before her, clasped her waist and pressed it close against his head.

第一章: “没有想到我会过来吧？”她上气不接下气地说。她是飞快地跑着上楼梯的。“亲爱的！亲爱的！这就是你住的地方？我轻轻松松就找到你了。你房东的女儿带我来的。我们前天就到了。我本来想给你写信的，但还是觉得自己过来更好。我可以在你这里呆十五分钟。起来，把门关上。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You didn’t expect me?’ she said, hardly able to draw her breath, she had run quickly up the stairs.‘Dear one!dear one!—so this is where you live?I’ve quickly found you.The daughter of your landlord conducted me.We arrived the day before yesterday.I meant to write to you, but I thought I had better come myself.I have come for a quarter of an hour.Get up, shut the door.’

第一章: 他站起身来，赶紧关上门，跑回她身旁，握紧她的双手。他一句话也说不出来，兴奋到无法呼吸。她双眼带笑地看向他的眼睛……他的眼里充满了狂喜……她感到有点儿难为情。
CHAPTER I: He got up, quickly shut the door, returned to her and took her by the hands.He could not speak; he was choking with delight.She looked with a smile into his eyes… there was such rapture in them… she felt shy.

第一章: “等等，”她说着，温柔地把手从他的手中抽出来，“让我先把帽子脱了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Stay,’ she said, fondly taking her hand away from him, ‘let me take off my hat.’

第一章: 她解下帽子，丢到一旁，从肩膀上拿下披肩，理了理头发，然后坐到了一张破旧的小沙发上。因萨罗夫注视着她，眼睛一眨不眨，像着了魔一样。
CHAPTER I: She untied the strings of her hat, flung it down, slipped the cape off her shoulders, tidied her hair, and sat down on the little old sofa.Insarov gazed at her, without stirring, like one enchanted.

第一章: “坐下吧。”她说道，没有抬头看他，用手指了指旁边的位置。
CHAPTER I: ‘Sit down,’ she said, not lifting her eyes to him and motioning him to a place beside her.

第一章: 因萨罗夫坐下了，不过没有坐在沙发上，而是坐在了她脚旁边的地板上。
CHAPTER I: Insarov sat down, not on the sofa, but on the floor at her feet.

第一章: “来吧，帮我把手套脱了。”她含糊地说道。她觉得有点儿害怕。
CHAPTER I: ‘Come, take off my gloves,’ she said in an uncertain voice.She felt afraid.

第一章: 他先解开扣子，然后慢慢拽下一只手套，跩到一半，便急切地将自己的双唇印在了那被手套遮住的、纤细、柔软、白皙的手腕上。
CHAPTER I: He began first to unbutton and then to draw off one glove; he drew it half off and greedily pressed his lips to the slender, soft wrist, which was white under it.

第一章: 埃琳娜全身一震，想用另一只手把他推开，但他又开始亲吻她的另一只手。埃琳娜把手缩回来，他抬起头，她看着他的脸，俯下身去，他们的双唇碰到了一起。
CHAPTER I: Elena shuddered, and would have pushed him back with the other hand; he began kissing the other hand too.Elena drew it away, he threw back his head, she looked into his face, bent above him, and their lips touched.

第一章: 过了一会儿，她挣脱开，站起身来，嘴里轻轻地说着：“不，不。”然后快步走到书桌旁边。
CHAPTER I: An instant passed… she broke away, got up, whispered ‘No, no,’ and went quickly up to the writing-table.

第一章: “我是这里的女主人，所以你不能对我有丝毫的隐瞒。”她说。她试着让自己平静下来，背对着他。“这么多信啊！都写的是什么呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘I am mistress here, you know, so you ought not to have any secrets from me,’ she said, trying to seem at ease, and standing with her back to him.‘What a lot of papers!what are these letters?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫皱起了眉头。“那些信？”他站起来说，“你可以看看。”
CHAPTER I: Insarov knitted his brows.‘Those letters?’ he said, getting up, ‘you can read them.’

第一章: 埃琳娜把那些信拿起来看了看。“这么多信，字很清秀，但是我马上就要走了……不管它们啦。它们不是情敌写的吧。嗯？它们不是用俄语写的啊。”她补充道，然后把信随意翻了翻。
CHAPTER I: Elena turned them over in her hand.‘There are so many of them, and the writing is so fine, and I have to go directly… let them be. They’re not from a rival, eh?…and they’re not in Russian,’ she added, turning over the thin sheets.

第一章: 因萨罗夫走到了她的身边，深情地抚摸着她的腰。她立刻朝他转了过来，朝他笑了笑，依偎在他的肩头。
CHAPTER I: Insarov came close to her and fondly touched her waist.She turned suddenly to him, smiled brightly at him and leant against his shoulder.

第一章: “那些信都是从保加利亚带过来的，埃琳娜。是我朋友写给我的，他们希望我过去。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Those letters are from Bulgaria, Elena; my friends write to me, they want me to come.’

第一章: “现在？去他们那儿？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Now?To them?’

第一章: “是的……现在，现在还有时间，也还有可能过去。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes… now, while there is still time, while it is still possible to come.’

第一章: 她马上就用双手环抱住他的脖子：“你会带我一起去的，对吗？”
CHAPTER I: All at once she flung both arms round his neck, ‘You will take me with you, yes?’

第一章: 他紧紧将她拥入胸口。“哦，我的宝贝，我的女英雄，你怎么会这么说呢！但是我这样一个无家可归、无依无靠的单身汉拉着你一起走，我会不会太邪恶、太疯狂了……而且还是去那样的地方！”
CHAPTER I: He pressed her to his heart.‘O my sweet girl, O my heroine, how you said that!But isn’t it wicked, isn’t it mad for me, a homeless, solitary man, to drag you with me… and out there too!’

第一章: 她捂住他的嘴：“嘘——再这样说我就生气了，再也不来见你了。我们之间的事不是已经定好了，一切都说好了吗？难道我不是你的妻子吗？一个妻子能离开她的丈夫吗？”
CHAPTER I: She shut his mouth…. ‘Sh—or I shall be angry, and never come to see you again.Why isn’t it all decided, all settled between us?Am I not your wife?Can a wife be parted from her husband?’

第一章: “妻子们不用冲锋陷阵啊。”他带着些许伤感的微笑说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Wives don’t go into war,’ he said with a half-mournful smile.

第一章: “哦，是的，她们不甘落后的时候我就可以留下来吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Oh yes, when they can’t stay behind, and I cannot stay here?’

第一章: “埃琳娜，我的天使！但是你想想，也许过两个星期我就会被迫离开莫斯科。我顾不上那些大学课程，顾不上继续我的研究课题。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena, my angel!..but think, I have, perhaps, to leave Moscow in a fortnight.I can’t think of university lectures, or finishing my work.’

第一章: “什么！”埃琳娜打断他，“你马上就要走？如果你愿意，我就不回家了，从这一刻起一直留在你身边好不好？我们马上就出发吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What!’ interrupted Elena, ‘you have to go soon?If you like, I will stop at once this minute with you for ever, and not go home, shall I?Shall we go at once?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫更加用情地将她搂在自己的双臂里。“如果我做错了，”他喊道，“就让老天来惩罚我吧！从今天起，就让我们永不分离！”
CHAPTER I: Insarov clasped her in his arms with redoubled warmth.‘May God so reward me then,’ he cried, ‘if I am doing wrong!From to-day, we are one for ever!’

第一章: “那我就留在这里吗？”埃琳娜问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Am I to stay?’ asked Elena.

第一章: “不，我的好姑娘。不，我的宝贝。你今天还是要回家，只是你得做好准备，随时出发。这件事不是立刻就能完成的。我们必须慢慢地筹划。我们需要钱、护照……”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, my pure girl; no, my treasure.You shall go back home to-day, only keep yourself in readiness.This is a matter we can’t manage straight off; we must plan it out well.We want money, a passport—’

第一章: “我有钱！”埃琳娜说道，“有80卢布。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I have money,’ put in Elena.‘Eighty roubles.’

第一章: “好的，但那还不够，”因萨罗夫说，“但是都用得上。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, that’s not much,’ observed Insarov; ‘but everything’s a help.’

第一章: “我还能拿到更多的钱。我能去借。我可以找母亲要……不，我不能找母亲要任何东西……但我能卖掉我的手表……还有我的耳环、两个手镯……还有蕾丝。”
CHAPTER I: ‘But I can get more.I will borrow.I will ask mamma….No, I won’t ask mamma for any….But I can sell my watch….I have earrings, too, and two bracelets… and lace.’

第一章: “钱不是关键，埃琳娜，护照，你的护照，这该怎么办？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Money’s not the chief difficulty, Elena; the passport; your passport, how about that?’

第一章: “是啊，这该怎么弄到呢？一定要护照吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, how about it?Is a passport absolutely necessary?’

第一章: “当然。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Absolutely.’

第一章: 埃琳娜笑了起来：“世事无常啊！我记得我小的时候……我们的一个女佣逃跑了。最后她被抓了回来，我们原谅了她，她跟我们一起生活了很长一段时间……不过，大家还是叫她‘逃跑的塔季扬娜’。我从没想过有一天我也会像她一样跑掉。”
CHAPTER I: Elena laughed.‘What a queer idea!I remember when I was little… a maid of ours ran away.She was caught, and forgiven, and lived with us a long while… but still every one used to call her Tatyana, the runaway.I never thought then that I too might perhaps be a runaway like her.’

第一章: “埃琳娜，难道你不觉得惭愧吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena, aren’t you ashamed?’

第一章: “为什么？当然，有护照固然是好。但是万一我们弄不到……”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why?Of course it’s better to go with a passport.But if we can’t—’

第一章: “我们之后再解决这些事情，之后，再等等。”因萨罗夫说，“让我再看看，让我再想想。我们再把所有的事情都想一遍。我也有钱。”
CHAPTER I: ‘We will settle all that later, later, wait a little,’ said Insarov.‘Let me look about; let me think a little.We will talk over everything together thoroughly.I too have money.’

第一章: 埃琳娜撩起他掉在前额的头发。
CHAPTER I: Elena pushed back the hair that fell over on his forehead.

第一章: “啊，德米特里！我们俩能一起离开了，这真是太好了！”
CHAPTER I: ‘O Dmitri!how glorious it will be for us two to set off together!’

第一章: “没错，”因萨罗夫说，“不过，我们到那里之后……”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes,’ said Insarov, ‘but there, when we get there—’

第一章: “嗯？”埃琳娜说，“就算我们死在一起又有什么不好呢？不，我们为什么要死呢？我们要活着，我们还年轻。你多大了？26？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well?’ put in Elena, ‘and won’t it be glorious to die together too?but no, why should we die?We will live, we are young.How old are you?Twenty-six?’

第一章: “是的，我26岁。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, twenty-six.’

第一章: “我20岁。我们的未来还有很长的时间。啊，你要离我而去吗？你不想和一个俄国女人相爱，你这个玻利维亚佬！现在让我看看你究竟是想怎样甩掉我吧！如果我那时不去找你，我们会变成什么样呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And I am twenty.There is plenty of time before us.Ah, you tried to run away from me?You did not want a Russian’s love, you Bulgarian!Let me see you trying to escape from me now!What would have become of us, if I hadn’t come to you then!’

第一章: “埃琳娜，你知道迫使我离开的原因是什么。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena, you know what forced me to go away.’

第一章: “我当然知道啊。你爱上我了，所以你害怕。但是你那时候肯定猜到了我也同样爱着你吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘I know; you were in love, and you were afraid.But surely you must have suspected that you were loved?’

第一章: “我发誓，埃琳娜，我没猜到。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I swear on my honour, Elena, I didn’t.’

第一章: 她出人意料地快速吻了他一下。“这个，我也因为这个而爱你。那……再见了。”
CHAPTER I: She gave him a quick unexpected kiss.‘There, I love you for that too.And goodbye.’

第一章: “你不能再多呆一会儿吗？”因萨罗夫问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘You can’t stop longer?’ asked Insarov.

第一章: “不行了，我最亲爱的。你觉得我一个人出来就这么容易吗？十五分钟早过了。”她披上披肩，戴上帽子。“你明天晚上来我们家吧。不，后天吧。虽然我们会觉得无趣、不自在，但我们也无能为力，至少我们能看见对方。再见了。让我走吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No, dearest.Do you think it’s easy for me to get out alone?The quarter of an hour was over long ago.’She put on her cape and hat.‘And you come to us to-morrow evening.No, the day after to-morrow.We shall be constrained and dreary, but we can’t help that; at least we shall see each other.Good-bye.Let me go.’

第一章: 他最后一次拥抱了她。“啊，小心点儿，你弄坏了我的表链子。哦，笨拙的孩子！算了，没关系。这样更好。我要去库兹涅茨基桥，把它送那里修一修。要是有人问我，我就说我去库兹涅茨基桥了。”她握着门把手。“顺便跟你说一句，我忘了告诉你了，库尔纳托夫斯基先生这两天会向我求婚。但是我的回答——会是这个——”说着她把左手的大拇指放在鼻尖，剩下的手指头在空中挥了挥。“那在下次见面之前，再见了。现在，我知道路了……而且不会浪费时间了。”
CHAPTER I: He embraced her for the last time.‘Ah, take care, you have broken my watch-chain.Oh, what a clumsy boy!There, never mind.It’s all the better.I will go to Kuznetsky bridge, and leave it to be mended.If I am asked, I can say I have been to Kuznetsky bridge.’She held the door-handle.‘By-the-way, I forgot to tell you, Monsieur Kurnatovsky will certainly make me an offer in a day or two.But the answer I shall make him—will be this—’ She put the thumb of her left hand to the tip of her nose and flourished the other fingers in the air.‘Good-bye till we see each other again.Now, I know the way…And don’t lose any time.’

第一章: 埃琳娜把门打开了一个缝，听了听，转身向因萨罗夫点了点头，然后快速地溜出了房间。
CHAPTER I: Elena opened the door a little, listened, turned round to Insarov, nodded her head, and glided out of the room.

第一章: 因萨罗夫在关着的门后站了一会儿，也听着门外的声音。他听见楼下院子的门砰地响了一声。他走到沙发旁边，坐了下来，用双手捂住自己的眼睛。这种事情从未在他的身上发生过。“我怎么有资格拥有这样的爱情呢？”他思索着，“这是梦吗？”
CHAPTER I: For a minute Insarov stood before the closed door, and he too listened.The door downstairs into the court slammed.He went up to the sofa, sat down, and covered his eyes with his hands.Never before had anything like this happened to him.‘What have I done to deserve such love?’ he thought.‘Is it a dream?’

第一章: 但是，留在这破旧昏暗的小屋子里的木犀香水味证明她确实来过。与这香气一起的还有空气中回响着的清脆的嗓音，灵巧的脚步声，还有从那天真无邪的少女身上散发出来的温暖和清新的气息。
CHAPTER I: But the delicate scent of mignonette left by Elena in his poor dark little room told of her visit.And with it, it seemed that the air was still full of the notes of a young voice, and the sound of a light young tread, and the warmth and freshness of a young girlish body.

第一章: 第二十四章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXIV

第一章: 因萨罗夫决定等待更确切的消息，同时开始着手为离开做准备。困难很大。对他自己来说倒没有什么阻碍。他只需要申请一张护照——但是埃琳娜该怎么办呢？以正当的方式来取得她的护照是不可能实现的。他是不是应该先秘密地跟她结婚，然后去拜见她的父母呢？“那样的话，他们应该会同意我们一起离开，”他思索着，“但是万一他们不同意呢？我们还是要走。但是，如果他们要起诉我……如果……不，无论如何，最好还是帮她弄到一张护照。”
CHAPTER I: Insarov decided to await more positive news, and began to make preparations for departure.The difficulty was a serious one.For him personally there were no obstacles.He had only to ask for a passport—but how would it be with Elena?To get her a passport in the legal way was impossible.Should he marry her secretly, and should they then go and present themselves to the parents?…‘They would let us go then,’ he thought ‘But if they did not?We would go all the same.But suppose they were to make a complaint… if…No, better try to get a passport somehow.’

第一章: 他决定去请教一个熟人（当然不能透露姓名）。那是一个退休了的又或许是被撤了职的律师，他在办理各种违法事件上的经验非常丰富。这个家伙住在很远的地方。因萨罗夫乘坐着肮脏的无顶四轮马车，颠簸了整整一个小时才到他家，但更糟糕的是，他不在家，而因萨罗夫在回去的路上又遇上一场突如其来的倾盆大雨，被淋成了落汤鸡。第二天一早，因萨罗夫强忍着头痛，第二次去拜访那个退休的律师。退休的律师一边聚精会神地听着因萨罗夫的话，一边从画有一位丰满乳房的美女的鼻烟盒中抽着鼻烟，并且用他那双狡猾的、跟鼻烟壶一样颜色的小眼睛暗自打量着他的客人。他听完了因萨罗夫的话，让因萨罗夫把“所说的实际情况说得更清楚一点儿”。不过他看出因萨罗夫不愿透露详情（事实上因萨罗夫来见他也是很不情愿的），他便只让因萨罗夫准备好最关键的“必需品”，然后再过来。“当你，”他一边从开着的鼻烟盒里吸着鼻烟一边说，“更有自信、不再羞怯的时候再来。”（他用很重的口音说。）“护照嘛，”他仿佛自言自语地说道，“是可以安排好的。比如说，您在外出游时，没有人能分清您到底是玛丽亚·布雷迪欣还是卡罗利娜·沃格尔迈尔？”因萨罗夫突然感到很不舒服，但他还是万分感谢了律师，说自己一两天后就会过来。
CHAPTER I: He decided to consult (of course mentioning no names) one of his acquaintances, an attorney, retired from practice, or perhaps struck off the rolls, an old and experienced hand at all sorts of clandestine business.This worthy person did not live near; Insarov was a whole hour in getting to him in a very sorry droshky, and, to make matters worse, he did not find him at home; and on his way back got soaked to the skin by a sudden downpour of rain.The next morning, in spite of a rather severe headache, Insarov set off a second time to call on the retired attorney.The retired attorney listened to him attentively, taking snuff from a snuff-box decorated with a picture of a full-bosomed nymph, and glancing stealthily at his visitor with his sly, and also snuff-coloured little eyes; he heard him to the end, and then demanded ‘greater definiteness in the statement of the facts of the case’; and observing that Insarov was unwilling to launch into particulars (it was against the grain that he had come to him at all) he confined himself to the advice to provide himself above all things with ‘the needful,’ and asked him to come to him again, ‘when you have,’ he added, sniffing at the snuff in the open snuff-box, ‘augmented your confidence and decreased your diffidence’ (he talked with a broad accent).‘A passport,’ he added, as though to himself, ‘is a thing that can be arranged; you go a journey, for instance; who’s to tell whether you’re Marya Bredihin or Karolina Vogel-meier?’A feeling of nausea came over Insarov, but he thanked the attorney, and promised to come to him again in a day or two.

第一章: 当晚，他去了斯塔霍夫家。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜热情地招待了他，还略带怪罪地说他不应该把他们忘光了。她看见他脸色苍白，还特意询问了他的身体状况。尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇一句话也没有对他说，只是带着一种复杂的、无所谓的好奇之情打量着他。舒宾对他十分冷淡，但是埃琳娜却让他吃惊不已。她一直都在等他。她特意为他穿了那件他们第一次在小教堂见面时穿的衣服。她很平静地欢迎了他，很有礼貌，笑得很自然，任何人都看不出这个女孩的命运已经注定，看不出让她光彩照人、举止灵巧动人的仅仅是心底暗藏的那份甜蜜的爱意。她替卓娅为客人倒茶，开着玩笑，闲聊着。她知道舒宾会观察她，而因萨罗夫不会掩饰自己，无法表现得漠不关心，所以她提前做好了准备。她是对的。舒宾的视线从没有离开过她，而因萨罗夫整个晚上都显得沉默、郁郁寡欢。埃琳娜却非常高兴，甚至一度想要去戏弄一下他。
CHAPTER I: The same evening he went to the Stahovs.Anna Vassilyevna met him cordially, reproached him a little for having quite forgotten them, and, finding him pale, inquired especially after his health.Nikolai Artemyevitch did not say a single word to him; he only stared at him with elaborately careless curiosity; Shubin treated him coldly; but Elena astounded him.She was expecting him; she had put on for him the very dress she wore on the day of their first interview in the chapel; but she welcomed him so calmly, and was so polite and carelessly gay, that no one looking at her could have believed that this girl’s fate was already decided, and that it was only the secret consciousness of happy love that gave fire to her features, lightness and charm to all her gestures.She poured out tea in Zoya’s place, jested, chattered; she knew Shubin would be watching her, that Insarov was incapable of wearing a mask, and incapable of appearing indifferent, and she had prepared herself beforehand.She was not mistaken; Shubin never took his eyes off her, and Insarov was very silent and gloomy the whole evening.Elena was so happy that she even felt an inclination to tease him.

第一章: “哦，顺便问一下，”她突然对他说道，“你的计划一切都还顺利吧？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Oh, by the way,’ she said to him suddenly, ‘is your plan getting on at all?’

第一章: 因萨罗夫一惊。
CHAPTER I: Insarov was taken aback.

第一章: “什么计划？”他问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What plan?’ he said.

第一章: “怎么，你忘了吗？”她朝他笑着，只有他才能明白这种幸福的笑，“你给俄国读者编的保加利亚文选啊？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why, have you forgotten?’ she rejoined, laughing in his face; he alone could tell the meaning of that happy laugh: ‘Your Bulgarian selections for Russian readers?’

第一章: “荒唐！”尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇低声嘀咕着。
CHAPTER I: ‘Quelle bourde!’ muttered Nikolai Artemyevitch between his teeth.

第一章: 卓娅在钢琴前坐下。埃琳娜轻微地耸了耸肩，向因萨罗夫使了个眼色，暗示他向门口看去。然后她慢慢地用手指头敲了两下桌子，看了看他。他知道她的意思是跟他约定在两天后见面。她看到他清楚了自己的想法，就朝他笑了笑。因萨罗夫起身准备告辞，他感觉很不舒服。库尔纳托夫斯基到了。尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇跳了起来，将右手高高抬起过头，然后缓缓放下，握住高级秘书先生的手掌。因萨罗夫本可以再多留一会儿看看他的情敌。埃琳娜轻轻摇了摇头，主人也觉得没有介绍他们两人认识的必要，于是因萨罗夫就离开了，在走之前跟埃琳娜最后一次交换了眼神。舒宾想了又想，干脆以一个自己不懂的法律问题与库尔纳托夫斯基展开了激烈的辩论。
CHAPTER I: Zoya sat down to the piano.Elena gave a just perceptible shrug of the shoulders, and with her eyes motioned Insarov to the door.Then she twice slowly touched the table with her finger, and looked at him.He understood that she was promising to see him in two days, and she gave him a quick smile when she saw he understood her.Insarov got up and began to take leave; he felt unwell.Kurnatovsky arrived.Nikolai Artemyevitch jumped up, raised his right hand higher than his head, and softly dropped it into the palm of the chief secretary.Insarov would have remained a few minutes longer, to have a look at his rival.Elena shook her head unseen; the host did not think it necessary to introduce them to one another, and Insarov departed, exchanging one last look with Elena.Shubin pondered and pondered, and threw himself into a fierce argument with Kurnatovsky on a legislative question, about which he had not a single idea.

第一章: 因萨罗夫辗转难眠了一整夜，到了早上，他觉得很难受，但他还是开始整理文件和写信，可他觉得头昏昏沉沉的。到了晚餐时间，他开始发烧，什么也吃不下去。晚上，他的体温急剧升高，四肢酸痛，头也痛得厉害。因萨罗夫躺在那张埃琳娜不久前刚坐过的小沙发上，思索着：“这真是自作自受，我怎么会去找那个老无赖啊。”他试着让自己睡着……但是病痛此时已经完全地缠上了他。他的脉搏剧烈地跳动着，血液像在燃烧一样，思绪像鸟一样飞来飞去。他已经不省人事了。他像是被人在脸上打了一拳一样躺在那里。突然他似乎听到有人在耳边轻声笑着、窃窃私语，他挣扎着睁开双眼，燃烧的蜡烛发出的光芒像利刃一样刺进了他的眼睛……这是怎么了？老律师站在他的面前，披着一件东方式的丝质长袍，腰带上还别了一块丝绸手帕，就像昨晚看到的那样……“卡罗利娜·沃格尔迈尔。”他那掉光了牙的嘴喃喃地说。因萨罗夫看着他，那个老人变得很宽、很厚、很高，他不再是一个人了，他变成了一棵树……因萨罗夫只能抓着扭曲的树枝往上爬。他紧抱着树枝，却掉了下来，胸口撞在一块尖石头上。卡罗利娜·沃格尔迈尔正蹲在那里，像个女商贩一样，用模糊的声音叫卖着：“馅饼，馅饼，卖馅饼啦。”一旁不断有血液喷涌而出，刀锋也闪耀着寒光……埃琳娜！一切消失于血红色的混沌之中。
CHAPTER I: Insarov did not sleep all night, and in the morning he felt very ill; he set to work, however, putting his papers into order and writing letters, but his head was heavy and confused.At dinner time he began to be in a fever; he could eat nothing.The fever grew rapidly worse towards evening; he had aching pains in all his limbs, and a terrible headache.Insarov lay down on the very little sofa on which Elena had lately sat; he thought: ‘It serves me right for going to that old rascal,’ and he tried to sleep….But the illness had by now complete mastery of him.His veins were throbbing violently, his blood was on fire, his thoughts were flying round like birds.He sank into forgetfulness.He lay like a man felled by a blow on his face, and suddenly, it seemed to him, some one was softly laughing and whispering over him: he opened his eyes with an effort, the light of the flaring candle smote him like a knife….What was it?the old attorney was before him in an Oriental silk gown belted with a silk handkerchief, as he had seen him the evening before….‘Karolina Vogelmeier,’ muttered his toothless mouth.Insarov stared, and the old man grew wide and thick and tall, he was no longer a man, he was a tree….Insarov had to climb along its gnarled branches.He clung, and fell with his breast on a sharp stone, and Karolina Vogelmeier was sitting on her heels, looking like a pedlar-woman, and lisping: ‘Pies, pies, pies for sale’; and there were streams of blood and swords flashing incessantly….Elena!And everything vanished is a crimson chaos.

第一章: 第二十五章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXV

第一章: “有个人在外面，看起来像个锁匠之类的。”第二天傍晚，别尔谢涅夫那个举止得体却对他疑神疑鬼的仆人对他说道，“他说是来拜访您的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘There’s some one here looks like a locksmith or something of the sort,’ Bersenyev was informed the following evening by his servant, who was distinguished by a severe deportment and sceptical turn of mind towards his master; ‘he wants to see you.’

第一章: “让他进来吧。”别尔谢涅夫说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Ask him in,’ said Bersenyev.

第一章: 那个“锁匠”走了进来。别尔谢涅夫认出他就是那个裁缝，因萨罗夫的房东。
CHAPTER I: The ‘locksmith’ entered.Bersenyev recognised in him the tailor, the landlord of Insarov’s lodgings.

第一章: “请问有何贵干？”别尔谢涅夫问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What do you want?’ he asked him.

第一章: “我是专程来找您的，阁下。”裁缝说，他的两只脚不停地挪动，不时地晃晃用最后三根手指捏着袖口的右手。“我的那个房客，好像病得很重。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I came to your honour,’ began the tailor, shifting from one foot to the other, and at times waving his right hand with his cuff clutched in his three last fingers.‘Our lodger, seemingly, is very ill.’

第一章: “因萨罗夫？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Insarov?’

第一章: “是的，我们的房客，肯定是他。他昨天早上还好好的，到了晚上却什么都不想吃，只要了水，我夫人就给他端了水过去，但是到了夜里，他就开始大吼大叫了，我们隔着一堵墙都听得一清二楚，而今天早上，他像跟木头似的躺在那里一动不动，发着高烧。愿主保佑我们！我想，我敢保证，他肯定会死，我想我应该向警察局汇报一声。因为他孤身一人。不过，我妻子说‘你去找找他的那个朋友，那个和我们房客一起住在乡下的人，也许他会告诉你该怎么办，或者他会亲自过来一趟。’所以我就来找阁下您了，我们也没有办法，就是说……”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, our lodger, to be sure; yesterday morning he was still on his legs, in the evening he asked for nothing but drink; the missis took him some water, and at night he began talking away; we could hear him through the partition-wall; and this morning he lies without a word like a log, and the fever he’s in, Lord have mercy on us!I thought, upon my word, he’ll die for sure; I ought to send word to the police station, I thought.For he’s so alone; but the missis said: “Go to that gentleman,” she says, “at whose country place our lodger stayed; maybe he’ll tell you what to do, or come himself.” So I’ve come to your honour, for we can’t, so to say—’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫拽过自己的帽子，给了裁缝一卢布，立马和他一同坐着马车赶往因萨罗夫租住的房间。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev snatched up his cap, thrust a rouble into the tailor’s hand, and at once set off with him post haste to Insarov’s lodgings.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫发现因萨罗夫穿着衣服、人事不省地躺在沙发上。他的脸色变得很难看。别尔谢涅夫立刻让房东给他脱了衣服并把他抬到床上，自己则飞奔出去，找了一个医生过来。医生立刻开了水蛭、芥末膏、甘汞，并且给他放血。
CHAPTER I: He found him lying on the sofa, unconscious and not undressed.His face was terribly changed.Bersenyev at once ordered the people of the house to undress him and put him to bed, while he rushed off himself and returned with a doctor.The doctor prescribed leeches, mustard-poultices, and calomel, and ordered him to be bled.

第一章: “他有生命危险吗？”别尔谢涅夫问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Is he dangerously ill?’ asked Bersenyev.

第一章: “有的，非常危险。”医生回答道，“是急性肺炎，已经恶化成传染性胸膜炎了，大脑可能已经受到感染，不过好在病人还年轻。他正在与病魔抗争。我到这里的时候就已经太晚了，但是我还是会按照科学的方法来为他治疗、全力以赴。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, very dangerously,’ answered the doctor.‘Severe inflammation of the lungs; peripneumonia fully developed, and the brain perhaps affected, but the patient is young.His very strength is something against him now.I was sent for too late; still we will do all that science dictates.’

第一章: 医生很年轻，也相信科学。
CHAPTER I: The doctor was young himself, and still believed in science.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫在那里留了一整夜。房东夫妇似乎都是热心肠的人，只要有人吩咐，他们就立刻去做。医生的助手到了，然后开始了治疗。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev stayed the night.The people of the house seemed kind, and even prompt directly there was some one to tell them what was to be done.An assistant arrived, and began to carry out the medical measures.

第一章: 将近清晨的时候，因萨罗夫醒了一小会儿，认出了别尔谢涅夫，问：“我生病了么？”他用重病患者所有的茫然、无神、困惑的眼光看向别尔谢涅夫周围，然后又昏睡了过去。别尔谢涅夫回了趟家，换了衣服，带了几本书，又回到因萨罗夫租住的房间。他下定决心至少要在那里呆上一段时间。他用屏风把因萨罗夫的床隔开，然后用沙发给自己弄了个休息的地方。这一天过得漫长又乏味。别尔谢涅夫除了用餐以外，其他时间都一直留在房间里面。夜幕降临了。他点上蜡烛，用灯罩罩了起来，然后开始看书。周围一片寂静。透过隔墙可以听见房东夫妇悄悄说话的声音，接着是哈欠声，还有叹息声。有人打了个喷嚏，随后被人小声地咒骂了一句。隔着屏风能听到病人低沉而急促的呼吸声，夹杂着几声短促的呻吟声和头不安地在枕头上磨蹭的声音……一个怪异的场景浮现在别尔谢涅夫眼前。他发现自己如今身处的这个房间的主人命悬一线，他也知道，埃琳娜爱着这个人……他依然记得那个夜晚，舒宾赶上他后清楚地告诉他，埃琳娜爱的是他，是他，别尔谢涅夫！可是现在……“现在我该怎么做呢？”他问着自己，“让埃琳娜知道他生病了？还是等等再说？这件事比以往我跟她讲的任何事都要糟糕。不可思议的是，命运总要让我夹在他们两人之间！”他下定决心过一阵子再跟埃琳娜说。他的目光落在了堆满信纸的桌子上……“他能完成他的梦想吗？”别尔谢涅夫思索着，“这一切会不会成为一场空呢？”他为这个被病魔击倒的年轻人而感到惋惜，他发誓，自己要尽可能地拯救他。
CHAPTER I: Towards morning Insarov revived for a few minutes, recognised Bersenyev, asked: ‘Am I ill, then?’ looked about him with the vague, listless bewilderment of a man dangerously ill, and again relapsed into unconsciousness.Bersenyev went home, changed his clothes, and, taking a few books along with him, he returned to Insarov’s lodgings.He made up his mind to stay there, at least for a time.He shut in Insarov’s bed with screens, and arranged a little place for himself by the sofa.The day passed slowly and drearily.Bersenyev did not leave the room except to get his dinner.The evening came.He lighted a candle with a shade, and settled down to a book.Everything was still around.Through the partition wall could be heard suppressed whispering in the landlord’s room, then a yawn, and a sigh.Some one sneezed, and was scolded in a whisper; behind the screen was heard the patient’s heavy, uneven breathing, sometimes broken by a short groan, and the uneasy tossing of his head on the pillow….Strange fancies came over Bersenyev.He found himself in the room of a man whose life was hanging on a thread, the man whom, as he knew, Elena loved….He remembered that night when Shubin had overtaken him and declared that she loved him, him, Bersenyev!And now….‘What am I to do now?’ he asked himself.‘Let Elena know of his illness?Wait a little?This would be worse news for her than what I told her once before; strange how fate makes me the go-between between them!’He made up his mind that it was better to wait a little.His eyes fell on the table covered with heaps of papers…‘Will he carry out his dreams?’ thought Bersenyev.‘Can it be that all will come to nothing?’And he was filled with pity for the young life struck down, and he vowed to himself to save it.

第一章: 这是个不安之夜。病人说了不少胡话。有几次别尔谢涅夫从小沙发上站起，小心翼翼地走到床的旁边，强忍心中的不安聆听他那断断续续的呓语。只有一次，因萨罗夫突然很清晰地说道：“我不要，我不要，她不能……”别尔谢涅夫吃了一惊，看着因萨罗夫。他的脸看上去非常痛苦，仿佛死人一样，同时又一动不动，他的手无力地放在床上。“我不要。”他用几乎听不到的声音重复着。
CHAPTER I: The night was an uneasy one.The sick man was very delirious.Several times Bersenyev got up from his little sofa, approached the bed on tip-toe, and listened with a heavy heart to his disconnected muttering.Only once Insarov spoke with sudden distinctness: ‘I won’t, I won’t, she mustn’t….’ Bersenyev started and looked at Insarov; his face, suffering and death-like at the same time, was immovable, and his hands lay powerless.‘I won’t,’ he repeated, scarcely audibly.

第一章: 医生第二天一早就来了，摇了摇头，开了一份新的处方。“危险期恐怕还要持续很长时间。”他边说边戴上帽子。
CHAPTER I: The doctor came in the morning, shook his head and wrote fresh prescriptions.‘The crisis is a long way off still,’ he said, putting on his hat.

第一章: “那过了危险期呢？”别尔谢涅夫问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘And after the crisis?’ asked Bersenyev.

第一章: “过了危险期有两种结果，康复，或者死亡。”
CHAPTER I: ‘The crisis may end in two ways, aut Caesar aut nihil.

第一章: 医生说完就离开了。别尔谢涅夫在外面的街道上来回地踱着步，他需要呼吸新鲜空气。他回到房间里，又看起书来。他很早以前就读完了劳默尔的书，现在正在研究格罗特。
CHAPTER I: The doctor went away.Bersenyev walked a few times up and down the street; he felt in need of fresh air.He went back and took up a book again.Raumer he had finished long ago; he was now making a study of Grote.

第一章: 突然，房门咯吱响了一声，房东的女儿小心地露出头来，她像往日一样裹着一块大头巾。
CHAPTER I: Suddenly the door softly creaked, and the head of the landlord’s daughter, covered as usual with a heavy kerchief, was cautiously thrust into the room.

第一章: “那次给了我一个银币的小姐，”她轻轻说道，“她来了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Here is the lady,’ she whispered, ‘who gave me a silver piece.’

第一章: 这个小孩子的头一下子就消失了，埃琳娜走了进来。
CHAPTER I: The child’s head vanished quickly, and in its place appeared Elena.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫像被针刺了一样跳了起来，但是埃琳娜纹丝不动，也没有叫出声来。看样子，她似乎一瞬间什么都清楚了。她的脸色惨白，走到屏风旁边，向后面看了看，抬起手臂，似乎变成了石头。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev jumped up as if he had been stung; but Elena did not stir, nor cry out.It seemed as if she understood everything in a single instant.A terrible pallor overspread her face, she went up to the screen, looked behind it, threw up her arms, and seemed turned to stone.

第一章: 如果再多看一会儿，她会扑到因萨罗夫身上去，但是别尔谢涅夫阻止了她。“你在做什么？”他低声颤抖着说，“你知不知道这样会害死他的！”
CHAPTER I: A moment more and she would have flung herself on Insarov, but Bersenyev stopped her.‘What are you doing?’ he said in a trembling whisper, ‘you might be the death of him!’

第一章: 她有些头昏。别尔谢涅夫把她扶到沙发上坐下。
CHAPTER I: She was reeling.He led her to the sofa, and made her sit down.

第一章: 她看了看他的脸，又从头到脚打量了他一遍，然后呆呆地盯着地板。
CHAPTER I: She looked into his face, then her eyes ran over him from head to foot, then stared at the floor.

第一章: “他会死吗？”她冰冷、平静的语气让别尔谢涅夫一阵毛骨悚然。
CHAPTER I: ‘Will he die?’ she asked so coldly and quietly that Bersenyev was frightened.

第一章: “上帝保佑，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”他说，“你怎么会这样说呢？”“他是病了，而且确实相当严重，但是我们会救他的，我向你保证。”
CHAPTER I: ‘For God’s sake, Elena Nikolaevna,’ he began, ‘what are you saying?He is ill certainly—and rather seriously—but we will save him; I promise you that.’

第一章: “他已经不省人事了？”她的声音依然冰冷、平静。
CHAPTER I: ‘He is unconscious?’ she asked in the same tone of voice as before.

第一章: “是的，他目前还没有醒过来。这是这种病的初期表现，但是这没什么，没什么——我向你保证。喝点儿水吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, he is unconscious at present.That’s always the case at the early stage of these illnesses, but it means nothing, nothing—I assure you.Drink some water.’

第一章: 她把头抬起来看着他，他发现她并没有听到刚才他说了些什么。
CHAPTER I: She raised her eyes to his, and he saw she had not heard his answer.

第一章: “如果他死了，”她还是用那种声音说，“我也会跟他一起死。”
CHAPTER I: ‘If he dies,’ she said in the same voice,‘ I will die too.’

第一章: 在那一刻因萨罗夫轻轻呻吟了一下。她浑身颤抖起来，抱着头，然后她解开了帽带。
CHAPTER I: At that instant Insarov uttered a slight moan; she trembled all over, clutched at her head, then began untying the strings of her hat.

第一章: “你想干什么？”别尔谢涅夫问她。
CHAPTER I: ‘What are you doing?’Bersenyev asked her.

第一章: “我要留在这里。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I will stay here.’

第一章: “你要呆——很久？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You will stay—for long?’

第一章: “我不知道，也许一天，也许一夜，也许一直——我不知道。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t know, perhaps all day, the night, always—I don’t know.’

第一章: “上帝保佑，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，你不要激动。我无论如何没有想到你会过来，不过，我还是——觉得你应该只能呆一会儿吧。别忘了你的家人会找你的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘For God’s sake, Elena Nikolaevna, control yourself.I could not of course have any expectation of seeing you here; but still I—assume you have come for a short time.Remember they may miss you at home.’

第一章: “那又怎么样？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What then?’

第一章: “他们会到处找你——会找到你——”
CHAPTER I: ‘They will look for you—find you—’

第一章: “然后呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What then?’

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜！你要知道。他现在不能保护你。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena Nikolaevna!You see.He cannot now protect you.’

第一章: 她垂下头，看起来像是在思考，然后把手帕放到嘴边。突然从她的胸口处迸发出不住的抽泣，残暴地撕裂着她。她一头扑到沙发上，尽量忍住哭声，但是她的身体还是像刚被捉住的小鸟一样浑身颤抖着。
CHAPTER I: She dropped her head, seemed lost in thought, raised a handkerchief to her lips, and convulsive sobs, tearing her by their violence, were suddenly wrung from her breast.She threw herself, face downwards, on the sofa, trying to stifle them, but still her body heaved and throbbed like a captured bird.

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜——上帝保佑。”别尔谢涅夫在她头上重复着。
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena Nikolaevna—for God’s sake,’ Bersenyev was repeating over her.

第一章: “啊！怎么了？”因萨罗夫的声音突然响起。
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah!What is it?’ suddenly sounded the voice of Insarov.

第一章: 埃琳娜惊得直起身来，别尔谢涅夫也在原地愣住了。过了片刻，他走到床前。因萨罗夫的头还是像原来那样无力地靠在枕头上，闭着眼睛。
CHAPTER I: Elena started up, and Bersenyev felt rooted to the spot.After waiting a little, he went up to the bed.Insarov’s head lay on the pillow helpless as before; his eyes were closed.

第一章: “他是在说胡话吗？”埃琳娜轻轻问。
CHAPTER I: ‘Is he delirious?’ whispered Elena.

第一章: “也许吧，”别尔谢涅夫说，“不过这没什么，他总是这样，特别是——”
CHAPTER I: ‘It seems so,’ answered Bersenyev, ‘but that’s nothing; it’s always so, especially if—’

第一章: “他是什么时候病倒的？”埃琳娜打断他。
CHAPTER I: ‘When was he taken ill?’Elena broke in.

第一章: “前天，我是昨天到这里的。相信我，埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜。我会一直守护着他的，一切都会好的。如果需要的话，我们会进行会诊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘The day before yesterday; I have been here since yesterday.Rely on me, Elena Nikolaevna.I will not leave him; everything shall be done.If necessary, we will have a consultation.’

第一章: “他会死去，而我不在他身边。”她哭着说，双手用力握着。
CHAPTER I: ‘He will die without me,’ she cried, wringing her hands.

第一章: “我向你保证我会每天告诉你他病情的变化，如果有危险的话——”
CHAPTER I: ‘I give you my word I will let you hear every day how his illness goes on, and if there should be immediate danger—’

第一章: “请你向我发誓，你会立刻写个纸条给我，不论是白天还是黑夜，直接写个纸条给我，我现在什么都不在乎了。你听见了吗？你能向我保证你会这样做吗？”
CHAPTER I: ’Swear you will send for me at once whenever it may be, day or night, write a note straight to me—I care for nothing now.Do you hear?you promise you will do that?’

第一章: “我在上帝面前保证。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I promise before God.’

第一章: “发誓。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Swear it.’

第一章: “我发誓！”
CHAPTER I: ‘I swear.’

第一章: 她突然抓住他的手，赶在他缩回去之前，弯下腰吻了上去。
CHAPTER I: She suddenly snatched his hand, and before he had time to pull it away, she had bent and pressed her lips to it.

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，你——”他结结巴巴地说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena Nikolaevna, what are you—’ he stammered.

第一章: “不——不——我不要——”因萨罗夫含糊地说，然后痛苦地叹了口气。
CHAPTER I: ‘No—no—I won’t have it—’ Insarov muttered indistinctly, and sighed painfully.

第一章: 埃琳娜走到屏风前，咬着手帕，久久地看着那个病人。眼泪静静地从她的脸颊滑落下来。
CHAPTER I: Elena went up to the screen, her handkerchief pressed between her teeth, and bent a long, long look on the sick man.Silent tears rolled down her cheeks.

第一章: “埃琳娜·尼古拉耶夫娜，”别尔谢涅夫对她说，“他要是清醒过来看到你的话，天知道，这会不会刺激到他。另外，我一直在等着医生来。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena Nikolaevna,’ Bersenyev said to her, ‘he might come to himself and recognise you; there’s no knowing if that wouldn’t do harm.Besides, from hour to hour I expect the doctor.’

第一章: 埃琳娜把帽子从沙发上拿起来戴上，然后静静地站着。她用悲痛的目光扫视了这间屋子。她仿佛想起来什么似的……
CHAPTER I: Elena took her hat from the sofa, put it on and stood still.Her eyes strayed mournfully over the room.She seemed to be remembering….

第一章: “我不能走啊！”她最后轻轻地说。
CHAPTER I: ‘I cannot go away,’ she whispered at last.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫抓紧她的手。“你要振作起来，”他说，“平静下来，我会照顾好他的。我今天晚上就去找你。”
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev pressed her hand: ‘Try to pull yourself together,’ he said, ‘calm yourself; you are leaving him in my care.I will come to you this very evening.’

第一章: 埃琳娜看着他说：“哦，我好心的朋友！”然后便呜咽着跑了出去。
CHAPTER I: Elena looked at him, said: ‘Oh, my good, kind friend!’ broke into sobs and rushed away.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫靠在墙上。一种难过、苦涩却又奇怪地带点儿欣慰的感觉笼罩了他的心。“我好心的朋友！”他想了想，耸了耸肩。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev leaned against the door.A feeling of sorrow and bitterness, not without a kind of strange consolation, overcame him.‘My good, kind friend!’ he thought and shrugged his shoulders.

第一章: “谁在这里？”他听见因萨罗夫的声音。
CHAPTER I: ‘Who is here?’ he heard Insarov’s voice.

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫走到他的旁边。“是我在这里，德米特里·尼卡诺罗维奇。你还好吗？感觉怎么样？”
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev went up to him.‘I am here, Dmitri Nikanorovitch.How are you?How do you feel?’

第一章: “就你一个人吗？”病人问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Are you alone?’ asked the sick man.

第一章: “是啊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.’

第一章: “那她呢？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And she?’

第一章: “你说的是谁？”别尔谢涅夫有些惊慌地问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Whom do you mean?’Bersenyev asked almost in dismay.

第一章: 因萨罗夫没有回答。“木犀香水味。”他喃喃地说着又闭上了眼睛。
CHAPTER I: Insarov was silent.‘Mignonette,’ he murmured, and his eyes closed again.

第一章: 第二十六章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXVI

第一章: 因萨罗夫在生与死之间徘徊了八天八夜。医生也不时地过来探望他，像年轻人对待难题时那样兴趣浓厚。舒宾听说了因萨罗夫危险的处境，询问了他的病情。他的同胞们——几个保加利亚人——来了。别尔谢涅夫认出了其中两个奇怪的人，他们就是之前突然到别墅找因萨罗夫，让他感到疑惑的人。他们都对此事表现出了真挚的同情，有些人还表示说要代替别尔谢涅夫在床前照顾因萨罗夫，但是他一直牢记对埃琳娜的承诺因此没有答应。他每天都去找埃琳娜，秘密地——有时直接说给她听，有时写一个字条——向她报告因萨罗夫的详细病情。她每天都急切地期盼他的到来，仔细听他说的话，认真地向他询问。她一直想去亲自探望因萨罗夫，但是别尔谢涅夫请求她不要这样做：这几天因萨罗夫身边总有人。她得知因萨罗夫生病的第一天自己也差点儿病倒了。她一回到家中就把自己关在了房间中，但又被叫去吃晚餐。她出现在餐厅的时候脸色十分可怕，把安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜吓得赶忙让她到床上去休息。无论如何，埃琳娜还是成功地控制住了自己的情绪。“如果他死了，”她重复着，“那我就跟着他一起死。”这个念头让她平静了下来，让她看起来镇静了一些。而且，谁也没去打扰她。安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜忙着治疗她那肿胀的脸；舒宾疯狂地埋头于工作之中；卓娅也陷入了哀思之中，读起了《维特》；尼古拉·阿尔捷米耶维奇对别尔谢涅夫“这位学者”的频繁造访非常反感，尤其因为他那与库尔纳托夫斯基有关的“倍受珍视的计划”没有任何进展；务实的高级秘书也十分困扰，等待着合适的时机。埃琳娜甚至没有向别尔谢涅夫致谢。向某些帮助致谢反而是件残酷、可耻的事。只是在他第四次造访时——那天夜里因萨罗夫的情况非常糟糕，医生也暗示需要一次会诊——只是在那时，她才提醒别尔谢涅夫曾许下的诺言。“很好，那我们走吧。”他对她说，她起身正准备穿衣服。“不，”他又决定说，“还是等到明天再去吧。”快到晚上的时候，因萨罗夫的情况有所好转。
CHAPTER I: For eight whole days Insarov lay between life and death.The doctor was incessantly visiting him, interested as a young man in a difficult case.Shubin heard of Insarov’s critical position, and made inquiries after him.His compatriots—Bulgarians—came; among them Bersenyev recognised the two strange figures, who had puzzled him by their unexpected visit to the cottage; they all showed genuine sympathy, some offered to take Bersenyev’s place by the patient’s bed-side; but he would not consent to that, remembering his promise to Elena.He saw her every day and secretly reported to her—sometimes by word of mouth, sometimes in a brief note—every detail of the illness.With what sinkings of the heart she awaited him, how she listened and questioned him!She was always on the point of hastening to Insarov herself; but Bersenyev begged her not to do this: Insarov was seldom alone.On the first day she knew of his illness she herself had almost fallen ill; directly she got home, she shut herself up in her room; but she was summoned to dinner, and appeared in the dining-room with such a face that Anna Vassilyevna was alarmed, and was anxious to put her to bed.Elena succeeded, however, in controlling herself.‘If he dies,’ she repeated, ‘it will be the end of me too.’This thought tranquillised her, and enabled her to seem indifferent.Besides no one troubled her much; Anna Vassilyevna was taken up with her swollen face; Shubin was working furiously; Zoya was given up to pensiveness, and disposed to read Werther; Nikolai Artemyevitch was much displeased at the frequent visits of ‘the scholar,’ especially as his ‘cherished projects’ in regard to Kurnatovsky were making no way; the practical chief secretary was puzzled and biding his time.Elena did not even thank Bersenyev; there are services for which thanks are cruel and shameful.Only once at her fourth interview with him—Insarov had passed a very bad night, the doctor had hinted at a consultation—only then she reminded him of his promise.‘Very well, then let us go,’ he said to her.She got up and was going to get ready.‘No,’ he decided, ‘let us wait till to-morrow.’Towards evening Insarov was rather better.

第一章: 这种折磨足足持续了八天。埃琳娜表面上很平静，但她日不能食，夜不能寐。她感觉四肢麻木，脑子里像充满了一种干燥的烟雾一样。“我的小姐像蜡烛一样越来越削瘦了。”她的女佣这样描述她。
CHAPTER I: For eight days this torture was prolonged.Elena appeared calm; but she could eat nothing, and did not sleep at night.There was a dull ache in all her limbs; her head seemed full of a sort of dry burning smoke.‘Our young lady’s wasting like a candle,’ her maid said of her.

第一章: 到了第九天，病人总算度过了危险期。在客厅中，埃琳娜坐在安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜旁边，给母亲读着《莫斯科公报》，却不知道自己到底在做什么。别尔谢涅夫走了进来。埃琳娜看了他一眼——每次她看他的第一眼都是那么迅速、恐惧、敏锐、战战兢兢——然后立刻就发现，他带来的是好消息。他面带笑容，轻轻朝她点了点头，她站起身来走到他旁边。
CHAPTER I: At last by the ninth day the crisis was passing over.Elena was sitting in the drawing-room near Anna Vassilyevna, and, without knowing herself what she was doing, was reading her the Moscow Gazette; Bersenyev came in.Elena glanced at him—how rapid, and fearful, and penetrating, and tremulous, was the first glance she turned on him every time—and at once she guessed that he brought good news.He was smiling; he nodded slightly to her, she got up to go and meet him.

第一章: “他已经恢复意识了，命总算是保住了，一个星期内他就能恢复如初了。”他悄悄对她说。
CHAPTER I: ‘He has regained consciousness, he is saved, he will be quite well again in a week,’ he whispered to her.

第一章: 埃琳娜像是挡住袭击一样伸开双臂，她一句话都没说，只有嘴唇在轻轻颤抖，脸上流露出美丽的红晕。别尔谢涅夫开始与安娜·瓦西里耶夫娜聊天，而埃琳娜走进自己的房间，跪倒在地，开始祈祷，感谢上帝。晶莹的泪水流过她的脸颊。她突然觉得非常疲倦，便把头放在枕头上，喃喃了一句：“可怜的安德烈·彼得罗维奇！”然后带着湿湿的睫毛和脸颊进入了梦乡。她已经很久没有休息和哭泣过了。
CHAPTER I: Elena had stretched out her arm as though to ward off a blow, and she said nothing, only her lips trembled and a flush of crimson overspread her whole face.Bersenyev began to talk to Anna Vassilyevna, and Elena went off to her own room, dropped on her knees and fell to praying, to thanking God.Light, shining tears trickled down her cheeks.Suddenly she was conscious of intense weariness, laid her head down on the pillow, whispered ‘poor Andrei Petrovitch!’ and at once fell asleep with wet cheeks and eyelashes.It was long since she had slept or wept.

第一章: 第二十七章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXVII

第一章: 事实证明别尔谢涅夫的话只说对了一部分。因萨罗夫虽然脱离了生命危险，但是身体恢复得非常缓慢，医生说他的整个身体系统都受到了严重的损伤。尽管如此，病人还是从床上爬了起来，开始在屋子里来回走动。别尔谢涅夫也回到自己的家中，但是他每天都会过来看望这位仍然虚弱的朋友，也像往常那样每天把因萨罗夫的身体状况告诉埃琳娜。因萨罗夫不敢写信给她，只是在与别尔谢涅夫的谈话中拐弯抹角地提起她，但是别尔谢涅夫却装作无所谓的样子，告诉因萨罗夫他曾多次拜访斯塔霍夫家，千方百计地让他知道埃琳娜之前有多么难过，而现在已经平静多了。埃琳娜也没有写信给因萨罗夫，她心里已经有了一个计划。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev’s words turned out only partly true; the danger was over, but Insarov gained strength slowly, and the doctor talked of a complete undermining of the whole system.The patient left his bed for all that, and began to walk about the room; Bersenyev went home to his own lodging, but he came every day to his still feeble friend; and every day as before he informed Elena of the state of his health.Insarov did not dare to write to her, and only indirectly in his conversations with Bersenyev referred to her; but Bersenyev, with assumed carelessness, told him about his visits to the Stahovs, trying, however, to give him to understand that Elena had been deeply distressed, and that now she was calmer.Elena too did not write to Insarov; she had a plan in her head.

第一章: 一天，别尔谢涅夫兴高采烈地来告诉她医生已经允许因萨罗夫吃些肉饼了，也许用不了多久他就能走出房门了，但她看起来却在发愣，头垂得很低。
CHAPTER I: One day Bersenyev had just informed her with a cheerful face that the doctor had already allowed Insarov to eat a cutlet, and that he would probably soon go out; she seemed absorbed, dropped her eyes.

第一章: “你能猜出我想对你说什么吗？”她说。别尔谢涅夫感到困惑。他知道她在想什么。
CHAPTER I: ‘Guess, what I want to say to you,’ she said.Bersenyev was confused.He understood her.

第一章: “我猜，”他看向别处，说道，“你想说你希望去探望他。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I suppose,’ he answered, looking away, ‘you want to say that you wish to see him.’

第一章: 埃琳娜涨得满脸通红，然后非常小声地说：“是的。”
CHAPTER I: Elena crimsoned, and scarcely audibly, she breathed, ‘Yes.’

第一章: “行啊，这有什么问题呢？我想这件事对你来说再简单不过了。”“呃！”他想着，“我的心里怎么会这么不情愿啊！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, what then?That, I imagine, you can easily do.’—‘Ugh!’ he thought, ‘what a loath-some feeling there is in my heart!’

第一章: “你的意思是我已经……”埃琳娜说，“但是我害怕的是——你说过，他房间里经常有人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You mean that I have already before…’ said Elena.‘But I am afraid—now he is, you say, seldom alone.’

第一章: “这个问题不难解决。”别尔谢涅夫回答说，仍旧不看向她，“这件事自然不能由我事先提醒他，但你可以写个字条，我帮你给他。谁能阻止你给你关心的好朋友写个字条呢？这无伤大雅。约定——我的意思是，你写个字条告诉他你什么时候到。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That’s not difficult to get over,’ replied Bersenyev, still not looking at her.‘I, of course, cannot prepare him; but give me a note.Who can hinder your writing to him as a good friend, in whom you take an interest?There’s no harm in that.Appoint—I mean, write to him when you will come.

第一章: “我有点儿不好意思。”埃琳娜嘀咕道。
CHAPTER I: ‘I am ashamed,’ whispered Elena.

第一章: “把条子给我吧，我这就拿走。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Give me the note, I will take it.’

第一章: “倒也不用那样，我只是想请求你——别生我的气，安德烈·彼得罗维奇——明天别去他那里！”
CHAPTER I: ‘There’s no need of that, but I wanted to ask you—don’t be angry with me, Andrei Petrovitch—don’t go to him to-morrow!’

第一章: 别尔谢涅夫咬了咬嘴唇。
CHAPTER I: Bersenyev bit his lip.

第一章: “啊！是的，我知道，清楚，清楚。”他补充了这两三个字后便赶紧告辞了。
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah! yes, I understand; very well, very well,’ and, adding two or three words more, he quickly took leave.

第一章: “这样更好，这样更好。”他思索着，匆匆回到家里，“我什么都不知道，但是这样更好。我是怎么了，怎么想着把我自己和别人的幸福快乐绑在一起呢？我一点儿也不后悔，我凭着良心做了该做的事，而现在，一切都结束了。随他们去吧！父亲过去跟我说的是对的，‘你和我，我亲爱的小伙子，我们不是纵欲好色之徒，我们也不是达官贵人，我们都不受命运和上天的青睐，我们甚至都不能成为殉道者——我们就只是干活的人，仅此而已。穿上你的皮围裙吧，干活的人，坐到你的工作椅上去，呆在你那昏暗的作坊里，让阳光去照耀别的人吧！即使是我们单调呆板的生活也有它自己的骄傲和快乐啊！’”
CHAPTER I: ‘So much the better, so much the better,’ he thought, as he hurried home.‘I have learnt nothing new, but so much the better.What possessed me to go hanging on to the edge of another man’s happiness?I regret nothing; I have done what my conscience told me; but now it is over.Let them be!My father was right when he used to say to me: “You and I, my dear boy, are not Sybarites, we are not aristocrats, we’re not the spoilt darlings of fortune and nature, we are not even martyrs—we are workmen and nothing more.Put on your leather apron, workman, and take your place at your workman’s bench, in your dark workshop, and let the sun shine on other men!Even our dull life has its own pride, its own happiness!”’

第一章: 第二天一早，邮递员就给因萨罗夫送去一封短信。“等着我吧，”埃琳娜写道，“不要让任何人去看你。A. P. 也不会去。”
CHAPTER I: The next morning Insarov got a brief note by the post.‘Expect me,’ Elena wrote to him, ‘and give orders for no one to see you.A. P. will not come.’

第一章: 第二十八章
CHAPTER I: CHAPTER XXVIII

第一章: 因萨罗夫一看完埃琳娜的信就开始着手整理房间。他叫女房东把装药的瓶瓶罐罐收走，自己脱下睡衣，穿上外套。他的头晕乎乎的，心也因为虚弱和喜悦而悸动不已。他的腿颤颤巍巍的。他一屁股坐到沙发上，然后开始看表。“现在十二点还差一刻。”他自言自语道，“她十二点之前肯定来不了，现在还有十五分钟，我得想点别的什么，不然我会崩溃的。在十二点之前她无论如何到不了。”
CHAPTER I: Insarov read Elena’s note, and at once began to set his room to rights; asked his landlady to take away the medicine-glasses, took off his dressing-gown and put on his coat.His head was swimming and his heart throbbing from weakness and delight.His knees were shaking; he dropped on to the sofa, and began to look at his watch.‘It’s now a quarter to twelve,’ he said to himself.‘She can never come before twelve: I will think of something else for a quarter of an hour, or I shall break down altogether.Before twelve she cannot possibly come.’

第一章: 门被打开了，埃琳娜穿着一袭素色丝质长裙走了进来。她脸色有些苍白，浑身充满了朝气和快乐。她快乐地呢喃了一声便扑进了他的怀里。
CHAPTER I: The door was opened, and in a light silk gown, all pale, all fresh, young and joyful, Elena came in, and with a faint cry of delight she fell on his breast.

第一章: “你还活着，你是属于我的。”她一遍又一遍地说着，并且用双手紧紧地抱住他的头，抚摸着。面对这样的亲密、这样的浓情蜜意、这样的幸福，他觉得呼吸困难，快要晕厥过去了。
CHAPTER I: ‘You are alive, you are mine,’ she repeated, embracing and stroking his head.He was almost swooning, breathless at such closeness, such caresses, such bliss.

第一章: 她坐在他的旁边，紧紧地抱住他，开始用双眼凝视着他，眼神里带着微笑，带着关爱和无限的柔情，这种眼神只能在充满爱意的女人眼里找到。
CHAPTER I: She sat down near him, holding him fast, and began to gaze at him with that smiling, and caressing, and tender look, only to be seen shining in the eyes of a loving woman.

第一章: 她的脸庞突然被忧郁笼罩。
CHAPTER I: Her face suddenly clouded over.

第一章: “你现在太瘦了，我可怜的德米特里，”她说着用手去抚摸他的脖子，“你的胡子可真长啊。”
CHAPTER I: ‘How thin you have grown, my poor Dmitri,’ she said, passing her hand over his neck; ‘what a beard you have.’

第一章: “你也瘦了，我可怜的埃琳娜。”他说着把埃琳娜的手贴到了他的嘴唇上。
CHAPTER I: ‘And you have grown thin, my poor Elena,’ he answered, catching her fingers with his lips.

第一章: 她开心地甩了甩头发。
CHAPTER I: She shook her curls gaily.

第一章: “这没什么大不了的。你看着吧，我们很快就能恢复强壮！暴风雨已经过去，就像我们相遇在小教堂那天一样，雨过天晴了。现在，我们要开始我们的生活了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That’s nothing.You shall see how soon we’ll be strong again!The storm has blown over, just as it blew over and passed away that day when we met in the chapel.Now we are going to live.’

第一章: 他仅以一笑当作回答。
CHAPTER I: He answered her with a smile only.

第一章: “德米特里，这段时间，这段时间是多么让人痛彻心扉！没有了爱人，人们怎能独活于世呢？我事先都知道安德烈·彼得罗维奇每天会对我说什么，我真的知道，我的生命跟你的一起潮起潮落。你能康复真好，我的德米特里！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Ah, what a time we have had, Dmitri, what a cruel time!How can people outlive those they love?I knew beforehand what Andrei Petrovitch would say to me every day, I did really; my life seemed to ebb and flow with yours.Welcome back, my Dmitri!’

第一章: 他不知道该跟她说些什么。他只想坐在她的脚边。
CHAPTER I: He did not know what to say to her.He was longing to throw himself at her feet.

第一章: “我还注意到一些事情，”她继续说道，把头发向脑后拢了拢——“在这段闲下来的时间里我发现了好多事情——当一个人非常悲惨的时候，他会傻傻地注意着周围所发生的一切！有些时候，我会盯着一只苍蝇发呆，心里感到非常凄凉和恐惧！但是这一切都过去了，都过去了，不是吗？未来的一切都充满了阳光，不是吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Another thing I observed,’ she went on, pushing back his hair—‘I made so many observations all this time in my leisure—when any one is very, very miserable, with what stupid attention he follows everything that’s going on about him!I really sometimes lost myself in gazing at a fly, and all the while such chill and terror in my heart!But that’s all past, all past, isn’t it?Everything’s bright in the future, isn’t it?’

第一章: “你就是我的未来，”因萨罗夫说，“所以我的未来是光明的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You are for me in the future,’ answered Insarov, ‘so it is bright for me.’

第一章: “对我也是一样的！你还记得吗，有一次我到你这里来，不是上一次，对，不是上一次。”她重复了一遍，身体不自觉地打了个寒颤，“我们说话的时候，我提到了死亡，我也不知道为什么会说起这个，我更没有想到，死神已经在旁边注视着我们。但是，你现在康复了，是吗？”
CHAPTER I: ‘And for me too!But do you remember, when I was here, not the last time—no, not the last time,’ she repeated with an involuntary shudder, ‘when we were talking, I spoke of death, I don’t know why; I never suspected then that it was keeping watch on us.But you are well now, aren’t you?’

第一章: “我现在好多了，我已经快要完全康复了。”
CHAPTER I: ‘I’m much better, I’m nearly well.’

第一章: “你很好，你还活着。哦，我太高兴了！”
CHAPTER I: ‘You are well, you are not dead.Oh, how happy I am!’

第一章: 随之而来的是一阵沉默。
CHAPTER I: A short silence followed.

第一章: “埃琳娜？”因萨罗夫说。
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena?’ said Insarov.

第一章: “怎么了，亲爱的？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Well, my dearest?’

第一章: “告诉我，你有没有想过，这场大病是上天对我们的惩罚？”
CHAPTER I: ‘Tell me, did it never occur to you that this illness was sent us as a punishment?’

第一章: 埃琳娜一脸严肃地看着他。
CHAPTER I: Elena looked seriously at him.

第一章: “我确实这样想过，德米特里。但是我又想，为什么我要受到惩罚呢？我犯了什么罪，我触怒了哪位神明呢？也许我的良心跟别人不一样，但是我无愧于心，又或许我有愧于你？我是你的绊脚石，我拖了你的后腿。”
CHAPTER I: ‘That idea did come into my head, Dmitri.But I thought: what am I to be punished for?What duty have I transgressed, against whom have I sinned?Perhaps my conscience is not like other people’s, but it was silent; or perhaps I am guilty towards you?I hinder you, I stop you.’

第一章: “你没有拖我的后腿，埃琳娜，我们将一起走下去。”
CHAPTER I: ‘You don’t stop me, Elena; we will go together.’

第一章: “好的，德米特里，让我们永远在一起，我将永远追随你……那是我的责任。我爱你……我再没有别的责任。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, Dmitri, let us go together; I will follow you….That is my duty.I love you….I know no other duty.’

第一章: “哦，埃琳娜！”因萨罗夫说，“你的每一句话都像枷锁一样紧紧地束缚住了我！”
CHAPTER I: ‘O Elena!’ said Insarov, ‘what chains every word of yours fastens on me!’

第一章: “怎么会是枷锁呢？”埃琳娜打断他，“我们都是没有羁绊的人，你和我。对的。”她眼睛盯着地板，若有所思，一只手依然在抚摸着他的头发，然后继续说道，“这段时间我经历了很多之前不懂的事情！如果以前有人告诉我，一个家教良好的女士，以各式各样编造出来的理由跑出了家，然后去了哪里呢？去了一个年轻男子的家中——我肯定会愤慨不已！现在，这真的成为了现实，但是我却没有一丝一毫的气愤。真的！”她把头转向因萨罗夫补充道。
CHAPTER I: ‘Why talk of chains?’ she interposed.‘We are free people, you and I. Yes,’ she went on, looking musingly on the floor, while with one hand she still stroked his hair, ‘I experienced much lately of which I had never had any idea!If any one had told me beforehand that I, a young lady, well brought up, should go out from home alone on all sorts of made-up excuses, and to go where? to a young man’s lodgings—how indignant I should have been!And that has all come about, and I feel no indignation whatever.Really!’ she added, and turned to Insarov.

第一章: 他深情款款地注视着她。埃琳娜禁不住轻柔地把手从因萨罗夫的头发上放了下来，蒙住了他的眼睛。
CHAPTER I: He looked at her with such an expression of adoration, that she softly dropped her hand from his hair over his eyes.

第一章: “德米特里！”她说，“你肯定不知道，我看到过你躺在这张可怕的床上，看到过你落入死神的手中、毫无知觉。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Dmitri!’ she began again, ‘you don’t know of course, I saw you there in that dreadful bed, I saw you in the clutches of death, unconscious.’

第一章: “你看到过我？”
CHAPTER I: ‘You saw me?’

第一章: “是的。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes.’

第一章: 他沉默了一下。“那时别尔谢涅夫也在这里？”
CHAPTER I: He was silent for a little.‘And Bersenyev was here?’

第一章: 她点了点头。
CHAPTER I: She nodded.

第一章: 因萨罗夫在埃琳娜跟前俯下身。“哦！埃琳娜！”他悄声说着，“我不敢看你了。”
CHAPTER I: Insarov bowed down before her.‘O Elena!’ he whispered, ‘I don’t dare to look at you.’

第一章: “为什么？安德烈·彼得罗维奇是个大好人。我不会因为他在而感到难为情。那还有什么可以让我不好意思的呢？我已经打算向大家宣布我是你的了……而我信任安德烈·彼得罗维奇就像信任一个哥哥一样。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Why?Andrei Petrovitch is so good.I was not ashamed before him.And what have I to be ashamed of?I am ready to tell all the world that I am yours….And Andrei Petrovitch I trust like a brother.’

第一章: “他救了我！”因萨罗夫大声说,“他是这个世界上最高尚、最善良的人！”
CHAPTER I: ‘He saved me!’ cried Insarov.‘He is the noblest, kindest of men!’

第一章: “是的……你知道吗？我欠他太多太多了。你知不知道是他最先跟我说你爱我的？如果我能告诉你一切……没错，他是个高尚的人。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes…And do you know I owe everything to him?Do you know that it was he who first told me that you loved me?And if I could tell you everything….Yes, he is a noble man.’

第一章: 因萨罗夫平静地看着埃琳娜。“他也爱着你，是吧？”
CHAPTER I: Insarov looked steadily at Elena.‘He is in love with you, isn’t he?’

第一章: 埃琳娜把头垂了下去。“他确实爱过我。”她小声地说。
CHAPTER I: Elena dropped her eyes.‘He did love me,’ she said in an undertone.

第一章: 因萨罗夫温柔地捧起她的手。“哦，你们这些俄国人，”他说，“你们有金子般的心！他，他就这样一直守着我，整夜不合眼。而你，亲爱的，我的天使……你没有责备，毫不犹豫……而这一切都是为了我，为了我啊——”
CHAPTER I: Insarov pressed her hand warmly.‘Oh you Russians,’ he said, ‘you have hearts of pure gold!And he, he has been waiting on me, he has not slept at night.And you, you, my angel…. No reproaches, no hesitations… and all this for me, for me—’

第一章: “是的，这一切都是为了你，因为他们爱你，德米特里！真是匪夷所思啊！我想我以前应该给你讲过，但是没关系，我很高兴可以再说一次，你也一定会很想听的。当我第一次遇见你——”
CHAPTER I: ‘Yes, yes, all for you, because they love you, Ah, Dmitri!How strange it is!I think I have talked to you of it before, but it doesn’t matter, I like to repeat it, and you will like to hear it.When I saw you the first time—’

第一章: “你眼睛里为什么含着泪水呢？”因萨罗夫打断了她。
CHAPTER I: ‘Why are there tears in your eyes?’Insarov interrupted her.

第一章: “眼泪？有吗？”她用手帕把眼泪擦干。“哦，小傻瓜！他不知道人们也会因为幸福而流泪。我想给你说，当我第一次看见你的时候，我并没有从你身上看出什么特别的地方，真的。我记得舒宾给我的印象更深，虽然我并不爱他。至于安德烈·彼得罗维奇嘛——哦，有一瞬间我确实在想，这就是我心中的那个他吗？对你，我没有任何这样的感觉。但是，后来——后来——你突然就偷走了我的心！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Tears?Are there?’She wiped her eyes with her handkerchief.‘Oh, what a silly boy!He doesn’t know yet that people weep from happiness.I wanted to tell you: when I saw you the first time, I saw nothing special in you, really.I remember, Shubin struck me much more at first, though I never loved him, and as for Andrei Petrovitch—oh, there was a moment when I thought: isn’t this he?And with you there was nothing of that sort; but afterwards—afterwards—you took my heart by storm!’

第一章: “请原谅我。”因萨罗夫说。他想要站起来，但是刚一起身就又跌到沙发上。
CHAPTER I: ‘Have pity on me,’ began Insarov.He tried to get up, but dropped down on to the sofa again at once.

第一章: “你不舒服吗？”埃琳娜焦急地问道。
CHAPTER I: ‘What’s the matter with you?’ inquired Elena anxiously.

第一章: “没什么……我还是很虚弱。我还没办法承受这突如其来的幸福。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Nothing….I am still rather weak.I am not strong enough yet for such happiness.’

第一章: “那你就安静地坐着。不要乱动，不要太过兴奋。”她用手指威胁他，说道，“你为什么要脱掉你的睡衣呢？你要恢复往日的风采还需要一段时间呢！坐下来，我给你讲故事。你只用静静地听着就好了。话说得太多也不利于你身体的恢复。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Then sit quietly.Don’t dare to move, don’t get excited,’ she added, threatening him with her finger.‘And why have you left off your dressing-gown?It’s too soon to begin to be a dandy!Sit down and I will tell you stories.Listen and be quiet.To talk much is bad for you after your illness.’

第一章: 她开始谈论舒宾，谈论库尔纳托夫斯基，谈论这两个星期她都做了些什么。她说，从报纸上看，战争似乎在所难免，因此他身体一好就必须争分夺秒地安排回国的事情。她就这样坐在他旁边，靠在他的肩膀上，慢慢地说着……
CHAPTER I: She began to talk to him about Shubin, about Kurnatovsky, and what she had been doing for the last fortnight, of how war seemed, judging from the newspapers, inevitable, and so directly he was perfectly well again, he must, without losing a minute, make arrangements for them to start.All this she told him sitting beside him, leaning on his shoulder….

第一章: 他听着她侃侃而谈，脸色忽白忽红。有时候，他想让她停下来。突然，他坐直了身体。
CHAPTER I: He listened to her, listened, turning pale and red.Sometimes he tried to stop her; suddenly he drew himself up.

第一章: “埃琳娜，”他用奇怪的声音对她说道，“离开我，快走。”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena,’ he said to her in a strange, hard voice ‘leave me, go away.’

第一章: “什么？”她困惑地说，很快又补充道，“你感觉不舒服？”
CHAPTER I: ‘What?’ she replied in bewilderment ‘You feel ill?’ she added quickly.

第一章: “不……我很好……只是，请你现在离开我吧。”
CHAPTER I: ‘No… I’m all right… but, please, leave me now.’

第一章: “我不明白你的意思。你在赶我走？你在干什么？”她突然说道。他从沙发上俯下身去，几乎都要挨着地了，然后把嘴唇印在了她的脚上。“不要这样，德米特里……德米特里——”
CHAPTER I: ‘I don’t understand you.You drive me away?..What are you doing?’ she said suddenly; he had bent over from the sofa almost to the ground, and was pressing her feet to his lips.‘Don’t do that, Dmitri…. Dmitri—’

第一章: 他站了起来。
CHAPTER I: He got up.

第一章: “那就离开我吧！你知道的，埃琳娜，我生病的时候，一开始我还没有失去意识，我知道我站在死亡深渊的旁边，甚至是发着高烧、说胡话的时候，我都模模糊糊地感受到死神要把我带走，我觉得我将要失去生命、失去你、失去这所有的一切。我放弃了希望……而这突然的起死回生，这黑暗过后的光明，你——你在我身边，陪着我——你的声音，你的呼吸……这都让我无法承受！我感觉到自己热烈地爱着你，我听到你说你是我的，但是我没有办法回答我自己……你走吧！”
CHAPTER I: ‘Then leave me!You see, Elena, when I was taken ill, I did not lose consciousness at first; I knew I was on the edge of the abyss; even in the fever, in delirium I knew, I felt vaguely that it was death coming to me, I took leave of life, of you, of everything; I gave up hope….And this return to life so suddenly; this light after the darkness, you—you—near me, with me—your voice, your breath….It’s more than I can stand!I feel I love you passionately, I hear you call yourself mine, I cannot answer for myself…You must go!’

第一章: “德米特里。”埃琳娜把头靠在他的肩膀上，喃喃地说道。直到现在她才明白他的意思。
CHAPTER I: ‘Dmitri,’ whispered Elena, and she nestled her head on his shoulder.Only now she understood him.

第一章: “埃琳娜，”他继续说道，“我爱你，这你是知道的。我已经准备好随时为了你牺牲我自己……为什么你这个时候要在我的身边，在我还很虚弱的时候，在我还没有办法控制自己的时候，在我浑身的血液都像火一样在燃烧的时候……你说，你是我的……你爱我——”
CHAPTER I: ‘Elena,’ he went on, ‘I love you, you know that; I am ready to give my life for you…. Why have you come to me now, when I am weak, when I can’t control myself, when all my blood’s on fire… you are mine, you say… you love me——’

第一章: “德米特里。”她又叫了一声，脸涨得通红，更用力地靠向他。
CHAPTER I: ‘Dmitri,’ she repeated; she flushed all over, and pressed still closer to him.

第一章: “埃琳娜，可怜可怜我，你快走吧，我感到我快要死了……我无法承受这么炽热的感情……我的整个灵魂都渴望着你……想想，死神差点儿把我们分开……但是现在，你就在这里，你就在我的怀里……”
